Title    : Tropical Cyclone Chido - Dec 2024
Published: Tue, 10 Dec 2024 00:00:00 +0000
Summary  :
<div class="tag country">Affected countries: Comoros, Madagascar, Malawi, Mayotte (France), Mozambique</div>
                                      <div class="tag glide">Glide: TC-2024-000224-MOZ</div>
                                                          <p>Tropical Cyclone Chido is expected to make landfall in Pemba in the early hours of Sunday, 15 December, with the intensity of an Intense Tropical Cyclone.</p>
<p>A number of provinces in the norther part of the country are forecasted to be impacted, primarily Cabo Delgado and Nampula, but also Niassa, Tete and, to a lesser extent, Zambezia.</p>
<p>Heavy rains (up to 200mm/24h) and strong winds (up to 120 km/h) are forecasted over the period 15-17 December; Chido has the same intensity of Tropical Cyclones Gombe (2022) and Freddy (2023).</p>
<p>The WFP-managed Disaster Analysis and Mapping (ADAM) system indicates that 1.7 million people are exposed to the Tropical Cyclone Chido, including a million people in Cabo Delgado who could be impacted by winds of more than 120 km/h.</p>
<p>The Government-led Technical Council for Disaster Management met in Maputo on 12 December and informed that al river basins are currently below the alert levels. However, several basins around the at-risk areas might reach alert levels.
Pemba City is at risk of urban floods, specifically the following areas: Bairro Cariaco, Alto Chuiba, Eduardo Mondlane, Natite, Ingonane, Paquetequete, Carioca.</p>
<p>There are concerns that due to cyclone Chido, the ongoing cholera outbreak in Nampula (283 cases and 21 deaths reported, as of 11 December) might deteriorate further. (<a href="https://reliefweb.int/node/4118111/">OCHA, 13 Dec 2024</a>)</p>
<p>On 15 December, Tropical Cyclone Chido made landfall in Mozambique. According to the National Institute for Natural Disasters (INGD), as of 24 December 2024, an estimated 453,971 people have been impacted, with 120 fatalities and 868 injuries reported. (<a href="https://reliefweb.int/node/4135935/">OCHA, 13 Dec 2024</a>)</p>
=== ENTRY END ===

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : South Sudan: Incendiary Bombs Kill, Burn Civilians
Published: Wed, 09 Apr 2025 23:00:00 -0400
Summary  :
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Remnants of a burnt tukul (home) in Mathiang, South Sudan, following an attack with an incendiary weapon on March 16, 2025. Many tukuls and other civilian objects were burnt in the fires from incendiary weapons use.
                    ©  2025 Private
          
    


  
<p>(Nairobi) – South Sudan’s use of improvised air-dropped incendiary weapons has killed and horrifically burned dozens of people, including children, and destroyed civilian infrastructure in Upper Nile state, Human Rights Watch said today. The government’s use of these weapons in populated areas may amount to war crimes.</p><p>Interviewees described the use of improvised incendiary weapons in at least four attacks in Nasir, Longechuk, and Ulang counties, Upper Nile state, which killed at least 58 people and burned others severely. The United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS), which has a&nbsp;robust mandate to protect civilians, should establish temporary operating bases in high risk areas, and proactively respond to the deteriorating situation. UN Security Council members should urge South Sudan to cease its unlawful attacks and call for the urgent deployment of peacekeeping forces to the affected areas.</p><p>“These weapons have killed dozens of people, including children, and left survivors with severe burn injuries causing long-term harm,” said&nbsp;Nyagoah Tut Pur, South Sudan researcher at Human Rights Watch. “The government should immediately stop using indiscriminate incendiary weapons on communities, facilitate safe aid access, and the UN should urgently deploy peacekeepers to the affected areas.”</p><p>The government’s&nbsp;aerial bombardments intensified from March 16, 2025, after a March 4 attack on a&nbsp;government military base and&nbsp;Nasir town by armed Nuer youth known as the “White Army” and a March 7&nbsp;attack by armed men on a UN helicopter that killed a UN crew member and over two dozen South Sudanese soldiers.</p>



      


  
  




  
          
                  


                  
          Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Locations of attacks documented by Human Rights Watch in Upper Nile, South Sudan in March 2025.&nbsp;
                    © 2025 Human Rights Watch
          
    


  
<p>On March 17, South Sudan’s information minister said its air force had bombed “so called White Army areas” and falsely implied that civilians who failed to leave the areas&nbsp;could lawfully be targeted. He revealed that Uganda was&nbsp;providing technical support to the South Sudan People’s Defence Forces (SSPDF), which Uganda has&nbsp;acknowledged.</p><p>A Ugandan forces’ spokesperson told Human Rights Watch that their support did not include aerial or ground attacks but could, if requested and they deemed it necessary. The Ugandan forces previously&nbsp;refuted allegations that it had targeted civilians and civilian objects and or used “chemical weapons and barrel bombs.”&nbsp;</p><p>Incendiary weapons&nbsp;inflict excruciating burns and other physical injuries, which can lead to&nbsp;psychological harm and lifelong scarring and disability, which can result in social and economic exclusion. They also&nbsp;cause fires that can indiscriminately destroy civilian objects. Use of these weapons in populated areas violates international humanitarian law, and if done with criminal intent, constitutes a war crime.&nbsp;</p><p>Protocol III to the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons explicitly prohibits using air-dropped weapons designed to set fires and burn people in “concentrations of civilians.” While South Sudan is not party to this protocol, its use of these weapons highlights the need to strengthen the international law that governs them.&nbsp;</p><p>Eight people interviewed, including witnesses, local responders, and two government officials, described the March 16 attack on Mathiang, in Longechuk county.&nbsp;</p><p>Witnesses described “barrels”—improvised incendiary weapons—being dropped from what appeared to be a multi-engine aircraft. A 39-year-old woman said: “It came swooping down, I thought it was going to fall on our compound…. Then we saw it drop barrels. As they dropped, [they caught fire].”&nbsp;</p><p>Another woman, 40, woke up feeling “the earth shaking…,” and ran outside … “only to see the village on fire.” She later saw the charred bodies of her neighbors, Khor Ruach Kerjiok, his wife, and their two children under age 10. Another resident said that the burned bodies of two older women aged 60 and above, Nyedier Kuach and Nyeget Kier, were found at home.</p><p>A senior health official said that at least 21 people were killed, 3 of whom died while being transported to Ethiopia for treatment. Health workers responding with very limited resources said the victims had extensive burn injuries. One said the burns continued to spread on the patients’ bodies, indicating that a substance that causes burns was used in the attack.</p><p>Accounts from witnesses describing what they saw and could smell when the improvised incendiary weapons were dropped, indicate that several types of flammable substances are being used as incendiary agents.&nbsp;</p><p>One responder explained how “[t]he area where the [flammable substance] landed was burning for some days, making crackling sounds.” Rain eventually extinguished the fires, “But it still smells … not like gasoline or kerosene,” he said.</p><p>Several residential compounds were burned, along with, a responder said, part of the market and two water pumps.&nbsp;</p><p>A video posted on social media on March 17 shows a fissure in the ground with visible active fire inside. The video reveals a large, burned area, including several tukuls (homes). Satellite imagery shows a burn scar appeared between March 16 to 17, along with burned tukuls 100 meters northeast of the market.</p>



      


  
  




  
          
                  


                  
          Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Satellite imagery from March 30, 2025, showing burned tukuls (homes) in Mathiang after an attack on March 16. A linear burn scar is visible on satellite imagery and its location was also confirmed by witness accounts.
                    © 2025 Planet Labs PBC. Analysis and graphics © 2025 Human Rights Watch
          
    


  
<p>Two witnesses said at least three women suffered miscarriages or stillbirths following the bombing.&nbsp;</p><p>Air-dropped improvised incendiary weapons were also used in Nasir town on March 16 and 19. Two officials said that at least 22 people were killed and dozens of homes burned. Human Rights Watch has also reviewed satellite imagery showing burn scars and burned structures, including a former UNMISS site and dozens of structures along the main road between March 16 and 20.</p>



      


  
  




  
          
                  


                  
          Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Satellite imagery from March 25, 2025, showing multiple burned structures and burn scars over several parts of Nasir town following the attacks of March 16 and March 19, 2025.
                    © 2025 Planet Labs PBC. Analysis and graphics © 2025 Human Rights Watch.
          
    


  
<p>Interviewees and photographs suggest that an incendiary weapon was also dropped in Kuich in Ulang county on March 21. Three witnesses describe seeing what appeared to be a propeller-driven aircraft drop incendiary substances in barrels.&nbsp;</p><p>“[The aircraft] dropped something that was on fire and there was a loud explosion [when it hit the ground] and immediately the surrounding caught fire,” one person said. Everyone started running in different directions.” When he returned to the site, he learned that “people [had been] killed on the spot and many people were seriously injured.”</p><p>Four witnesses said the attack killed 15 people, including 3 children, and seriously burned 17 others. A responder in Ulang town described victims, most with burn injuries, “their black skin is coming out. One man who died at the hospital was burned even his teeth. I also saw an older woman in her 70s, she had big blisters.” As of March 30, seven remained in critical condition.&nbsp;</p><p>Civilian structures burned included a nutrition center and a healthcare clinic. A guard there, Duop Bichiok Diew, in his 50s, died from burn injuries. Shelters and a market were also destroyed.&nbsp;</p><p>Photographs posted on social media on March 24, show several structures reduced to ashes near Sobat River in Kuich. Next to the nutrition center, visible impact sites were still burning. Satellite imagery confirmed that at least a dozen structures burned between March 21 and 22.</p>



      


  
  




  
          
                  


                  
          Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Satellite imagery from March 25, 2025, showing burned structures including a destroyed nutrition center in Kuich, after the March 21 attack.&nbsp;
                    © 2025 Planet Labs PBC. Analysis and graphics © 2025 Human Rights Watch.  
          
    


  
<p>Government attacks on populated areas in the three counties, notably with helicopter gunfire and munitions continue, putting civilians at further risk and worsening the humanitarian situation, which already included a cholera outbreak.&nbsp;</p><p>Tens of thousands of people have fled, including into Ethiopia. Humanitarian access remains heavily constrained, as aid organizations&nbsp;face violence as well as&nbsp;bureaucratic restrictions.</p><p>South Sudan remains under a&nbsp;UN arms embargo prohibiting external military support to the country’s warring parties. Ugandan forces’&nbsp;participation in the operations violates the embargo. The Security Council should call out Uganda’s violations and ensure renewal of the embargo to protect civilians from unlawful violence, Human Rights Watch said. The council should press South Sudan to ensure that the UN mission can safely operate and approve any requests for additional UN troops.</p><p>“As the government of South Sudan continues to show utter disregard for civilians, it is now dropping flaming barrels of fire from the air,” Pur said. “The international community should press the government to end these unlawful attacks and ensure concrete steps to protect civilian lives.”</p>
=== ENTRY END ===

Source: Doctors Without Borders - USA - Medical aid where it is needed most. Independent. Neutral. Impartial.
=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : MSF steps up Myanmar earthquake response
Published: Wed, 09 Apr 2025 19:51:20 +0000
Summary  :
<span>MSF steps up Myanmar earthquake response</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"> MSF teams are distributing essential non-food items, helping restore clean water sources, and providing physical and mental health care. </div>
  </div>
<span><span>Kate Rankin</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2025-04-09T15:51:20-04:00" title="Wednesday, April 9, 2025 - 3:51pm">April 9 2025, 3:51pm</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="Mobile clinics in Mandalay" height="1196" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB227455.jpg" width="1594" />

</div>
  </div>
  <div class="field field--name-body field--type-text-with-summary field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>MSF has prioritized responding in the hardest-hit and currently accessible cities of Mandalay and Naypyidaw, while serious concerns persist for people living in more remote and less accessible areas such as Sagaing.</p><p>As of April 8, over 3,600 deaths have been reported, more than 5,000 people injured, and an estimated 17 million individuals affected—many severely. Key infrastructure sustained significant damage, including hospitals, roads, and water systems, while ongoing telecommunication disruptions continue to hamper relief efforts.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>The earthquake struck a country already gripped by several health crises and conflict, compounding the challenges communities face. Limited resources, staff, and supplies have left some facilities overburdened and struggling to respond to the growing health needs.</p><p>While local communities are demonstrating remarkable solidarity, our staff have reported extensive destruction. Many residents remain outdoors for fear of aftershocks, while monasteries have opened their doors to host displaced families.&nbsp;</p></div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />

            View of the Naypyidaw Hospital after the March 28 earthquake. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Myanmar 2025 © MSF

</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Damaged infrastructure compromises health care</h2><p>In the hardest-hit cities, damage to infrastructure has severely impacted hospitals' ability to function. Due to fears of further building collapse, structural damage has forced medical staff to treat patients outside in some cases.&nbsp;</p><p>In Naypyidaw and Mandalay, where hospital systems were particularly damaged, MSF carried out assessments, delivered medical supplies, and initiated discussions with key stakeholders, including the Ministry of Health.</p><p>In Mandalay, our teams are working to improve water, sanitation, and hygiene conditions in damaged hospitals by installing water tanks and additional handwashing basins. Teams are reinforcing waste management with dozens of bins and helping patients cope with extreme heat –often reaching 104°F –while awaiting treatment outside damaged facilities by setting up fans.</p><p>At the same time, mobile medical teams began providing consultations in makeshift shelters including monasteries, treating a range of conditions from common illnesses to chronic diseases such as diabetes and hypertension. In southern Shan, mobile teams also distributed essential non-food items, restored clean water sources, and continued assessments in affected and displaced communities.</p></div>
</div>

              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Psychological impact of the earthquake</h2><p>A key priority for our response is <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/mental-health" title="Mental health">mental health</a>. In Mandalay, teams composed of trained staff and student volunteers have been visiting patients in surgical, orthopedic, and trauma wards at local hospitals to provide <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/what-psychological-first-aid" title="What is psychological first aid?">psychological first aid</a>. In a context where survivors face high levels of psychological stress, these efforts are essential. The disaster and the fear of aftershocks, which continue to be recorded, in addition to the consequences of the ongoing conflict ravaging many parts of the country, contribute to this stress.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Damage caused to a market by the Myanmar earthquake. " height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB226982.jpg?itok=NonlHmMo" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            A view of damage to the Thapyay Kone Market in Naypyidaw after the earthquake.   
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Major concerns over expected environmental impact</h2><p>With the rainy season approaching, floods and landslides could exacerbate existing access challenges, particularly in remote areas. The rainy season also significantly heightens the likelihood of public health threats associated with outbreaks of waterborne disease such as <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>, and vector-borne diseases like <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a> or dengue fever. This is due to the potential flood-related contamination of the already reduced number of safe water sources. Immediate actions like scaled up provision of clean water, safe sanitation facilities, distribution of mosquito nets, and hygiene promotion are essential to mitigate the additional threats.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="content__wrapper">

              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>What needs to happen now?</h2><p>In order to address the immense needs, it is crucial for humanitarian aid to reach all affected areas, including hard-to-reach locations, unhindered. To avoid longer-term harmful consequences for people grappling with the aftermath of this earthquake, a further significant scale-up of aid and assurance of access to health care in all affected areas is urgently needed.&nbsp;</p><p>As part of MSF’s long-standing presence in Myanmar since its first intervention in 1992, we reaffirm our readiness to provide emergency medical humanitarian assistance wherever needed, as we continue to support communities affected by conflict, disease, and now, one of the worst earthquakes to strike the region in recent history.</p></div>

Title    : Taiwan’s OAC steps up marine conservation
Published: 2025/04/11
Summary  :
<div class="article-content-part">The Ocean Affairs Council is implementing a research sponsorship program for the second year to foster technological innovation and applications to ensure sustainable marine conservation.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The OAC said it will offer NT$75 million (US$2.28 million) in research grants to 30 selected projects on topics spanning maritime protection and security, ocean pollution prevention, sustainable marine development and smart ocean, as well as surface and underwater vehicle technology development, which are all important subjects of global marine research.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
According to the agency, the country&rsquo;s abundant territorial waters and marine resources render it important for Taiwan to enhance marine technological prowess. This will ensure that local businesses are both globally competitive and meet environmental challenges such as climate change, it said.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
In comparison to the NT$14 million spent last year, the increased amount underscores the importance the government attaches to marine technology development, the OAC said. The grants aim to facilitate research and development of marine technology and cultivate personnel, so as to lay an even stronger sustainable marine development foundation, the agency added.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
In addition to the research sponsorship, the OAC launched the Marine Pollution Control Fund committee April 9 and Minister Kuan Bi-ling convened the first meeting the same day. The 17-member committee comprises academics and experts with a wide range of expertise and marks a major milestone in government policymaking, it said.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
OAC statistics show that the fund has accumulated NT$210 million as of March this year. With an annual reserve of NT$50 million allocated since 2024, the goal is for the fund to reach NT$500 million in total to ensure the government has enough resources to respond to major marine pollution incidents, the agency added. (SFC-E)<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Write to Taiwan Today at <a href="mailto:ttonline@mofa.gov.tw">ttonline@mofa.gov.tw</a></div>

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : A "Remarkable" Afghan Ceasefire
Published: Fri, 22 Jun 2018 21:50:54 +0000
Summary  :
<div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><img src="http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Afghan%20ALP_USMC%20Image_20120414_b.jpg" /></span></strong></span></strong></p>
<p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 8.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 8.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">Image Source: U.S. Marine Corps, Cpl. Reece Lodder (Flickr)</span></span></p>
<p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><br /></span></strong></span></strong></p>
<p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">A “Remarkable” Afghan Ceasefire</span></strong></span></strong></p>
<p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">By Scott DesMarais</span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">Key Takeaway:</span></em></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> The U.S. and Afghanistan have an opportunity to advance their strategic goal of negotiating an acceptable settlement with the Taliban, but not all Taliban members are reconcilable. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The Taliban faces a potential rift between its leadership and rank-and-file militants in Afghanistan that threatens the Taliban’s cohesion. Large numbers of rank-and-file militants expressed their support for peace during unprecedented joint celebrations alongside Afghan National Security Forces (ANSF) during a nationwide ceasefire for Eid al-Fitr on June 15 - 17. The ceasefire’s events exposed rifts amongst Taliban leadership concerning reconciliation. The U.S. and the Government of Afghanistan could exploit these apparent rifts in order to advance their strategic goal of a negotiated settlement with the Taliban. The new momentum towards peace could nonetheless generate additional pressure for the withdrawal of the U.S. from Afghanistan amidst the scheduled 2018 Afghan Parliamentary Elections.<strong> </strong>ISIS - Wilayat Khorasan could also exploit these rifts in to bolster its recruitment of hardline Taliban militants and expand its operations in Afghanistan.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">What Happened</span></span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">The Taliban and Afghan National Security Forces (ANSF) engaged in “</span></strong><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/in-remarkable-scenes-taliban-fighters-join-eid-celebrations-across-afghanistan-as-cease-fire-begins/2018/06/15/8c48e7c4-70ab-11e8-b4d8-eaf78d4c544c_story.html?noredirect=on&amp;utm_term=.4741279e9cb0"><strong><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">remarkable scenes</span></strong></a></span><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">” of joint celebration during a three-day ceasefire observed by both the Taliban and the ANSF. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The Government of Afghanistan </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/17/world/asia/afghanistan-bombing-taliban-isis.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; color: #1155cc;">estimated</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> that up to 30,000 Taliban militants entered government-held cities across the country during the three-day truce in honor of the end of Ramadan.<span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span style="background: white;"><span><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"><sup>1 </sup></span></span></span></span></span>The </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/the-eid-ceasefire-allowing-afghans-to-imagine-their-country-at-peace/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">gatherings</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> reportedly occurred in several regions that have seen intense fighting during the Taliban’s 2018 Al-Khandaq Offensive including Faryab, Farah, Ghazni, and Kunduz Provinces as well as traditional Taliban strongholds such as </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/16/atmar-taliban-soldiers-selfies-%E2%80%98war-flames-fueled-outside%E2%80%99"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Helmand</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> and </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/the-eid-ceasefire-allowing-afghans-to-imagine-their-country-at-peace/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Kandahar</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> Provinces. Even “senior” leaders reportedly met with government officials in </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/the-eid-ceasefire-allowing-afghans-to-imagine-their-country-at-peace/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Zabul</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> and </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://twitter.com/voadeewa/status/1007626016657944577?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw&amp;ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.afghanistan-analysts.org%2Fthe-eid-ceasefire-allowing-afghans-to-imagine-their-country-at-peace%2F"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Logar</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> Provinces. Taliban fighters interviewed by the media repeatedly </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/17/world/asia/afghanistan-bombing-taliban-isis.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan&amp;action=click&amp;contentCollection=world&amp;region=stream&amp;module=stream_unit&amp;version=latest&amp;contentPlacement=3&amp;pgtype=collection"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">expressed</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> their fatigue with continued violence and their </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"></a><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; color: #1155cc;">growing</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> desire for peace.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">The ceasefire could validate President Ghani’s strategy to achieve a negotiated settlement. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">Ghani </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-taliban/afghanistans-ghani-offers-talks-with-taliban-without-preconditions-idUSKCN1GC0J0"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">offered</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> the Taliban full political reconciliation in exchange for a ceasefire and the resumption of peace negotiations on February 28. The Taliban refused to acknowledge the offer officially, although multiple U.S. officials have claimed that </span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">elements of the Taliban including “</span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-afghanistan/taliban-talking-and-fighting-says-u-s-commander-in-afghanistan-idUSKCN1IV2HP"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">senior-level leaders</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">” are “</span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/13/asia/mattis-afghanistan-taliban-peace-talks-intl/index.html"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">clearly interested</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">” in talks with the Government of Afghanistan since Ghani’s peace offer. <span style="background: white;">Ghani later unilaterally </span></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/07/world/asia/afghanistan-ashraf-ghani-cease-fire-taliban.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan&amp;action=click&amp;contentCollection=world&amp;region=stream&amp;module=stream_unit&amp;version=latest&amp;contentPlacement=1&amp;pgtype=collection"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">announced</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> the ceasefire for Eid al-Fitr on June 7 despite ongoing operations by the Taliban that </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/7-provincial-centers-face-%E2%80%98serious-security-threats"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">threatened</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> at least seven provincial capitals around Afghanistan. The Taliban bowed to public pressure and </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/09/world/asia/taliban-cease-fire-afghanistan.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">announced</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> their own nominally-unrelated ceasefire on June 9. Ghani has attempted to leverage the apparent success of the truce to spur further political progress. Ghani </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;"><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-taliban-palace/afghan-president-extends-ceasefire-with-taliban-by-10-days-idUSKBN1JD0R6">announced</a> </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">a unilateral ten-day extension of the ceasefire - until June 30 – on June 17. He also stressed that his government is open to negotiations with the Taliban on “issues of mutual concern” including the “</span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/afghan-government-extends-cease-fire-with-taliban-as-fighters-join-civilians-to-celebrate-eid/2018/06/16/a3fcecce-7170-11e8-b4d8-eaf78d4c544c_story.html?noredirect=on&amp;utm_term=.b022e704f63d"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; color: #1155cc;">presence of foreign forces</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">” in Afghanistan.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The Taliban leadership has thus far rejected further extension of a ceasefire and has resumed its attacks in some remote locations</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">. The Taliban spokesperson </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afp.com/en/news/205/taliban-say-ceasefire-wont-be-extended-suicide-attack-kills-18-doc-16341x6"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">stated</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> that the group has “no intention to extend the ceasefire" on June 17 and resumed offensive operations throughout Afghanistan including on June 18. Taliban militants conducted significant attacks in </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/18/4-security-personnel-killed-taliban-attacks"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Faryab</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">, </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.voanews.com/a/taliban-afghan-attack/4446599.html"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN-US">Badghis</span></a></span><span class="MsoHyperlink"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">, and </span></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/20/policemen-among-24-killed-farah-clashes-raid"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Farah</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> Provinces since their ceasefire’s expiration. The Taliban may intend to exploit the government’s extended ceasefire to amass fighters and launch a coordinated operation against </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/7-provincial-centers-face-%E2%80%98serious-security-threats"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">vulnerable</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> provincial capitals in Faryab or Farah Provinces. The Taliban also executed smaller attacks </span><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">in many provinces where joint celebrations occurred such as </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/clashes-resume-kunduz-after-eid-ceasefire"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Kunduz</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">, </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/20/4-taliban-killed-many-security-personnel-injured-logar-helmand-clashes"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Logar</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">, </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/19/policemen-among-7-dead-nangarhar-assault"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Nangarhar</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">, and </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/20/4-taliban-killed-many-security-personnel-injured-logar-helmand-clashes"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Helmand</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">Implications</span></span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The Taliban faces a potential rift between its leadership and rank-and-file militants in Afghanistan that threatens the Taliban’s cohesiveness. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">Taliban militants repeatedly </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/17/world/asia/afghanistan-bombing-taliban-isis.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">violated</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> a formal directive from their leadership to avoid government-controlled areas on June 16. Taliban fighters also </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://twitter.com/1TVNewsAF/status/1008650300381679616"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">demanded</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> an extension to the ceasefire in parts of Paktika Province </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/the-eid-ceasefire-allowing-afghans-to-imagine-their-country-at-peace/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">controlled</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> by the hardline Haqqani Network. The Taliban released an official post-ceasefire statement stressing the organizational cohesion and control demonstrated by the “successful implementation” of the truce despite the clear violations of leadership orders.<sup><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif;" xml:lang="EN">2 </span></span></span></span></sup><span>The Taliban leadership also allegedly </span></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">considered</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> a ten-day ceasefire for late 2018 due to growing pressure for a negotiated settlement within the Taliban.</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> The Government of Afghanistan and the U.S. could attempt to exploit the apparent divisions within the Taliban to split rank-and-file fighters from their leadership if the Taliban refuses to engage with Kabul.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The Taliban also faces a power struggle within its ruling Quetta Shura. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The ceasefire could exacerbate a </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/50-quetta-shura-supports-peace-talks-says-raziq"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">rift</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> between Taliban leaders who are open to reconciliation and hardliners unwilling to negotiate a settlement. The joint celebrations reportedly </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"></a><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; color: #1155cc;">surprised</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> and angered some Taliban leaders including Taliban Second Deputy Leader </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Mullah Yaqoob</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">.<sup><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif;" xml:lang="EN">3</span></span></span></span></sup> Taliban leader Mullah Haibatullah Akhundzada – a reported </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.crpaweb.org/single-post/2018/03/20/Do-the-Taliban-Have-any-Appetite-for-Reconciliation-with-Kabul-Antonio-Giustozzi"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">moderate</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> - may use widespread support for peace amongst the rank-and-file to consolidate his control within the Quetta Shura vis-à-vis hardliners such as Mullah Yaqoob and First Deputy Leader </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Haqqani_Network_0.pdf"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Siraj Haqqani</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">. This power struggle predates the ceasefire. Akhundzada reportedly </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/02/01/new-appointments-reflect-power-struggle-within-taliban"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">reshuffled</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> multiple shadow governors and senior leaders to increase his control over the movement in February 2018. </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.khaama.com/taliban-reshuffles-leadership-council-after-eid-ceasefire-05385/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Rumors</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> of additional post-ceasefire leadership changes may further demonstrate shifting dynamics in favor of Akhundzada. The weakening of hardliners like Haqqani - who maintains </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Haqqani_Network_0.pdf"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">close ties</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> to al Qaeda and Pakistan - in favor of Akhundzada could open space for peace-inclined factions of the Taliban to pursue a negotiated settlement. Hardline elements are likely to continue the fight against Kabul.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">The U.S. could exploit these apparent rifts in order to advance its strategic objectives in Afghanistan. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">The U.S. intends to use military and diplomatic means to </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.defense.gov/News/Transcripts/Transcript-View/Article/1382901/department-of-defense-press-briefing-by-general-nicholson-via-teleconference-fr/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">pressure</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> the Taliban to negotiate a peace settlement with the Government of Afghanistan. </span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2018/06/283271.htm"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">stated</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> that the U.S. is “prepared to support, facilitate, and participate” in peace negotiations that would include “a discussion of the role of international actors and forces” in Afghanistan on June 16. U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs Alice Wells </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://docs.house.gov/meetings/FA/FA00/20180620/108448/HHRG-115-FA00-Wstate-WellsA-20180620.pdf"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">reaffirmed</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> the willingness to participate in negotiations but reiterated the established U.S. position that the Taliban must negotiate directly with the Government of Afghanistan on June 20. Incoming U.S. Forces – Afghanistan Commander <span style="background: white;">Lt. Gen. Scott Miller has also testified that a </span></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.defense.gov/News/Article/Article/1554390/resolute-support-nominee-effort-still-needed-to-prevent-homeland-attacks/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">political settlement</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> must end the War in Afghanistan.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The U.S. nonetheless must remain cautious that the peace process does not jeopardize its access to Afghanistan. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">Members of the both houses of the Afghan Parliament have </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/violence-increased-afghanistan-following-trump-strategy"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">criticized</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> the U.S. role in Afghanistan since May 2018. Some members of the upper house have </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/index.php/afghanistan/cancel-security-agreements-us-and-nato-senators"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">called</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> for the review or cancellation of the Bilateral Security Agreement (BSA) between the U.S. and Afghanistan.<sup><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif;" xml:lang="EN">4 </span></span></span></span></sup>Meanwhile, </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/15/world/asia/afghanistan-peace-march-.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan&amp;action=click&amp;contentCollection=world&amp;region=stream&amp;module=stream_unit&amp;version=latest&amp;contentPlacement=6&amp;pgtype=collection">peace protesters</a> </span></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-taliban/afghan-peace-marchers-arrive-in-kabul-exhausted-and-tired-of-war-idUSKBN1JE0DZ"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">marching</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> from Helmand Province to Kabul to encourage reconciliation with the Taliban have also </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/peace-hopefully-for-a-few-days-a-ceasefire-for-eid-as-helmand-marchers-approach-kabul/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">demanded</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> a specific timeline for the withdrawal of the U.S. from Afghanistan. Taliban sources have also claimed that a clearly-defined timeline for withdrawal could have </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">persuaded</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> Taliban leadership to accept a ceasefire extension after Eid al-Fitr. These converging demands for the withdrawal of the U.S. from Afghanistan could begin to spiral into a widespread populist movement ahead of the scheduled 2018 Afghan Parliamentary Elections and 2019 Afghan Presidential Elections. The U.S. must not depart abruptly or under a fixed timeline but rather through a gradual drawdown after setting and testing the conditions for sustained peace in Afghanistan.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">ISIS could also exploit the ceasefire and possibility of a negotiated settlement to expand its operations in Afghanistan. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">ISIS’s Afghanistan branch, ISIS Wilayat Khorasan,<strong> </strong></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://ent.siteintelgroup.com/Statements/is-claims-85-casualties-in-2nd-suicide-bombing-in-24-hours-on-afghan-taliban-and-afghan-security-forces-in-nangarhar.html"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">claimed</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> two separate </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-taliban/afghanistan-eid-car-bomb-claimed-by-islamic-state-kills-26-idUSKBN1JC044"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">attacks</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> that targeted joint celebrations between the Taliban and ANSF in Nangarhar Province during Eid al-Fitr. The statements </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://ent.siteintelgroup.com/Statements/is-claims-killing-wounding-nearly-100-from-afghan-taliban-and-afghan-forces-in-what-former-calls-mysterious-explosion-in-nangarhar.html"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">noted</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> that the attacks targeted gatherings of both the ANSF and “the apostate Taliban Movement.” The Taliban later released a post-ceasefire </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; color: #1155cc;"><a href="https://ent.siteintelgroup.com/Statements/is-claims-killing-wounding-nearly-100-from-afghan-taliban-and-afghan-forces-in-what-former-calls-mysterious-explosion-in-nangarhar.html">statement</a> </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">arguing that the Taliban is the only movement leading “jihad across the country,” and adding that “multiple parties [are] not participating in this jihad.”<sup><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif;" xml:lang="EN">5 </span></span></span></span></sup>The statement - while directed against the U.S. assessment of a fractured jihadist movement in Afghanistan - may also highlight the Taliban leadership’s concern that the ceasefire will harm their credentials as the leaders of the jihad in Afghanistan. ISIS could position itself to recruit </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.crpaweb.org/single-post/2017/12/15/Enemies-or-Jihad-Brothers-Relations-Between-Taliban-and-Islamic-State"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">dissatisfied hardline</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> members of the Taliban if Taliban leadership begin openly pursuing a peaceful settlement with the Government of Afghanistan.</span></p>
<div>

The Taliban’s “unrelated” ceasefire only lasted from June 15 - 17. </span></p>

Source: ProPublica
=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : Connecticut DMV Never Set Up System to Enforce a Century-Old Towing Law
Published: Mon, 07 Apr 2025 05:00:00 -0400
Summary  :
<p class="byline">
                by <a class="name" href="https://ctmirror.org/author/daltimari/">Dave Altimari</a> and <a class="name" href="https://ctmirror.org/author/gmonk/">Ginny Monk</a>, <a href="https://ctmirror.org/">The Connecticut Mirror</a>                </p>
                                             

        
                        <p>This article was produced for ProPublica’s Local Reporting Network in partnership with <a href="https://ctmirror.org/">The Connecticut Mirror</a>. <a href="https://www.propublica.org/newsletters/dispatches">Sign up for Dispatches</a> to get stories like this one as soon as they are published.</p>

        

    
      
  



                    
<p>This year, the head of Connecticut’s Department of Motor Vehicles made a startling public admission, telling lawmakers that the agency, which regulates the towing industry, has never enforced a century-old law meant to protect drivers whose cars are towed.</p>

<p>Under that law, if vehicle owners don’t reclaim their towed cars or can’t afford the fees, towing companies can sell them, but they are required to hold onto the proceeds for a year so the vehicle owner can claim the money. Tow companies are entitled to subtract their fees. But, even if the owner still doesn’t come forward, the companies aren’t supposed to pocket the profits and must turn over any remaining money to the state.</p>

<p>DMV Commissioner Tony Guerrera told lawmakers the agency had never set up a process to accept deposits and wasn’t tracking whether any money had come in.</p>

<p>In fact, the DMV commissioner said he wasn’t aware of that part of the statute until The Connecticut Mirror and ProPublica brought it to his attention last fall as part of an <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/connecticut-dmv-tow-companies-car-sales">investigation into how Connecticut’s laws favor towing companies</a> at the expense of drivers. After the story’s publication, the state treasurer’s office audited its deposits and determined that no tow truck company or the DMV had ever turned over money from sales in the history of the law.</p>

<p>In a statement, Guerrera said, “This law has been in effect since the 1930’s, yet unfortunately, there has never been a system in place to effectively monitor its implementation.”</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            Tony Guerrera, the commissioner of the Connecticut Department of Motor Vehicles, told lawmakers the state doesn’t have a system to ensure that towing companies turn over the unclaimed profits from car sales.
    
            (Shahrzad Rasekh/The Connecticut Mirror)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
<p>This failure has hurt both vehicle owners and the state itself: Owners don’t have the opportunity to get money back that the law says should be theirs, and the state is missing out on both the potential payments and any interest or investment income that would accrue from the deposits.</p>

<p>The unenforced law is another example of how the DMV has failed to oversee the towing industry, which sells thousands of cars following tows each year. In an extreme case, reported by the news organizations last month, a DMV employee was found to be part of a scheme to <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/connecticut-dmv-employee-sells-towed-cars">undervalue cars and sell them for thousands in profit</a>, according to an internal DMV investigation. The employee denied he did anything wrong and still works at the DMV. </p>

<p>In another, criminal court records show, a Norwalk towing company owner was caught driving a Mercedes-Benz he had towed, racking up nearly 6,000 miles in 22 months. The tower was charged with larceny and participated in a diversion program, after which his record was expunged. CT Mirror and ProPublica have spoken to dozens of people who had their cars towed and never saw them again. Many said they weren’t notified that their cars would be sold.</p>

<p>Legislators are now aiming to create a system to make sure car owners — or eventually the state — get that money. A <a href="https://www.cga.ct.gov/2025/TOB/H/PDF/2025HB-07162-R00-HB.PDF">wide-ranging bill</a> to <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/connecticut-lawmakers-seek-overhaul-of-towing-laws">overhaul the entire towing statute</a> would require towing companies to submit documentation to the DMV of the sale price, any towing and storage fees they incurred and information on the vehicle and its owner within 15 days of a sale.</p>

<p>The bill would also reform the process of “escheating,” or remitting money to the state. After reviewing the sale document, the DMV would require the tower to send a certified letter notifying the owner or lienholder of the sales proceeds. Instead of the general fund, leftover money would be sent to the state’s unclaimed property fund and appear on a publicly posted list.</p>

<p>Guerrera said the DMV recently added more staff charged with overseeing the sales system and added a section to its website this year to ensure tow companies are aware of the requirement to turn money over to the state.</p>

<p>During an interview late last year, Guerrera said that implementing the process wasn’t the DMV’s responsibility and that doing so was up to the state treasurer’s office. But the treasurer pushed back on that in a statement, saying it fell under DMV rules. After the initial CT Mirror and ProPublica story was published, Guerrera took more ownership.</p>

<p>“I am glad this has been brought to my attention and I am more than prepared to address this issue, ensuring that it is now being handled properly and in accordance with its intended purposes,” he said in a statement.</p>

<p>The Transportation Committee approved the bill on March 19, sending it to the House. Some lawmakers opposed it, arguing the bill was intended to target a “few bad apples” but adds unnecessary regulations on all towing companies.</p>

<p>House Speaker Matt Ritter, D-Hartford, said he expects lots of debate as the bill winds its way through the legislature, but he said the escheating process needs to be addressed.</p>

<p>“There’s got to be some accountability and transparency on that for sure,” Ritter said. “This is people’s property.”</p>

<p>Timothy Vibert, president of Towing and Recovery Professionals of Connecticut, said a past association president asked DMV officials about how to return funds to the state but received no answers.</p>

<p>He said tow companies rarely make back their towing and storage fees when they sell cars and questioned why any tower would ever give the state money.</p>

<p>“There might have been a little bit of a windfall with one car or another, but there’s been a whole lot of losers, so why does the state get a chance to take it?” asked Vibert, who owns Farmington Motor Sports. </p>

<p>He added that many towers would rather return the cars.</p>

<p>“What the towers are doing is keeping those cars and then just getting rid of them for $500 or $600,” Vibert added. “So we’re keeping the cars for, I’m going to guess 45 days, maybe sometimes 50, depending on the paperwork, and then we’re just disposing of them because they’re not worth anything.”</p>

<p>House Minority Leader Vincent Candelora, R-North Branford, said he thinks there usually isn’t money left over after fees. “I think, frankly, what usually happens is the tow companies wait for the towing and storage fees to exceed the value, so it never ends up going to the state or back to the individual,” he said.</p>

<p>Kristianne Hall experienced the fees piling up firsthand while she was bartending in downtown New Haven. The job posed a delicate balance. She had to work her shift and offer sufficient service to get good tips. But she also had to keep the parking meter fed. There were a few times Hall couldn’t get to the meter, and parking tickets stacked up.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            Kristianne Hall said she should have received thousands of dollars after her car was towed and sold, but she never got anything.
    
            (Octavio Jones for ProPublica)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
<p>In 2015, her car got booted and then towed when she couldn’t afford to pay the $500 to get the device taken off. By the time she had that money saved, she said, the towing company quoted her $2,000 to get the vehicle back from its lot.</p>

<p>Hall couldn’t afford that and never saw the car again. She estimated the 2008 Chevrolet Aveo was worth about $5,000, which is supported by a Kelley Blue Book report, thousands more than what the towing company told her she’d need to pay to get it back.</p>

<p>“Why was I not entitled to the rest of that money if I own that car outright?” she asked.</p>

<p>After the tow, Hall struggled to get to and from work. She had to take an Uber home because the city bus stopped running before her shifts ended. She quickly ran low on money and had to turn to her roommates to help her pay bills before she eventually moved in with her grandparents in Florida.</p>

<p>“I felt like a failure because I couldn’t hack it,” Hall said. “It was a really, really hard and almost traumatic situation.”</p>
        
    
                    
    
        <p>
            <strong><a href="https://www.propublica.org/getinvolved/car-towing-connecticut-help-propublica-investigate">Has Your Car Been Towed in Connecticut? Share Your Story and Help Us Investigate.</a></strong>
        </p>

            
             

                                    
        
                        <p><a href="https://www.propublica.org/people/asia-fields">Asia Fields</a> contributed reporting.</p>

Title    : Google sued for £5bn in UK over allegations of shutting out rivals
Published: Wed, 16 Apr 2025 14:59:59 GMT
Summary  :
<p>Class action argues US tech firm charged more for advertising on its preinstalled apps than it could in fair market</p><p>Google is being sued in the UK for up to £5bn in damages over allegations it shut out rivals in the internet search market and abused this dominance to overcharge businesses for advertisements.<br /><br />
 A class action filed at the competition appeal tribunal on Wednesday argues that the US company has taken actions that enable it to charge higher prices for the promotions that appear in search queries than it otherwise could in a fair market.<br /><br />
 It is alleged that Google, which is owned by Alphabet, contracted phone makers to pre-install the Google search app and Chrome browser on Android devices and paid Apple to make it the default search engine on iPhones, with the intention of shutting out competition.<br /><br />
 The claim is filed by a competition law expert, Or Brook, on behalf of thousands of businesses and alleges Google ensured its search engine had better functionality and more features for Google’s own advertising offering than that of its competitors.</p><p>A Google spokesperson said: “This is yet another speculative and opportunistic case and we will argue against it vigorously. Consumers and advertisers use Google because it is helpful, not because there are no alternatives.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2025/apr/16/google-sued-for-5bn-in-uk-over-allegations-of-shutting-out-rivals">Continue reading...</a>

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : DR Congo: Floods - Apr 2025
Published: Fri, 04 Apr 2025 00:00:00 +0000
Summary  :
<div class="tag country">Affected country: Democratic Republic of the Congo</div>
                                      <div class="tag glide">Glide: FL-2025-000045-COD</div>
                                                          <p>Heavy rainfall has been affecting Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, since 4 April, causing flooding and landslides that have resulted in casualties and damage. According to the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC), as of 7 April, 33 people have died and 46 were injured due to the overflow of the Ndjili River, affecting 13 out of 24 municipalities in Kinshasa city area. Media reports further indicate that several roads and houses have been destroyed or damaged, power outages have been recorded, and the water supply has been cut off. (<a href="https://reliefweb.int/node/4144934">ECHO, 8 Apr 2025</a>)</p>
<p>Following floods, the Ndjili river overflow, and landslides that occurred across 13 municipalities (out of 24) of the Kinshasa capital city (western Democratic Republic of the Congo) over the period from 4 to 11 April, the number of casualties has increased, and widespread damage was reported. The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) reports, as of 13 April, 165 fatalities, 28 injured persons, more than 7,000 displaced people (a number of these across four relief sites) and a total of over 60,000 affected people across the Kinshasa capital city area. In addition, the IFRC also reports several destroyed and damaged houses. The UNOSAT was activated on 11 April and the International Charter was activated on 10 April to provide the damage assessment. Over the next 96 hours, more rainfall is still forecast over the already affected Kinshasa area. (<a href="https://reliefweb.int/node/4146232">ECHO, 14 Apr 2025</a>)</p>
<p>Severe flooding triggered by torrential rains in recent weeks has displaced almost 10,000 people in Tanganyika Province, the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). This unfolding emergency reflects the double crisis facing the DRC, where extreme weather shocks such as flooding compound the suffering caused by ongoing conflict and mass displacement. The Rugumba River burst its banks, inundating large areas of Kalemie and Nyunzu territories. Homes, schools and agricultural land have been destroyed, leaving thousands without shelter or livelihoods. Stagnant and contaminated floodwaters are raising concerns over the risk of disease outbreaks, with reported cholera cases in the province already six times higher than during the same period last year. The flooding has hit a community already under severe strain. Since January, Tanganyika has received around 50,000 internally displaced people (IDPs) fleeing violence in South Kivu. Many had been sheltering in local homes, churches, and schools—now damaged or destroyed. The floods also wiped out key crops like cassava, maize, and peanuts, worsening an already serious food insecurity situation in the country. (<a href="https://reliefweb.int/node/4146561">UNHCR, 15 Apr 2025</a>)</p>
