=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : Sudan crisis response
Published: Wed, 04 Oct 2023 12:36:48 +0000
Summary  :
<span>Sudan crisis response</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">How MSF is responding to urgent needs inside Sudan and in neighboring countries.</div>
  </div>
<span><span>Leila Rafei</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2023-10-04T08:36:48-04:00" title="Wednesday, October 4, 2023 - 8:36am">October 4 2023, 8:36am</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="Faces and stories of resilience" height="1333" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/image_base_media/2025/02/MSB218028.jpg" width="2000" />

</div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in Sudan are treating war-wounded patients with catastrophic injuries and providing humanitarian aid and medical care in refugee camps and displacement sites, where people are living in poor conditions and lack adequate health care and basic needs. More than 12 million people have been <a href="https://data.unhcr.org/en/situations/sudansituation">displaced</a> by the current conflict, including over 3 million people who have fled to neighboring countries such as <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/chad" title="Chad">Chad</a>, <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, and <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/south-sudan">South Sudan</a>.</p><p><em>Photo above: Displaced people attend an MSF health promotion session on cholera prevention in Al Tadamon gathering site, Gedaref state. Sudan 2024 © Faiz Abubakr</em></p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--three-statistics-in-columns paragraph--view-mode--default">
          <div class="statistics-wrapper-full">
      <div class="statistics-wrapper content__wrapper  greater-six">
                  
          <div class="statistics-item greater-six">
  <div class="statistics__number">
      194,032
  </div>
	<div class="statistics__description"><p><strong>Emergency room</strong> consultations</p></div>
</div>
                  
          <div class="statistics-item less-seven">
  <div class="statistics__number">
      59,887
  </div>
	<div class="statistics__description"><p><strong>malnutrition</strong> cases treated</p></div>
</div>
                  
          <div class="statistics-item greater-six">
  <div class="statistics__number">
      174,779
  </div>
	<div class="statistics__description"><p><strong>malaria </strong>patients treated</p></div>
</div>
                
      </div>
    </div>
    </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">
	
		
		
		
		
		
	
	<div class="paragraph paragraph--type--accordion paragraph--view-mode--default">
					
<div class="msf-accordion accordion-container content__wrapper">
      <h2 class="msf-accordion__heading">Sudan crisis FAQ</h2>
  
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>What’s happening in Sudan?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> For nearly two years, Sudan has experienced ongoing violence, including intense gunfire, shelling, and airstrikes. </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>For nearly two years, large parts of Sudan have been experiencing ongoing violence, including intense urban warfare, gunfire, shelling, and airstrikes. The health system, already fragile before the conflict started, is struggling to cope with existing and emerging medical needs while facing overwhelming pressure from the destruction and looting of health facilities, acute shortages of utilities and medical supplies, and under-resourced, unpaid, and overworked personnel. As a result, people face significant challenges accessing medical care throughout the country.</p><h4>What to know about the war in Sudan</h4><h5>It’s led to the world’s largest displacement crisis.&nbsp;</h5><p>The war in Sudan has forced more than 12 million people—over 1 in 5 Sudanese—to flee their homes in the nearly two years since it started, including over 3 million who have crossed its borders into neighboring countries like Chad and South Sudan, where MSF is providing assistance for refugees and returnees. Many displaced people are sheltering in crowded camps established in the aftermath of the 2003 Darfur crisis, with no roof over their heads to protect them from the rain and scorching summer heat.</p><h5>Sudan's health system has collapsed.&nbsp;</h5><p>Sudan’s health system was already fragile before this conflict. Today, artillery attacks, the occupation of hospitals by armed forces, power outages, and shortages of medical supplies and personnel have brought Sudan’s health system to the brink of collapse. Millions of Sudanese lack access to essential medical care despite alarming needs.</p><h5>The war in Sudan is a war on people.&nbsp;</h5><p>People in Sudan continue to be subjected to horrific violence as warring parties attack each other with little respect for civilian life. The violence has also taken on an ethnic dimension in Sudan’s Darfur region, which was devastated by another war in the early 2000s. Refugees who have fled from West Darfur to Chad describe an unbearable spiral of violence, with looting, homes burned, beatings, sexual violence, and massacres, particularly targeting the Masalit ethnic minority.</p><p>Civilians, residential areas, infrastructure, health workers, and health facilities must be protected.</p><h5>The humanitarian response remains critically underfunded.&nbsp;</h5><p>It’s also hindered by restricted access to conflict zones. An urgent-scale-up of humanitarian response is needed to meet the needs of people in Sudan. MSF is one of the few international organizations working in parts of Sudan that are most heavily impacted by the violence. The UN and other humanitarian organizations are barely visible on the ground beyond the main entry points in the east (Port Sudan) and west (El Geneina). This is partly due to the mounting violence, lawlessness, and access challenges imposed by both parties to the conflict.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>What are the medical and humanitarian needs MSF is seeing in Sudan?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> With a collapsed health system, the medical needs in Sudan are dire, urgent, and exacerbated by the conflict. </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>With a collapsed health system, the medical needs in Sudan are dire, urgent, and exacerbated by the conflict.</p><h5>Food insecurity and malnutrition</h5><p>Food insecurity and malnutrition have reached catastrophic levels in parts of Sudan, particularly in Zamzam camp, North Darfur, which is the largest displacement site in the country. In 2024, multiple screenings carried out by MSF and Sudanese health authorities in the camp indicated alarming and worsening rates of malnutrition. On August 1, 2024, the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) Famine Review Committee concluded that <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/sudan-after-famine-declaration-catastrophic-malnutrition-zamzam-camp-only-getting-worse" title="Sudan: After famine declaration, catastrophic malnutrition in Zamzam camp is only getting worse">famine conditions</a> were prevalent in the area.</p><h5>Access to health care&nbsp;</h5><p>Sudan’s health system was already fragile before this conflict. Today, artillery attacks, the occupation of hospitals by armed forces, power outages, and shortages of medical supplies and personnel have brought Sudan’s health system to the brink of collapse. Active fighting and lack of transportation hinder patients’ ability to reach the health facilities that are functioning. By the time many arrive at a hospital, they are in critical condition; pregnant women often have to give birth at home.</p><h5>Disease outbreaks&nbsp;</h5><p>Before the current war, Sudan had a high prevalence of non-communicable diseases and faced both seasonal and non-seasonal outbreaks of diseases like <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/measles" title="Measles">measles</a> and <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>. Now, as the ongoing conflict has disrupted essential services such as water supply and the availability of medicine, the health situation has become even more dire.</p><div class="ckeditor-readmore-wrapper"><div class="ckeditor-readmore"><p>As people flee to overcrowded camps, the risk of disease outbreaks has risen, especially among children. The lack of availability and access to vaccinations has left many children unvaccinated, heightening the risk of deadly but vaccine-preventable diseases such as measles.</p><p>In addition, people with chronic diseases such as <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/diabetes" title="Diabetes">diabetes</a>, asthma, and heart disease are facing serious complications due to lack of medicines and lack of access to functional health facilities.</p></div></div><h5>Surgery and emergency care&nbsp;</h5><p>The war has put intense pressure on hospitals with surgery and emergency departments. MSF teams are seeing war-wounded patients with catastrophic injuries caused by explosions, bullets, and stabbings, and are responding to mass casualty incidents. People injured in road traffic accidents and women in need of emergency cesarean sections also face difficulty accessing care.</p><h5>Maternal and pediatric care&nbsp;</h5><p>Pregnant women and children residing in camps, particularly in the western, southern, and eastern regions of the country, are especially vulnerable to health risks due to harsh living conditions and the insufficient humanitarian response. Women often give birth in unsanitary tents or at home, increasing the risk of complications and infections, while access to <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/maternal-health" title="Maternal health">maternal health</a> care remains insufficient.</p><p>At the same time, the need for postnatal and pediatric care is immense. Children under 5 years old, especially newborns and toddlers, have an increased likelihood of contracting diseases and are more vulnerable to complications from malnutrition, <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a>, measles, or acute watery diarrhea.</p><h5>Obstruction of humanitarian access&nbsp;</h5><p>Throughout the war, there has been a systematic obstruction of aid, humanitarian access, and supplies. It has been difficult to get visas for humanitarian staff to enter the country and travel permits to move around Sudan. Permits to cross front lines have repeatedly been denied. Attempts have also been made to prevent aid from entering the country, including from Chad and South Sudan.</p><h5>Mental health&nbsp;</h5><p>The war and violence continue to have serious <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/mental-health" title="Mental health">mental health</a> implications for people fleeing or stuck in the midst of the fighting. People continue to experience extreme trauma as they lose family members and loved ones; witness and experience violence, including <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/sexual-and-gender-based-violence" title="Sexual and gender-based violence">sexual violence</a>; and the deterioration of their own health or the health of loved ones.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>How is MSF responding in Sudan?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> MSF works in 10 out of 18 states in Sudan with a team of more than 1,500 Sudanese staff and over 200 international staff.  </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF works in 10 out of 18 states in Sudan with a team of more than 1,500 Sudanese staff and over 200 international staff. Our teams work in or support 22 hospitals; 42 primary health care facilities and mobile clinic sites; and 15 integrated community case management sites. We also pay incentives to 3,356 Ministry of Health staff.</p><p>MSF’s main medical activities in Sudan include:</p><ul><li><strong>Emergency care and surgery</strong>, including trauma care for the war-wounded and &nbsp;those with non-war related injuries</li><li><strong>Maternal and pediatric health care</strong>, including cesarean sections</li><li><strong>Malnutrition screening and treatment </strong>for acutely malnourished children and pregnant mothers</li><li><strong>Outpatient care and mobile clinics</strong>, including in sites where displaced people and refugees have sought shelter</li><li><strong>Routine- and catch-up vaccination campaigns</strong></li><li><strong>Responses to outbreaks</strong> of diseases including cholera and measles</li><li><strong>Donations</strong> of medicines and medical supplies to health care facilities</li><li><strong>Incentives, training, and logistical support</strong> for Ministry of Health staff</li><li><strong>Water and sanitation activities, </strong>including setting up and restoring and cleaning latrines and water points.</li></ul></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
        <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/png" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/png" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/png" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/png" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/png" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Map of MSF activities in Sudan." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/MSB217911.png?itok=L2rOsg8U" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
              
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>How is MSF responding in neighboring countries?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> MSF is providing assistance for refugees and returnees who have fled to Chad and South Sudan. </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF is providing assistance for refugees and returnees who have fled to Chad and South Sudan.</p><h3>Chad</h3><p>Since the war started, <a href="https://data.unhcr.org/en/situations/sudansituation">more than 700,000</a> refugees and returnees have crossed the border from Sudan to eastern Chad, according to the UN Refugee Agency. MSF teams work in three border regions that have been hosting most new arrivals: Ouaddaï, Wadi Fira, and Sila, supporting refugees, returnees, and host communities.</p><p>In 2024, MSF provided a wide range of medical services in Chad: primary health care, malnutrition screening and treatment, vaccination, and sexual and reproductive health care. Given the struggle to acquire sufficient, quality water—which increases the risk of waterborne diseases—MSF is constantly working to improve access to water and sanitation. Our teams dig boreholes, build and connect water points in camps, provide technical support to other actors, set up latrines, and rehabilitate water pumps in host-communities. MSF is also intervening in response to an increase in cases of hepatitis E, which is currently an epidemic in the east of the country.</p><p>In addition to medical support, MSF provides refugee communities with non-food items such as plastic sheeting, mosquito nets, and soap, which is crucial during the rainy season to prevent additional heath risks.</p><p>Despite these efforts, the humanitarian response in eastern Chad has been struggling due to insufficient funding for humanitarian organizations on the ground, leaving critical gaps in the provision of food, shelter, water, and sanitation.&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
        <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Returnees in a camp in Twic, South Sudan." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2024/04/MSB169939.jpg?itok=0ME2z06t" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Majook-noon camp houses thousands of displaced people, many of whom are South Sudanese returnees fleeing the war in Sudan. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> South Sudan 2023 ©&nbsp;Sean Sutton/Panos pictures
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h3>South Sudan</h3><p>Since the war in Sudan started, more than 1 million people have fled to South Sudan. The border county of Renk, which has seen a surge of approximately 120,000 new arrivals since December 2024, has been significantly impacted. MSF is providing medical services to refugees and returnees and host communities in several regions, including Renk, the Abyei Special Administrative Area, and the capital, Juba.</p><p>In Renk, MSF supports Renk County Hospital, offering pre- and post-operative care for war-related injuries in partnership with the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), which provides surgical care, runs pediatric services, and operates a cholera treatment unit. MSF has set up 17 additional tents to accommodate the influx of patients.</p><p>MSF also conducts outreach activities at the Gossfami, Girbanat, and Atam informal settlements, which host over 60,000 people facing a severe lack of health care services. MSF initially supplied non-food items like blankets and water containers and continues to conduct outpatient consultations, predominantly treating malaria and diarrhea cases. Our teams also run an ambulance service referring patients to Renk Civil Hospital, provide up to 23,000 liters [over 6,000 gallons] of water daily, and are currently setting up sanitation infrastructure, including latrines and water points.</p><p>On October 28, 2024, the South Sudan Ministry of Health declared a cholera outbreak in Renk County, exacerbated by inadequate sanitation and overcrowded living conditions. The disease spread unusually fast to at least seven of the nation's 10 states. MSF has responded in five states, treating cholera patients and administering vaccinations in areas such as Renk, Malakal, Rubkona, Juba, and Gorom refugee camp, where currently over 12,000 Sudanese refugees are living.</p><p>Despite the increasing number of refugees and returnees, significant gaps remain in the humanitarian response. Water supply and sanitation facilities pose urgent concerns; many communities depend on dwindling rainwater sources, which raises the risk of communal conflict. Moreover, food and shelter shortages persist, with many living in inadequate conditions, such as makeshift tents or under trees, while lacking essential needs. MSF is committed to supporting all affected people in South Sudan, including refugees, returnees, and local communities facing dire circumstances.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>How long has MSF worked in Sudan?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> MSF has been present in Sudan since 1979, witnessing historic changes and escalating needs as political and social dynamics shift rapidly. </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF has been present in Sudan since 1979, witnessing historic changes and escalating needs in response to the rapid shifts in the country’s political and social dynamics, which in turn impact health needs.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our intervention began shortly before the Second Sudanese Civil War (1983-2005), which was fought primarily between the north and south of Sudan and was one of Africa's longest civil wars. MSF was actively involved in providing medical care to war-affected communities dealing with massive displacement, famine, and the outbreak of diseases. With the independence of South Sudan in 2011, MSF continued operations in both countries, adapting to the shifting dynamics of conflict and the division of resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>When the war broke out in April 2023, many activities were either stopped or shifted to respond to the emerging needs and emergencies across the country. Some activities continued—in Darfur, for example—thanks to the efforts of our locally hired MSF staff, who continued to work despite the extremely difficult personal and environmental circumstances.&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>What does it mean to be an independent and impartial medical humanitarian organization?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> MSF provides medical care to anyone who needs it, regardless of race, religion, or political affiliation. </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF provides medical care to anyone who needs it, regardless of race, religion, or political affiliation. We are calling on all parties to the conflict to ensure the safety of civilians, medical facilities, and personnel. Hospitals must remain a sanctuary for people seeking care. &nbsp;</p><p>To facilitate our humanitarian and medical work, we speak to all parties to the conflict to request safe, rapid, and unimpeded access to civilians who require medical care and to ensure the safety and security of our staff. This is why our independence and impartiality are essential to our work in all the places we operate across the globe.&nbsp;</p><p><a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/who-we-are" title="Who we are">Learn more about the principles that guide our work &gt;</a></p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
  </div>
			</div>
</div>

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : Trapped and abused: The plight of domestic workers in Lebanon
Published: Wed, 16 Apr 2025 13:00:00 +0000
Summary  :
<span>Trapped and abused: The plight of domestic workers in Lebanon</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">MSF teams in Lebanon are responding to the health needs of migrants abused under the kafala sponsorship system. </div>
  </div>
<span><span>Leila Rafei</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2025-04-16T09:00:00-04:00" title="Wednesday, April 16, 2025 - 9:00am">April 16 2025, 9:00am</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="Trapped and abused: migrant workers’ experiences in Lebanon" height="1333" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB224987.jpg" width="2000" />

</div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>Most patients at MSF's clinic in the northern Beirut suburb of Bourj Hammoud are migrants, drawn to the area for its affordable housing, diverse religious sites, and proximity to public transport stations. Many of the migrants chose to leave their home countries in search of a better life in Lebanon—only to find themselves trapped under the <em>kafala</em> (sponsorship) system, excluded from legal protections afforded to other workers and robbed of their agency. Half are domestic workers, often subjected to mistreatment and abuse in their employers' homes.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/png" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/png" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/png" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/png" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/png" width="550" />
                  <img alt="A domestic worker holds her child in a kitchen in Lebanon." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/MSB224982%28High%29.png?itok=fHxFZSY4" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            "No one is giving me any work because I can’t take my son with me," said Tigist*, a domestic worker from Ethiopia. "This world doesn’t see us as human.” <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Lebanon 2025 © Myriam Boulos/Magnum
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Living under the kafala system</h2><p>Migrant workers come to Lebanon through the kafala<em> </em>system, which has been described by human rights activists and organizations as amounting to “<a href="https://www.hrw.org/news/2022/01/04/lebanons-abusive-kafala-sponsorship-system">modern-day slavery</a>.” Under this system, many migrants are overworked and underpaid—or not paid at all—with no breaks or days off. Those who are domestic workers often face verbal and physical abuse in their employers' homes, with serious implications for their health and well-being. These workers are almost exclusively women.</p><p>Under the kafala system, sponsors often take migrants' legal documents along with their agency as humans. Migrants can be denied their right to communicate with anybody outside of the household, including their family. Leaving the house is not always possible, and they can only return to their home country if their sponsor consents.&nbsp;</p><div class="background-tan text-align-center">"I’m scared to get out of the house. Other than for work, I don’t go anywhere. If I face a problem, this is not my country and my family can’t help me."&nbsp;<br /><em><strong>—&nbsp;Beatrice</strong></em></div><p><a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/focus/global-access-to-medicine" title="Access to medicine and medical care">Access to health care</a> is severely limited for migrants bound by the kafala system, which allows employers to deny workers their right to health care. Even those operating outside the system face difficulty accessing care, as they are frequently turned away from hospitals and primary health care centers for not having legal documents, or simply because they’re not Lebanese. Some avoid seeking health services altogether for fear of being turned away or deported, or because they don't have the money to pay for care. This can worsen and complicate medical conditions.</p><p>While some workers are able to find support within migrant communities, many are left homeless, without legal documents, and in need of urgent assistance. Those seeking to return home might not have the resources to arrange their paperwork or buy a plane ticket. Despite the hardships they face, some choose to stay in Lebanon because they need to feed their families, or simply because they have nowhere to go.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Migrant women hold hands at MSF's clinic in Bourj Hammoud, Beirut, Lebanon." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB224988.jpg?itok=mTfYT3Y1" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Migrants often help each other out when they can due to a strong sense of solidarity. Ahmet* and Nasima*, pictured here, provide support to one another and live together in Mar Elias. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Lebanon 2025 © Myriam Boulos/Magnum
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>The dehumanization of domestic workers</h2><p>When migrant workers share their stories with MSF staff, themes of racism and discrimination are prevalent. In Lebanon, the term <em>El-Srilankiyye</em> (Arabic for “The Sri Lankan”) has historically been used to refer to migrant domestic workers—regardless of their actual nationality—reflecting the origin of most workers arriving in the early 2000s. As migration patterns shifted, the term <em>El-Ethiopiyye</em> (“The Ethiopian”) became more common.</p><div class="background-tan text-align-center">"This world doesn’t see us as human."&nbsp;<br /><em><strong>—&nbsp;Tigist*</strong></em></div><p>These labels not only reduce individuals to their nationality but also reinforce stereotypes that people from these backgrounds are inherently domestic workers. More concerning is the implication that such work is degrading, further marginalizing people who take on these essential roles. Their mistreatment and exploitation have been normalized to the point that even the most shocking stories have become recurrent.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="A domestic worker stands beside a cabinet in her apartment in Beirut, Lebanon." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB224992.jpg?itok=M09d2djR" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            "I feel like I’m in prison—I don’t know anything about the outside world," said Ahmet*, who lives with her 2-year-old son and seven other migrants in a small rooftop apartment in Mar Elias, Beirut. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Lebanon 2025 © Myriam Boulos/Magnum
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Migrants’ medical needs go unmet and unheard</h2><p>At the MSF clinic in Bourj Hammoud, our teams are responding to migrants’ medical needs through primary health care consultations, sexual and reproductive health services, and mental health services, including psychiatric consultations. We also have been covering the cost of referrals for hospitalization in life-threatening cases, including for psychiatric emergencies.</p><div class="background-tan text-align-center">"[My employer] did not believe I was experiencing sexual harassment. She did not even believe me when I told I her I was sick."&nbsp;<br /><em><strong>— Martha*</strong></em></div><p>“In 2024, psychiatric consultations in the Bourj Hammoud clinic doubled compared to the previous year,” said Elsa Saikali, MSF mental health supervisor. “This highlights the huge mental health needs among migrant communities. Migrant workers are often dehumanized, subjected to racism and discrimination, and exposed to physical and sexual abuse. All this has deep repercussions on their psychological well-being.”</p><p>One of the challenges migrants face in Lebanon is the language barrier, which further limits their ability to access health care as they are obliged to sign documents and communicate in Arabic to survive. But at MSF’s clinic, things are done differently.</p><div class="background-tan text-align-center">“For the 15 days I spent in that house, I would wait until everyone was asleep to sneak some bread or an orange. I was living on scraps.”&nbsp;<br /><em><strong>—&nbsp;Makdes*</strong></em></div><p>“We’re one of the rare organizations in Lebanon offering translation for migrants during mental health sessions,” said Saikali. “What makes our clinic special is the presence of community health educators for patients. They are MSF staff from the migrant communities who facilitate patient bonding, build trust, and make sure the patient is properly informed about their health status.”</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Beatrice, a domestic worker, sits in the home she shares with three other migrant women in a southern suburb of Beirut, Lebanon." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB224997.jpg?itok=N2piKvDC" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Beatrice* was locked inside her employer's home when an Israeli airstrike hit close by. She jumped off the balcony in an attempt to escape, breaking both of her ankles. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Lebanon 2025 © Myriam Boulos/Magnum
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>But the needs of migrant communities in Lebanon span beyond medical care, and it's difficult for patients to take care of their mental health if they’re experiencing homelessness or unable to feed themselves. This is where the role of our social workers comes in.</p><p>“My job is to refer patients to services that are beyond MSF’s ability to respond to,” said Hanan Hamadi, MSF social worker at the Bourj Hammoud clinic. “The patients who come to me have the most basic needs, such as shelter, food items, and cash assistance. I refer them to other organizations offering these services.”</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="MSF staff meet with a patient who is a migrant worker during a consultation at MSF's clinic in Bourj Hammoud, a Beirut suburb." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB224962.jpg?itok=yWU0tyen" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Dr. Fatima Assed, a general practitioner at MSF's clinic in Bourj Hammoud, conducts a consultation with Kumari, a Sri Lankan migrant, with the help of translator Rainey. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Lebanon 2025 © Myriam Boulos/Magnum
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>War adds another challenge for migrants in Lebanon&nbsp;</h2><p>The recent <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/whats-happening-lebanon" title="What's happening in Lebanon?">Israeli bombardment of Lebanon</a> exacerbated many migrants' socio-economic challenges. Many have disclosed to MSF teams that they were abandoned in war-affected areas, left on the streets or locked inside the homes of employers who fled for safety.</p><p>During the two-month war, migrant community leaders helped MSF teams reach those most in need of assistance in overcrowded shelters and apartments, where we <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/msf-scales-response-lebanon-bombings-continue" title="MSF scales up response in Lebanon as bombings continue">donated essential relief items and delivered medical care</a> through a mobile clinic.</p><div class="background-tan text-align-center">"During the war, she would make me watch news of airstrikes on television and threaten to dump me in the targeted areas ... She would tell me, ‘Look how they discarded their migrant worker, I will do the same to you.'"<em>&nbsp;</em><br /><em><strong>— Makdes*</strong></em></div><p>Other programs run by local and international organizations helping migrants have dwindled over the years—some only operating for limited periods of time, leaving gaps in migrants' resources once closed.</p><p>“It is getting increasingly difficult to refer our patients to other organizations offering assistance to migrants in Lebanon,” said Hamadi. “This is due to the scarce funding allocated to programs supporting migrants and the defunding or closure of others. This is not a recent issue, as it’s been happening for a while.”</p><p>One of the biggest challenges MSF teams in Lebanon are facing is referring patients for hospitalization, including for psychiatric emergencies. Organizations with scarce funding might have to stop covering hospitalization for migrants. If these organizations scale down this support, MSF alone would not be able to cover the gap alone, and many people’s needs will go unmet.</p><p><em>*Names have been changed</em></p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>In their own words</h2><h3><em>Stories of domestic workers in Lebanon</em></h3></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">


  
  
  
<div class="content__wrapper">
  <div class="standout-media-container bg--white standout-media-block--left">
    <div class="standout-media-info">
      
      <h2 class="heading-2 hz-listing__title">Beatrice</h2>

              
  <div class="field field--name-field-description field--type-text-long field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>When Beatrice shared her story with MSF, the sound of Israeli forces' reconnaissance drones was triggering memories of the day she broke both ankles trying to flee her employer's home.&nbsp;</p><p>It was October 6, 2024, and <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/whats-happening-lebanon" title="What's happening in Lebanon?">Lebanon was under intense Israeli bombardment</a>. Beatrice was cleaning the house when she saw a bomb hit a nearby building. She instinctively tried to flee, but her employer had locked her inside—so she jumped from the balcony, leaving her in need of urgent care.</p><p>"My friends called an organization to see if they can support me with the treatment, Beatrice said. "That organization along with MSF covered my surgery, medication, and the two-month recovery period.”</p></div>
  </div>
      
              <div class="standout-media-content">
          <div class="mega-accordion__expanded-content">
            
  <div class="field field--name-field-content-expanded-section field--type-text-long field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>Beatrice came to Lebanon in 2022, leaving her children with her mother back home in <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/sierra-leone" title="Sierra Leone">Sierra Leone</a> so she could earn a living. Yet like many other migrants she has been overworked and underpaid, barely managing to cover food and rent. As the sole provider for her family, the $50 left of her paycheck is hardly enough for them to survive.</p><p>She spent her first three months in Lebanon living with her employer's family, cleaning while taking care of their three children. “When one of the kids was acting up and I had to say no to him, she threatened to kill me," Beatrice said. "She used to say, ‘African kids are not like Lebanese kids,’ but aren’t we all people, just with different skin colors?”</p><p>Beatrice dreams of making enough money to build an orphanage in Sierra Leone, helping children get the shelter and education they deserve. But since her injury last October, she hasn't been able to work. Debts are piling up as she pays rent for a house she shares with three other migrant women. She fears going outside. "If face a problem, this is not my country and my family can’t help me.”</p></div>
  </div>
          </div>
          <div class="expandable__button">
          <a class="btn--expand btn--toggle-plus" href="">View more</a>
          </div>
        </div>
          </div>
    <div class="standout-media-image">
          
                  <source height="519" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/png" width="553" />
              <source height="519" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/png" width="553" />
              <source height="450" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/png" width="480" />
              <source height="450" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/png" width="480" />
              <source height="315" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/png" width="335" />
                  <img alt="A domestic worker in Lebanon." height="519" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/standout_mbt_553_519/public/MSB224998_Beatrice.png?itok=lotvpw1Y" width="553" />

  

    </div>
  </div>
</div>

</div>
              <div class="field__item">


  
  
  
<div class="content__wrapper">
  <div class="standout-media-container bg--white standout-media-block--right">
    <div class="standout-media-info">
      
      <h2 class="heading-2 hz-listing__title">Makdes</h2>

              
  <div class="field field--name-field-description field--type-text-long field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>Makdes* and her family were saving up money to start a project in Ethiopia. She knew people working in Lebanon, so she decided to take the same journey in hopes to earn enough money to support her family.</p><p>The first family she lived with in Lebanon made her work under impossible conditions. “In my culture, you have to be offered food to eat,” said Makdes. “But they never cared or even asked if I’ve eaten.” Before and after each family meal, Makdes had to clean on an empty stomach. “I would wait until everyone was asleep to sneak some bread or an orange. I was living on scraps.”</p><p>In her last three days working in that home, she was bedridden with exhaustion. Her employer locked her inside her room, accusing her of simply not wanting to work. Later, she was taken back to the agency that had brought her to Lebanon. The agency sent her to another family's home, where the situation was even more difficult—slapped and yelled at by an employer who scared her for fun.</p></div>
  </div>
      
              <div class="standout-media-content">
          <div class="mega-accordion__expanded-content">
            
  <div class="field field--name-field-content-expanded-section field--type-text-long field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>“During the war, she would make me watch airstrikes on television and threaten to dump me in the targeted areas. She constantly swore at me and humiliated me.”</p><p>That employer also refused to allow her to call home, calling her “just a maid” who “shouldn’t be spoiled.” “She would tell me, ‘Look how they discarded their migrant worker, I will do the same to you,’” recounted Makdes.&nbsp;</p><p>“In Ethiopia, I was never scared of anything," she added. "After my time in Lebanon, I jump at the simplest incident. Now, when I get scared or nervous, my heart starts beating so fast until I lose consciousness.”</p><p>After all she's endured, Mades just wants to go home. She sought the help of her embassy and is now awaiting repatriation.</p></div>
  </div>
          </div>
          <div class="expandable__button">
          <a class="btn--expand btn--toggle-plus" href="">View more</a>
          </div>
        </div>
          </div>
    <div class="standout-media-image">
          
                  <source height="519" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/png" width="553" />
              <source height="519" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/png" width="553" />
              <source height="450" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/png" width="480" />
              <source height="450" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/png" width="480" />
              <source height="315" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/png" width="335" />
                  <img alt="A domestic worker with her face covered by a hat in Lebanon." height="519" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/standout_mbt_553_519/public/MSB224985_Makdes.png?itok=ktrI9g-D" width="553" />

  

    </div>
  </div>
</div>

</div>
              <div class="field__item">


  
  
  
<div class="content__wrapper">
  <div class="standout-media-container bg--white standout-media-block--left">
    <div class="standout-media-info">
      
      <h2 class="heading-2 hz-listing__title">Martha</h2>

              
  <div class="field field--name-field-description field--type-text-long field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>Originally from the <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/ethiopia-msf-staff-attacked-after-witnessing-killings-soldiers-tigray" title="Ethiopia: MSF staff attacked after witnessing killings by soldiers in Tigray">Tigray</a> region in Ethiopia, Martha* moved to the capital, Addis Ababa, to provide for her family, working in a hotel during the day and studying management at night.&nbsp;</p><p>One day she lost her job, so she decided to go to Lebanon. Soon after she arrived, her employer sent her to live with their elderly parents and their caregiver. For the three months she lived in that house, the caregiver <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/sexual-and-gender-based-violence" title="Sexual and gender-based violence">sexually harassed her</a>, but no one believed her. Even after she recorded a video of the harassment, the perpetrator was not held accountable and her experience was dismissed. She was then sent to live in her employer’s house along with other migrant workers.</p><p>“My employer would yell at me if I asked her for anything or asked her a question,” said Martha. “She mistreated me, often delaying paying me my salary. She did not believe I was experiencing sexual harassment. She did not even believe me when I told I her I was sick.”</p></div>
  </div>
      
              <div class="standout-media-content">
          <div class="mega-accordion__expanded-content">
            
  <div class="field field--name-field-content-expanded-section field--type-text-long field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>Martha fell ill with severe kidney pain, and once again her pain was dismissed. At first, her employer refused to take her to a doctor. When a mediator tried to convince the employer that Martha was indeed sick, her response was, “She’s under my name [legally], she’s mine, I will take her wherever I want.” By the time Martha was finally taken to a doctor, she was no longer able to walk. She was supposed to go back to the doctor’s clinic for a follow-up, but the employer denied her that right and she became sick again.&nbsp;</p><p>“The house was always guarded; I could not run away,” Martha said. “I told my employer I needed to renew my passport, so she took me to the embassy and I never went back. I’ve been in this shelter for a month now. I want to go back home.”</p><p>Despite the hardships she faced, Martha does not hold a grudge. “I have suffered, yes, but I learned from my experiences. I have not one dime on me, but at least I saved my family from going hungry. No matter what happens, I will always have love in my heart, which is what I like the most about myself.”</p></div>
  </div>
          </div>
          <div class="expandable__button">
          <a class="btn--expand btn--toggle-plus" href="">View more</a>
          </div>
        </div>

              <div class="field__item">


  
  
  
<div class="content__wrapper">
  <div class="standout-media-container bg--white standout-media-block--right">
    <div class="standout-media-info">
      
      <h2 class="heading-2 hz-listing__title">Ahmet</h2>

              
  <div class="field field--name-field-description field--type-text-long field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>Ahmet* arrived in Lebanon from <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> eight years ago, with travel papers arranged by an agency back home. Two people picked her up from the airport in Beirut, claiming that they’d apply for residency for her, but ended up running away with all her money.</p><p>That’s when the reality hit her: Without a visa to live or work in Lebanon, she would need a sponsor who she'd probably have to live with, and unable to choose the type of work that suited her. The promise of a better life in Lebanon quickly vanished.</p><p>Ahmet started taking odd jobs where she could find them, mainly ironing and dishwashing. Her husband later joined her in Lebanon and found a job at a hotel. Around a year ago, however, he was arrested for not having a valid work permit. He spent four months in jail before being deported to Bangladesh.</p></div>
  </div>
      
              <div class="standout-media-content">
          <div class="mega-accordion__expanded-content">
            
  <div class="field field--name-field-content-expanded-section field--type-text-long field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>Ahmet has chronic heart problems that worsened after delivering her now 2-year-old son. Her medications are expensive, unavailable at health centers, and difficult to buy from the pharmacy—so sometimes her husband sends them from Bangladesh.</p><p>“I am currently burning through our savings and accepting help from others to stay alive,” Ahmet said. “I need [to cover] health care expenses, rent, bills, milk, and diapers for my baby. This past year—living without my husband and through a war—has been very tough for me.”</p><p>"My mind is constantly turning," she added. "I worry about everything. If my heart gives out, what will happen to my son?”</p></div>
  </div>
          </div>
          <div class="expandable__button">
          <a class="btn--expand btn--toggle-plus" href="">View more</a>
          </div>
        </div>
          </div>

              <source height="450" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/png" width="480" />

    </div>

              <div class="field__item">


  
  
  
<div class="content__wrapper">
  <div class="standout-media-container bg--white standout-media-block--left">
    <div class="standout-media-info">
      
      <h2 class="heading-2 hz-listing__title">Tigist</h2>

              
  <div class="field field--name-field-description field--type-text-long field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>When Tigist* was just 14 years old, she migrated from Ethiopia hoping to support her family. She spent five years working in a restaurant in Sudan before migrating to Lebanon so she could make more money.&nbsp;</p><p>At 19, she spent four months living in a family's home where she had to work many hours through hunger and thirst. Only then would she be given a small amount of food and water—but forced to eat quickly so she could get back to work.</p><p>Years years later, she fell in love with a Sudanese man and married him. She had hoped for a companion and support system, but instead, her husband abused her, beating and mistreating her on a regular basis before finally kicking her and their son out of the house. The two became homeless.</p></div>
  </div>
      
              <div class="standout-media-content">
          <div class="mega-accordion__expanded-content">
            
  <div class="field field--name-field-content-expanded-section field--type-text-long field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>“I haven’t been able to support myself and my son,” said Tigist. “No one is giving me any work because I can’t take my son with me. I feel scared and abandoned, as if having a baby is a fault. Everyone gave up on me after I delivered my child. This world doesn’t see us [migrant workers] as human.”</p><p>Tigist hopes her son will see better days in the future, one in which his needs are met and she doesn’t feel helpless. She’s spent the past six months in the embassy shelter, wanting to go home.</p><p>“I want to open my own restaurant in Ethiopia if I manage to have enough money,” she said. “I haven’t seen my father in a really long time. I really miss him. I hope to provide the best life for my son. I work hard and never give up or give in to hardships.”</p></div>
  </div>

Title    : Sudan’s largest displacement camp is under attack
Published: Tue, 15 Apr 2025 14:40:00 +0000
Summary  :
<span>Sudan’s largest displacement camp is under attack</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">The half-million residents of Zamzam camp have been starved, shelled, and deprived of lifesaving assistance.</div>
  </div>
<span><span>Leila Rafei</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2025-04-15T10:40:00-04:00" title="Tuesday, April 15, 2025 - 10:40am">April 15 2025, 10:40am</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="Newly displaced families arrive in Tawila on April 13 following new attacks in Zamzam camp, Sudan." height="1080" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/MSB228009%28High%29.png" width="1920" />

</div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p><strong>Marion Ramstein, MSF emergency field coordinator in North Darfur, described the situation in Zamzam:</strong></p><p>“There are reports of people fleeing and many casualties, although we can’t verify how many at the moment.</p><p>“Back in February, we were <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/escalation-fighting-forces-msf-halt-operations-sudans-zamzam-camp" title="Escalation in fighting forces MSF to halt operations in Sudan’s Zamzam camp">forced to suspend all MSF activities in the camp</a> because of escalating security issues. Repeated shelling, shooting at our ambulances, and a tightened siege that prevented us from resupplying facilities and sending staff made it impossible for MSF to continue working in Zamzam despite the immense needs.</p><p>“The communication network with Zamzam has been shut down. We don’t have news of many of the people who worked with us and decided to remain with their relatives in the camp after the suspension of our field hospital. We’re horrified by what they have to endure, and extremely worried about them and the hundreds of thousands of people already on the brink of survival in the area. We were appalled to learn that nine staff from Relief International were killed. It was the only international humanitarian organization still operating in Zamzam.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--social-media-post-embed paragraph--view-mode--default" id="social-66522">
    
          <article>
  
      

<div class="lozad-twitter"></div>


  </article>

      </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>"On April 12 and 13, our team in Tawila saw more than 10,000 people fleeing from Zamzam and nearby areas. They arrived in an advanced state of dehydration, exhaustion, and stress. They have nothing but the clothes they’re wearing, nothing to eat, nothing to drink. They sleep on the ground under the trees. Several people told us about family members left behind—lost during the escape, injured, or killed.”</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="mini-cta">
  <h3 class="heading-3 mini-cta__heading">No end in sight: Sudan’s two years of war</h3>

  
<a class="link-item link-bold link-cta mini-cta__link" href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/no-end-sight-sudans-two-years-war">Read more</a>
</div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF set up a health post at the entrance of Tawila city to receive the new arrivals and provide water and medical care. Our teams quickly distributed what we had on hand, such as blankets, mosquito nets, and buckets; and we are referring the most critical cases to the local hospital MSF has been supporting since last October. MSF teams are also screening newly arrived children for malnutrition so they can immediately receive therapeutic food and be enrolled in our nutritional program for adequate care.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/png" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/png" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/png" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/png" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/png" width="550" />
                  <img alt="New families arrive in Tawila following new attacks in Zamzam camp, Sudan." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/MSB227938%28High%29.png?itok=fvl-2crp" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            The situation around El Fasher, including camps like Zamzam, has deteriorated significantly since May 2024, with heavy fighting and siege becoming daily threats. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Sudan 2025 © Marion Ramstein/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>Since May 2024, <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/sudan-supply-blockade-forces-msf-stop-care-5000-malnourished-children-north-darfur" title="Sudan: Supply blockade forces MSF to stop care for 5,000 malnourished children in North Darfur ">sieges</a> and heavy fighting became everyday threats for people living in El Fasher, capital of North Darfur, along with nearby displacement sites like Zamzam camp. Violence and starvation have only escalated since then, as well as a spiraling <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a> crisis <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/children-are-dying-malnutrition-catastrophic-rate-north-darfur-camp" title="Children are dying from malnutrition at a catastrophic rate in North Darfur camp">documented by several MSF reports</a>. The IPC Famine review committee <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/sudan-after-famine-declaration-catastrophic-malnutrition-zamzam-camp-only-getting-worse" title="Sudan: After famine declaration, catastrophic malnutrition in Zamzam camp is only getting worse">declared a famine in Zamzam camp</a> last August, but the massive humanitarian response required never materialized.&nbsp;</p><p>As the already-desperate situation reaches a new critical threshold, we urge the warring parties in Sudan and all stakeholders with influence to spare civilians, lift the siege, and remove all obstacles depriving people in North Darfur from lifesaving humanitarian aid.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="content__wrapper">
  <div class="email-sign-up email--bg-light">
    <h2 class="heading-2 email__heading">We speak out. Get updates.</h2>

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : South Sudan: No health facility left in Ulang after armed looting
Published: Tue, 15 Apr 2025 13:33:17 +0000
Summary  :
<span>South Sudan: No health facility left in Ulang after armed looting</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">All medical services at MSF's hospital—the only functioning health facility in the area—have been suspended following the attack.</div>
  </div>
<span><span>Kate Rankin</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2025-04-15T09:33:17-04:00" title="Tuesday, April 15, 2025 - 9:33am">April 15 2025, 9:33am</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="MSF teams navigate swamps and grasses to reach displaced communities" height="1500" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB145830.jpg" width="2000" />

</div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>“We are outraged by the attack on our hospital and the threats against our medical staff in Ulang,” said Zakariya Mwatia, MSF head of mission in South Sudan. “This facility has been a lifeline for the community at a time of <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/violence-and-cholera-ravage-both-sides-south-sudan-ethiopia-border" title="Violence and cholera ravage both sides of South Sudan-Ethiopia border">escalating violence and an active cholera outbreak</a>. Such attacks on hospitals and health care workers are completely unacceptable. We are gravely concerned about the devastating impact the closure of medical services will have on already-vulnerable communities, who now face even greater barriers to accessing lifesaving care.”</p><h2>Fear is driving patients away from care</h2><p>As violence drew closer to Ulang on the night of April 13, patients began fleeing the hospital in fear—despite needing medical care. At the time, the hospital had more than 100 patients receiving critical treatment, including trauma care, <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/maternal-health" title="Maternal health">maternity</a> services, and <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/focus/child-health-initiatives" title="Children’s health">pediatric</a> care. While some patients remained in the facility as long as they could, they were ultimately forced to flee when armed men entered the facility and began looting it room by room.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--blockquote paragraph--view-mode--default quote-icon">
                  	
<div class="blockquote-container blockquote-container--white">
  <div class="blockquote__wrapper">
    <blockquote><p></p><p>This unacceptable act of violence shows a complete disregard for humanitarian principles and international humanitarian law, and it has directly affected our ability to provide care at a time when it is most urgently needed.</p><figcaption>Zakariya Mwatia, MSF head of mission in South Sudan</figcaption></blockquote>
  </div>
</div>
            </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>No MSF staff have been reported injured. However we remain extremely concerned for the safety of our teams and patients.</p><p>“The safety of our staff and patients is our foremost priority,” Mwatia added. “We are taking all necessary measures to evacuate our teams as we fear further escalation of violence. This unacceptable act of violence shows a complete disregard for humanitarian principles and international humanitarian law, and it has directly affected our ability to provide care at a time when it is most urgently needed.”</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Deteriorating security affects health care access</h2><p>The attack on the MSF hospital in Ulang is part of a broader pattern of insecurity affecting health care in the area. In January 2025, two clearly marked MSF boats carrying six staff were attacked by armed men while returning to Ulang after delivering medical supplies to Nasir County Hospital. That incident forced MSF to suspend all outreach activities in the region.</p><p>In Ulang, MSF has been operating a secondary health care hospital alongside a network of decentralized primary health care services since 2018. In 2024 alone, MSF teams provided over 10,000 outpatient consultations, admitted 3,284 patients for inpatient care, and assisted with 650 maternal deliveries. Over the years, the 60-bed hospital has served as a critical facility for communities affected by violence, disease outbreaks, and limited access to health care.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="MSF health promotion teams visit the community in Ulang to raise awareness about cholera and other health issues in Ulang, South Sudan." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB226056.jpg?itok=3-qCcrwA" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            An MSF health promotion team visits community members in Ulang to raise awareness about cholera and other health issues. An ongoing cholera outbreak is spreading in the north and east of the country, spilling into Ethiopia. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> South Sudan 2025 ©&nbsp;MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Cholera outbreak heightens urgent needs</h2><p>The suspension of services at the hospital is a major blow to <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/focus/global-access-to-medicine" title="Access to medicine and medical care">health care access</a> in the area, which has been left without a single functioning health facility. This disruption also resulted in the suspension of critical support that MSF has been providing to several primary health care centers across the region, halting vital efforts to treat <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a> patients and control an <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/south-sudan-racing-stop-cholera-outbreak" title="South Sudan: Racing to stop a cholera outbreak">ongoing outbreak</a>. Further, more than 800 patients living with <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/hivaids" title="HIV/AIDS">HIV</a>, <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/tuberculosis" title="Tuberculosis">tuberculosis</a> (TB), and other chronic diseases have lost access to their treatment, putting their lives at significant risk.</p><p>MSF continues to support health services in other parts of Upper Nile state, including Renk and Malakal counties. We urgently call on all parties to the conflict to respect and protect health facilities, patients, civilians, and medical staff, in accordance with international humanitarian law.</p><p>“MSF remains committed to providing impartial, lifesaving care wherever it is needed, but the safety of patients and health workers must be guaranteed,” Mwatia emphasized.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="content__wrapper">
