=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : No end in sight: Sudan’s two years of war
Published: Mon, 14 Apr 2025 13:57:26 +0000
Summary  :
<span>No end in sight: Sudan’s two years of war</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">After shocking attack on Sudan's largest displacement camp, MSF repeats call on warring parties to protect civilians</div>
  </div>
<span><span>Leila Rafei</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2025-04-14T09:57:26-04:00" title="Monday, April 14, 2025 - 9:57am">April 14 2025, 9:57am</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="MSF emergency intervention in Tawila" height="1500" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB220146.jpg" width="2000" />

</div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) reiterates our call on the warring parties and their allies to ensure that civilians, humanitarian personnel, and medical teams are protected and that all restrictions impeding the movement of humanitarian supplies and staff are lifted, especially as the rainy season fast approaches.</p><p>“The warring parties are not only failing to protect civilians—they are actively compounding their suffering,” said Claire San Filippo, MSF emergency coordinator. “Wherever you look in Sudan, you will find needs—overwhelming, urgent, and unmet. Millions are receiving almost no humanitarian assistance, medical facilities and staff remain under attack, and the global humanitarian system is failing to deliver even a fraction of what’s required.”</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--blockquote paragraph--view-mode--default quote-icon">
                  	
<div class="blockquote-container blockquote-container--white">
  <div class="blockquote__wrapper">
    <blockquote><p></p><p>Wherever you look in Sudan, you will find needs—overwhelming, urgent, and unmet.&nbsp;</p><figcaption>Claire San Filippo, MSF emergency coordinator</figcaption></blockquote>
  </div>
</div>
            </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>As front lines have shifted over the course of the war, especially in Khartoum and Darfur, civilians have feared retaliatory attacks from both warring parties. For the past two years, both RSF and SAF have repeatedly and indiscriminately bombed densely populated areas. The RSF and allied militias have unleashed a campaign of brutality, including systematic <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/sexual-and-gender-based-violence" title="Sexual and gender-based violence">sexual violence</a>, abductions, mass killings, looting of aid, erasure of civilian neighborhoods, and occupation of medical facilities. Both sides have laid siege to towns, destroyed vital infrastructure, and blocked humanitarian aid.&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Newly displaced families arrive in Tawila on April 13 following new attacks in Zamzam camp, Sudan." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB228009.jpg?itok=Y8vGWVAG" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Newly displaced families arrive in Tawila on April 13 following new attacks in Zamzam camp. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Sudan 2025 © Marion Ramstein/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>On April 11, RSF and allied armed groups launched a <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/sudans-largest-displacement-camp-under-attack" title="Sudan’s largest displacement camp is under attack">large-scale ground offensive</a> on the Zamzam camp for displaced people, where escalating security issues <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/escalation-fighting-forces-msf-halt-operations-sudans-zamzam-camp" title="Escalation in fighting forces MSF to halt operations in Sudan’s Zamzam camp">forced MSF to suspend activities in February</a>. There were reports of massive displacement and casualties, including nine staff members from Relief International—the only international humanitarian organization still working in Zamzam—who were killed during this shocking new attack.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="mini-cta">
  <h3 class="heading-3 mini-cta__heading">Sudan’s largest displacement camp is under attack</h3>

  
<a class="link-item link-bold link-cta mini-cta__link" href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/sudans-largest-displacement-camp-under-attack">Read more</a>
</div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF set up a health post in Tawila city to receive people displaced from the camp and provide water and medical care, in addition to other services. "We don't have news of many of the people who worked with us and decided to remain with their relatives in the camp after the suspension of our field hospital," said Marion Ramstein, MSF emergency field coordinator in North Darfur. "We're horrified by what they have to endure, and extremely worried about them and the hundreds of thousands of people already on the brink of survival in the area."</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="MSF doctor measures the mid-upper arm circumference of a child in Sudan. " height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/02/MSB220114.jpg?itok=gsSyrWww" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            A health worker screens a child for malnutrition in Tawila, North Darfur.  <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Sudan 2024 © MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Hunger and famine take hold</h2><p>Widespread starvation is taking hold in areas across Sudan, according to the UN: Sudan is currently the only place in the world where famine has been officially declared in multiple locations. <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/sudan-after-famine-declaration-catastrophic-malnutrition-zamzam-camp-only-getting-worse" title="Sudan: After famine declaration, catastrophic malnutrition in Zamzam camp is only getting worse">Famine was first declared</a> in Zamzam camp for internally displaced people in August 2024, and has since spread to 10 more areas. Seventeen additional regions are now on the brink. Without immediate intervention, hundreds of thousands of lives are at risk.</p><p>In March, MSF supported multi-antigen catch up <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/vaccination" title="Vaccination">vaccination</a> campaigns for children under 2 years old in South Darfur. The over 17,000 children who received vaccinations in 11 of the 14 localities were also screened for malnutrition, with 7 percent of those screened found to be suffering from severe acute malnutrition and with 30 percent with global acute malnutrition. In December 2024, during a therapeutic food distribution in Tawila locality, North Darfur, MSF teams screened over 9,500 children under 5 years old. They found a staggering 35.5 percent global acute malnutrition rate, with 7 percent of the children suffering from severe acute malnutrition.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="MSF staff hold a meeting in the Atam clinic in South Sudan. " height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB220248.jpg?itok=XSWlYJGL" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            MSF staff hold a meeting at the mobile clinic in Atam, South Sudan, which has received thousands of Sudanese refugees.  <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> South Sudan 2025 © Paula Casado Aguirregabiria/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Simultaneous emergencies compound crises</h2><p>Sudan is facing multiple, overlapping health emergencies at the same time. MSF teams have treated over 12,000 patients—including women and children—for trauma injuries directly resulting from violent attacks. During the first week of February 2025, MSF teams in three areas of Sudan—Khartoum, North Darfur, and South Darfur states—treated mass influxes of war-wounded patients. Sudan is also experiencing one of the worst <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/maternal-health" title="Maternal health">maternal</a> and <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/focus/child-health-initiatives" title="Children’s health">child health</a> crises we are seeing anywhere in the world. In October 2024, in two MSF-supported facilities in Nyala, capital of South Darfur, 26 percent of pregnant and breastfeeding women seeking care were acutely malnourished.&nbsp;</p><p>“Outbreaks of <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/measles" title="Measles">measles</a>, <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>, and diphtheria are spreading, driven by poor living conditions and disrupted vaccination campaigns,” said Marta Cazorla, MSF emergency coordinator. “<a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/mental-health" title="Mental health">Mental health</a> support and care for survivors of sexual violence remain painfully limited. These compounding crises reflect not just the brutality of the conflict, but the dire consequences of the crumbling public health care system and a failing humanitarian response.”&nbsp;</p><p>Since April 2023, more than 1.7 million people have sought medical consultations at hospitals, health facilities and mobile clinics MSF supports or is working in, and more than 320,000 people were admitted to our emergency wards.</p><p>About 13 million people have been displaced by the conflict, according to the UN—many of them displaced multiple times. Of these, 8.9 million remain displaced inside Sudan, while 3.9 million have crossed into neighboring countries. Many live in overcrowded camps or makeshift shelters, without access to food, water, health care, or a sense of the future. People depend entirely on humanitarian organizations—but organizations are not responding everywhere.&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="MSF doctors examine Sameera, who developed an arm infection from a poorly administered injection following a home delivery in Darfur, Sudan." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/03/MSB225077.jpg?itok=I8A2gSA9" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            MSF doctors examine Sameera, who developed an arm infection from a poorly administered injection following a home delivery. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Sudan 2025 ©&nbsp;Belen Filgueira/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Health facilities destroyed&nbsp;</h2><p>According to the World Health Organization (WHO), more than 70 percent of health facilities in conflict-affected areas are barely operational or completely closed, leaving millions without access to critical care amid one of the worst humanitarian crises in recent history. Since the war began, MSF has recorded over 80 violent incidents targeting our staff, infrastructure, vehicles, and supplies. Clinics have been looted and destroyed, medicines stolen, and health care workers assaulted, threatened, or killed.&nbsp;</p><p>“Buildings were destroyed, even beds were looted, and medicines ,” said Muhammad Yusuf Ishaq Abdullah, MSF health promotion officer in Tawila, North Darfur, about the state of Tawila’s hospital after being attacked and looted in June 2023. “From afar, it looked like a hospital, but when you entered it, it was a shelter for snakes and grass.”</p><p>These attacks must stop. Medical personnel and facilities are not targets.&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="A mother cares for her child in the pediatric section of the cholera treatment center in Kosti, Sudan." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB223198.jpg?itok=Se3aDkLF" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            A mother cares for her child in the pediatric section of the cholera treatment center in Kosti, which experienced a cholera outbreak. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Sudan 2025 © MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>The threat of rainy season approaches</h2><p>The fast-approaching rainy season threatens to make an already catastrophic situation even worse—severing supply routes, flooding entire regions, and cutting off communities just as the hunger gap peaks and malnutrition and malaria spike.</p><p>MSF calls for immediate preparedness measures ahead of the rainy season. More border crossings must be opened, and key roads and bridges must be repaired and kept accessible, especially in Darfur, where seasonal flooding isolates communities year after year.&nbsp;</p><p>In addition, humanitarian restrictions must be lifted, and unhindered access must be guaranteed. MSF urges all actors—including donors, governments, and UN agencies—to enable and prioritize aid delivery, ensuring that assistance not only reaches the country but is transported swiftly and safely to the hardest-hit and most remote communities. Without a serious commitment to overcoming the political, financial, logistical, and security barriers that hinder last-mile delivery, countless lives will remain beyond the reach of help.</p><p>The people of Sudan have endured this horror for too long. They cannot and should not wait any longer to access essential needs.&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : Shooting at MSF-supported hospital in Goma kills one person
Published: Fri, 11 Apr 2025 16:32:12 +0000
Summary  :
<span>Shooting at MSF-supported hospital in Goma kills one person</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">An increase in violent incidents in Democratic Republic of Congo is affecting health care services, and may force facilities to close.</div>
  </div>
<span><span>Kate Rankin</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2025-04-11T12:32:12-04:00" title="Friday, April 11, 2025 - 12:32pm">April 11 2025, 12:32pm</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="A damaged window in Kyeshero Hospital. " height="1200" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/MSB227771%20resize.png" width="1600" />

</div>
  </div>
  <div class="field field--name-body field--type-text-with-summary field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams supporting the intensive nutritional treatment unit of the hospital witnessed the armed men shooting outside the hospital wards, looking for people who had taken refuge inside the hospital for several weeks. Two members of the hospital's staff were severely beaten. The gunmen did not enter the wards but shot into some of them.</p></div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--blockquote paragraph--view-mode--default quote-icon">
                  	
<div class="blockquote-container blockquote-container--gray">
  <div class="blockquote__wrapper">
    <blockquote><p></p><p>The shooting spread fear and disrupted medical services. A bullet passed through a window and landed in a patient's mattress.</p><figcaption>Margot Grelet, MSF emergency coordinator in Goma and North Kivu</figcaption></blockquote>
  </div>
</div>
            </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>“The use of force and weapons inside Kyeshero Hospital has transformed a medical facility—which [is] supposed to remain a safe place at all times—into a dangerous zone where one person was killed,” said Margot Grelet, MSF emergency coordinator in Goma and North Kivu. “The shooting spread fear and disrupted medical services. A bullet passed through a window and landed in a patient's mattress. Such events are unacceptable and must never be repeated, either in Goma or elsewhere.”&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="A man rests with a external fixator on his arm in DRC. " height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/03/MSB222535.jpg?itok=xpo2oZvf" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Charles Baraka Chanungiyo was attacked by assailants as he slept in his home, and he suffered gunshot wounds to the arm and machete wounds to the wrist. He was treated at the MSF-supported Salama Hospital in Bunia. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> DR Congo 2025 © Fanny Hostettler/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Ongoing and escalating violence in DRC</h2><p>This is not an isolated incident, and reflects an alarming <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/dr-congo-msf-adapts-response-violence-spreads-south-kivu" title="DR Congo: MSF adapts response as violence spreads in South Kivu">increase in violence</a> perpetrated by all parties to the conflict affecting health facilities and endangering the lives of patients and medical staff in the region this year.&nbsp;</p><p>MSF reiterates its commitment to providing medical care alongside local health services in the conflict-affected provinces of <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/four-questions-about-whats-going-eastern-dr-congo" title="Four questions about what’s going on in eastern DR Congo">eastern DRC</a>. However, the increased frequency and severity of these incidents is straining our capacity to respond and may lead to the suspension of some services.&nbsp;</p><p>“Without minimum security guarantees, health workers and humanitarian organizations cannot work,” said Grelet. “They must not risk their lives to continue providing vital care to the [community]. We call on all parties concerned to preserve the civilian [status] of health facilities.”</p><p>Since the beginning of the year, MSF teams have experienced around 15 violent incidents directly affecting the structures and hospitals they support in North and South Kivu.&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
    

  


  <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="inline-tout__wrapper">
          <a class="inline-tout__link-wrapper" href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/conflict-dr-congo-whats-happening-how-help"></a>
              <div class="inline-tout__content">
                      <div class="inline-tout__image-content">
                        
                  <source height="159" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="159" />
              <source height="159" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="159" />
              <source height="159" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="159" />
              <source height="105" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="105" />
              <source height="105" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="105" />
                  <img height="159" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/inline_tout_desktop_thumbnail/public/image_base_media/2025/01/MSB220365.jpg?itok=2NGN3tfo" width="159" />

  

        </div>
                    <div class="content-tout-right">
        <h2 class="heading-2 inline-tout__title">Conflict in DR Congo: What’s happening &amp; how to help</h2>
                  
<a class="link-item link-icon--right-arrow inline-tout__cta" href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/conflict-dr-congo-whats-happening-how-help">Read more</a>
              </div>
                </div>
      </div>
</div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>MSF staff among victims of violence&nbsp;</h2><p>One <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/dr-congo-msf-staff-base-hit-bullets-critically-injured" title="DR Congo: MSF staff on base hit by bullets, critically injured ">tragic incident</a> took place on February 20 in the town of Masisi in North Kivu. During clashes between the armed groups VDP/Wazalendos and M23/AFC, fighters shot and wounded two people at the MSF base, including MSF employee <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/msf-mourns-colleague-killed-dr-congo" title="MSF mourns colleague killed in DR Congo">Jerry Muhindo Kavali</a>, who died of his injuries two days later.&nbsp;</p><p>On March 19 In Walikale, about 90 miles from Masisi, our base was hit by crossfire, striking our structures and some of our vehicles during <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/new-wave-violence-eastern-drc-puts-civilians-further-risk" title="New wave of violence in eastern DRC puts civilians at further risk">clashes</a> between the Congolese army (FARDC), M23/AFC, and their allies.&nbsp;</p><p>In mid-February, the General Referral Hospital in <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/dr-congo-crisis-uvira-brink-chaos" title="DR Congo crisis: Uvira on the brink of chaos">Uvira</a>, South Kivu, came under fire during clashes in the town, endangering patients and staff. Medical activities were interrupted, and patients had to take cover to avoid being hit. Armed men also entered the hospital premises, shooting inside.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">

    <div class="body-text  "><h4>MSF in DRC&nbsp;</h4><p>MSF supports several health structures in Goma and several locations across North and South Kivu, focusing on primary and secondary health care, including <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/maternal-health" title="Maternal health">maternal</a>, <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/focus/child-health-initiatives" title="Children’s health">pediatric</a>, <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>, and <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a> care, and care for victims of <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/sexual-and-gender-based-violence" title="Sexual and gender-based violence">sexual violence</a>. MSF has worked at Kyeshero Hospital in Goma for several years, particularly in the management of cases of malnutrition. MSF teams have also supported Virunga Hospital in Goma, as well as Minova General Referral Hospital and Numbi Hospital Center in South Kivu, treating people wounded in armed clashes at the start of the year.</p></div>

Title    : Surviving near the front line: Surgical care in Ukraine
Published: Thu, 10 Apr 2025 15:42:05 +0000
Summary  :
<span>Surviving near the front line: Surgical care in Ukraine</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">Many patients in Ukraine are forced to delay urgently needed care because of shelling and an unstable front line. </div>
  </div>
<span><span>Kate Rankin</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2025-04-10T11:42:05-04:00" title="Thursday, April 10, 2025 - 11:42am">April 10 2025, 11:42am</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="Surviving near the frontline: surgical care for patients" height="1500" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB227488.jpg" width="2000" />

</div>
  </div>
  <div class="field field--name-body field--type-text-with-summary field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>As patients with complications continue to arrive, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are helping to alleviate the burden on the hospital by supporting its emergency department and operating theater. MSF also conducts <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/transit-survival-msf-ambulances-aid-ukraines-war-wounded" title="In transit for survival: MSF ambulances aid Ukraine’s war-wounded">ambulance referrals</a> for patients who need to be examined by highly specialized surgeons in hospitals further away from the front line.</p></div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--blockquote paragraph--view-mode--default quote-icon">
                  	
<div class="blockquote-container blockquote-container--gray">
  <div class="blockquote__wrapper">
    <blockquote><p></p><p>I should have come about a month ago, but I just couldn’t make it. It is hell in our village now. The entire street was destroyed, everyone is hiding.</p><figcaption>Volodymyr, MSF patient</figcaption></blockquote>
  </div>
</div>
            </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>One patient, Volodymyr, is waiting for his second surgery. He is from the village of Komar in the <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/my-town-fire-ukrainians-flee-front-lines-donetsk" title="“My town is on fire”: Ukrainians flee front lines in Donetsk">Donetsk</a> region, located less than 7 miles from the front line. He came to the hospital four days ago with Fournier’s gangrene—a type of flesh-eating disease that should have been treated much earlier, but ongoing hostilities made it difficult to seek care.</p><p>“I could no longer walk, so my neighbor had to bring me to the hospital,” says Volodymyr. “I should have come about a month ago, but I just couldn’t make it. It is hell in our village now. The entire street was destroyed, everyone is hiding in their basements. As soon as it seems to become quieter, the <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/ukraine-relentless-attacks-dobropillia-add-ongoing-medical-needs" title="Ukraine: Relentless attacks in Dobropillia add to ongoing medical needs">shelling</a> starts again.”</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Destruction in the Donetsk region, Ukraine, due to shelling." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/03/MSB224146.jpg?itok=omNnba_A" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Destruction from shelling in the Donetsk region. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Ukraine 2025 ©&nbsp;MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Consequences of delayed treatment</h2><p>Patients like Volodymyr who have neglected diseases are common in this hospital, which is the closest medical facility to the eastern front line that provides secondary care. It is located at the intersection of three regions with active fighting, and receives a high influx of people seeking medical help.</p><p>People come here from the frontline communities of Donetsk, Dnipropetrovsk, and Zaporizhzhia regions, where the shelling does not stop for even a day. The living conditions there are difficult. Patients often do not have <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/access-medicines" title="Access to medicines">access to medicines</a> and medical care, or to food and hygiene items, spending most of their time hiding in the basements of their homes.</p><p>The most intense fighting continues in the Donetsk region, where the front line remains unstable and shifts rapidly, leaving behind devastated towns and villages with people trapped in them. The current hotspots are near Pokrovsk, Kurakhove, and Chasiv Yar. Hospitals in these areas have had to <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/ukraine-last-civilian-hospital-pokrovsk-forced-evacuate-all-staff" title="Ukraine: Last civilian hospital in Pokrovsk forced to evacuate all staff">evacuate</a> their medical staff and equipment, forcing residents to travel long distances to reach the nearest medical facility. Roads are often littered with remnants of weapons, some of which may still contain unexploded ordnance, making travel extremely dangerous. As a result, many people delay seeking medical help, and their conditions worsen.</p><p>“Once we had a patient with a three-day-old peritonitis [inflammation of the abdomen’s inner wall], so we had to take him to the operating theater immediately,” recalls MSF medical activity manager Dr. Khassan El-Kafarna. “People have limited access to health care, and we see how it affects them. There are lots of patients with exacerbated non-communicable diseases: hypertensive crisis, strokes, and neglected surgical diseases.”</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Building destroyed by shelling in Donetsk region, Ukraine." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/03/MSB224144.jpg?itok=ucuEsSz6" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Building destroyed by shelling in Donetsk region. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Ukraine 2025 © Yuliia Trofimova/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Preparing for surgery amid possible power cuts&nbsp;</h2><p>Attacks on energy infrastructure can cause unexpected power outages. The hospital has generators, but the surgeons cannot afford to have any interruptions in their work. That’s why Dr. Khassan, who is performing Volodymyr’s operation, wears a headlamp for the procedure.</p><p>Hospital staff are usually quick to switch on generators, as they’ve become used to the power cuts. However, delays and difficulties still occur. Hospitals must maintain sufficient fuel reserves, and while MSF supports some hospitals with fuel donations, it remains an additional challenge in providing health care. “At such times, elevators don’t work,” recalls Dr. Khassan. “We had to carry patients up the stairs to the operating room on stretchers.”</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="An MSF team performs an operation in Ukraine. " height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB227490.jpg?itok=QE2RfFSt" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            MSF medical activity manager Khassan El-Kafarna assists a Ministry of Health medical team at the operation theater in an Ukrainian hospital near the front line.  <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Ukraine 2025 © Yuliia Trofimova/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Treating patients with war-related injuries</h2><p>Other patients MSF teams treat are those with war-related injuries, such as trauma from shelling, landmines, and bomb and shrapnel blasts. “These people often have multiple traumas to various parts of their bodies, including head trauma, penetrating abdominal and chest wounds, and soft tissue trauma,” says Dr. Khassan. “A lot of patients we receive have open fractures.”</p><p>People with war-related injuries also do not come to us immediately after they sustain their trauma, Dr. Khassan explains, “We are dealing with infected wounds. Patients could not get help for a long time and they come to us in advanced stages of sepsis. For the past month we treated seven patients with septic complications.”&nbsp;</p><p>MSF continues to support medical facilities in Ukraine near the front line. Our medical teams operate in the hospital in the Dnipropetrovsk region and in the city of Kherson. In 2024, MSF teams assisted and performed 1,149 surgeries and supported 435 patients in intensive care units. In the city of Kherson, an MSF medical team also provides surgical and trauma care, running &nbsp;triage and performing surgeries.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="content__wrapper">

        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Surgery is just the first step on a long road to recovery</h2><p>Volodymyr’s operation lasted less than an hour. This was not the first surgery he had to undergo. “When he first came to us, he had septic shock and anemia,” Dr. Khassan says. “Now we got rid of the source of the infection, but he definitely needs tertiary care. We need to stabilize him before we can refer him to a higher-level facility, because he needs a plastic surgeon, a urologist, and admission to intensive care.”&nbsp;</p><p>The nurse finishes bandaging Volodymyr, and he is sent to the intensive care unit. There is a long road to recovery ahead of him. Despite his condition and the approach of the front line closer to his village, Volodymyr says that, most of all, he wants to return home.</p></div>

Title    : MSF steps up Myanmar earthquake response
Published: Wed, 09 Apr 2025 19:51:20 +0000
Summary  :
<span>MSF steps up Myanmar earthquake response</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"> MSF teams are distributing essential non-food items, helping restore clean water sources, and providing physical and mental health care. </div>
  </div>
<span><span>Kate Rankin</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2025-04-09T15:51:20-04:00" title="Wednesday, April 9, 2025 - 3:51pm">April 9 2025, 3:51pm</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="Mobile clinics in Mandalay" height="1196" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB227455.jpg" width="1594" />

</div>
  </div>
  <div class="field field--name-body field--type-text-with-summary field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><p>MSF has prioritized responding in the hardest-hit and currently accessible cities of Mandalay and Naypyidaw, while serious concerns persist for people living in more remote and less accessible areas such as Sagaing.</p><p>As of April 8, over 3,600 deaths have been reported, more than 5,000 people injured, and an estimated 17 million individuals affected—many severely. Key infrastructure sustained significant damage, including hospitals, roads, and water systems, while ongoing telecommunication disruptions continue to hamper relief efforts.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>The earthquake struck a country already gripped by several health crises and conflict, compounding the challenges communities face. Limited resources, staff, and supplies have left some facilities overburdened and struggling to respond to the growing health needs.</p><p>While local communities are demonstrating remarkable solidarity, our staff have reported extensive destruction. Many residents remain outdoors for fear of aftershocks, while monasteries have opened their doors to host displaced families.&nbsp;</p></div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Ruins of Naypyidaw Hospital following an earthquake. " height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB227677.jpg?itok=OcAS6MSP" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            View of the Naypyidaw Hospital after the March 28 earthquake. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Myanmar 2025 © MSF 
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Damaged infrastructure compromises health care</h2><p>In the hardest-hit cities, damage to infrastructure has severely impacted hospitals' ability to function. Due to fears of further building collapse, structural damage has forced medical staff to treat patients outside in some cases.&nbsp;</p><p>In Naypyidaw and Mandalay, where hospital systems were particularly damaged, MSF carried out assessments, delivered medical supplies, and initiated discussions with key stakeholders, including the Ministry of Health.</p><p>In Mandalay, our teams are working to improve water, sanitation, and hygiene conditions in damaged hospitals by installing water tanks and additional handwashing basins. Teams are reinforcing waste management with dozens of bins and helping patients cope with extreme heat –often reaching 104°F –while awaiting treatment outside damaged facilities by setting up fans.</p><p>At the same time, mobile medical teams began providing consultations in makeshift shelters including monasteries, treating a range of conditions from common illnesses to chronic diseases such as diabetes and hypertension. In southern Shan, mobile teams also distributed essential non-food items, restored clean water sources, and continued assessments in affected and displaced communities.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="MSF teams install a water tank at Mandalay General Hospital in Myanmar. " height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB227202.jpg?itok=tpuhaR5c" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            MSF teams install and fix a water tank at the Mandalay General Hospital.  <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Myanmar 2025 © MSF 
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Psychological impact of the earthquake</h2><p>A key priority for our response is <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/mental-health" title="Mental health">mental health</a>. In Mandalay, teams composed of trained staff and student volunteers have been visiting patients in surgical, orthopedic, and trauma wards at local hospitals to provide <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/what-psychological-first-aid" title="What is psychological first aid?">psychological first aid</a>. In a context where survivors face high levels of psychological stress, these efforts are essential. The disaster and the fear of aftershocks, which continue to be recorded, in addition to the consequences of the ongoing conflict ravaging many parts of the country, contribute to this stress.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Damage caused to a market by the Myanmar earthquake. " height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB226982.jpg?itok=NonlHmMo" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            A view of damage to the Thapyay Kone Market in Naypyidaw after the earthquake.   
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Major concerns over expected environmental impact</h2><p>With the rainy season approaching, floods and landslides could exacerbate existing access challenges, particularly in remote areas. The rainy season also significantly heightens the likelihood of public health threats associated with outbreaks of waterborne disease such as <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>, and vector-borne diseases like <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a> or dengue fever. This is due to the potential flood-related contamination of the already reduced number of safe water sources. Immediate actions like scaled up provision of clean water, safe sanitation facilities, distribution of mosquito nets, and hygiene promotion are essential to mitigate the additional threats.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="content__wrapper">
  <div class="email-sign-up email--bg-dark">
    <h2 class="heading-2 email__heading">We speak out. Get updates.</h2>
    <p class="caption   email__caption"></p>

              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>What needs to happen now?</h2><p>In order to address the immense needs, it is crucial for humanitarian aid to reach all affected areas, including hard-to-reach locations, unhindered. To avoid longer-term harmful consequences for people grappling with the aftermath of this earthquake, a further significant scale-up of aid and assurance of access to health care in all affected areas is urgently needed.&nbsp;</p><p>As part of MSF’s long-standing presence in Myanmar since its first intervention in 1992, we reaffirm our readiness to provide emergency medical humanitarian assistance wherever needed, as we continue to support communities affected by conflict, disease, and now, one of the worst earthquakes to strike the region in recent history.</p></div>

Title    : President Lai meets with Tuvaluan deputy prime minister
Published: 2025/04/16
Summary  :
<div class="article-content-part">President Lai Ching-te received Panapasi Nelesone, Tuvalu&rsquo;s deputy prime minister and minister of finance and economic development, April 15 at the Presidential Office in Taipei City, expressing appreciation for the Pacific ally&rsquo;s long-standing support of Taiwan&rsquo;s international participation.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Lai said he looks forward to a continued strengthening of ties with Tuvalu, reiterating points made during his meeting last week with Lily Tangisia Faavae, the nation&rsquo;s new ambassador to Taiwan. The allies will soon sign agreements on labor cooperation and mutual recognition of sailors&rsquo; training and competency documents to further collaboration across the board, he added.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Taiwan and Tuvalu enjoy a close partnership in the areas of agriculture, education, information and communications technology, and medical care, the president said. Both countries value freedom and democracy, and are staunch partners in marine resources conservation, climate adaptation and countering authoritarian expansion, he added, expressing his hope that the partners continue to work together to advance peace and prosperity in the Indo-Pacific.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
In response, Nelesone said Taiwan&rsquo;s assistance in education, health and climate change resilience has significantly influenced the lives of Tuvalu&rsquo;s people. He took the opportunity to thank President Lai for a recent donation of shoes to Tuvaluan students.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Taiwan&rsquo;s strong commitment to the bilateral relationship is critical to the two sides&rsquo; efforts to promote their shared values, which include democracy, resilience and sustainable development, the deputy prime minister said, adding that he believes the partnership will continue to grow and become a model for regional cooperation. (YCH-E)<br />

Title    : National Palace Museum Southern Branch online video tour releases in April
Published: 2025/04/16
Summary  :
<div class="article-content-part">The National Palace Museum is not only the largest museum in Taiwan but was also ranked sixth among the most visited art museums in the world in 2015. The National Science and Technology Council's humanities salon series of online guided tour videos invited assistant professor Chiu Ling-ting from the National Taiwan University of Arts Department of Painting and Calligraphy Arts to give an in-depth introduction to the historical context of the NPM and reveal some secret aspects of the NPM Southern Branch in Chiayi County.<br />
<br />
The museum's cultural artefact collections come mainly from the royal collections of the Song, Yuan, Ming and Qing dynasties. Treasures from the Forbidden City can be seen all over the world, but the best collection is held by the NPM in Taipei City and Chiayi County in Taiwan.<br />
<br />
The opening of the NPM Southern Branch in 2015 injected new life into the visitor experience by combining displays with other events like outdoor art exhibitions, showing the NPM collection from multiple perspectives. Chiu, who acts as guide in the video, was curator of the first prize in the new media art category of the 2019 Florence Biennale in Italy and frequently visits museums and art fairs to facilitate her research.<br />
<br />
The video will premiere on YouTube on Friday, April 18, at 2:00 p.m. It will introduce the architectural design of the NPM Southern Branch and its collections.(POC-E)&nbsp;<br />

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : President Lai attends Cybersec 2025
Published: 2025/04/16
Summary  :
<div class="article-content-part">President Lai Ching-te pledged to continue advancing research and development of information security products and services while encouraging related investment to upgrade cybersecurity across the board.<br />
<br />
Lai made the remarks while attending the Cyberssec 2025 opening ceremony April 15 in Taipei City.<br />
<br />
This year&rsquo;s edition, themed &ldquo;Team Cybersecurity,&rdquo; has brought together global experts and representatives from more than 400 international cybersecurity brands to share their experiences and deepen mutual exchanges, the president said, adding that the ongoing three-day event involves over 300 speeches and has drawn an estimated total of over 20,000 participants.<br />
<br />
According to the Presidential Office, prominent guests included Raymond Greene, director of the American Institute in Taiwan, and other members of the diplomatic corps stationed in Taiwan.<br />
<br />
As digital threats continue to escalate, individuals and organizations cannot face the challenge alone, Lai said. By joining forces, participants can help build a robust global cybersecurity network that meets the digital defense needs of all, he added.<br />
<br />
The president noted that following his inauguration last May, he established a Whole-of-Society Defense Resilience Committee, inviting civil groups and specialists to take part to reinforce the security of financial networks, key infrastructure, telecommunications and transportation.<br />
<br />
Lai said that last month he proposed an additional 17 national security strategies and requested government agencies to take proactive measures to prevent hackers from accessing domestic information.<br />
<br />
The president went on to say that the 2025 national strategy for information security was officially announced last week, and an initiative to strengthen domestic information safety has also been devised for the years 2025-2028.<br />
<br />
The four-year project focuses on three main goals: strengthening societal information security resilience, enriching the information security industry ecosystem and forging new defense technologies, Lai said, adding that the Ministry of Digital Affairs is amending the Cyber Security Management Act to ensure more comprehensive protection.<br />
<br />
The president concluded by thanking industry leaders for their investment and contributions and said he looked forward to working together to jointly safeguard information security and spur development across all sectors. (POC-E)<br />
<br />
Write to Taiwan Today at <a href="mailto:ttonline@mofa.gov.tw">ttonline@mofa.gov.tw</a></div>

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : MOA lauds success of Taiwan-Indonesia young farmer internship project
Published: 2025/04/16
Summary  :
<div class="article-content-part">A closing ceremony for Indonesian trainees of the Young Farmer Internship Program in Taiwan was held April 15 in Taipei City, spotlighting interministerial promotion of agricultural personnel development and exchanges between the two partner countries.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
According to the Ministry of Agriculture, 57 youths from the New Southbound Policy partner country took part in the program this time. Since the initiative&rsquo;s launch in 2009, with a halt during the COVID-19 pandemic, a total of 582 young farmers from Indonesia and the Philippines have received training in Taiwan.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
This project aims to empower individuals as agricultural leaders and entrepreneurs through professional training at Taiwan&rsquo;s agricultural facilities to learn about the latest techniques, technologies and strategies in agriculture, animal husbandry, fisheries and related sectors.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The MOA said after the intensive yearlong training, participants obtained key skills and knowledge of agricultural management, essential for future career development. Among this year&rsquo;s trainees, 23 have been employed by Taiwan businesses operating in Indonesia, three will remain in Taiwan to work, while others have teamed up to become suppliers for the Indonesian fast food sector. MOA statistics shows that about 80 percent of trainees opted to continue to work in agriculture-related sectors after returning home.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Launched in 2016 as a key plank in the government&rsquo;s national development strategy, the NSP seeks to deepen the country&rsquo;s agricultural, business, cultural, education, tourism and trade ties with the 10 Association of Southeast Asian Nations member states, six South Asian countries, Australia and New Zealand. (SFC-E)<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Write to Taiwan Today at <a href="mailto:ttonline@mofa.gov.tw">ttonline@mofa.gov.tw</a></div>

&nbsp;<br />
As a key player in the global supply chain, Taiwan is ready to contribute to the trade bloc&rsquo;s economic and trade integration, the premier said. It is hoped that the U.K. will continue to support Taiwan&rsquo;s CPTPP participation to safeguard global economic order and ensure freedom-based development and prosperity for all, he added.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
According to Cho, trade relations between the two sides date back to the 19th century, when the U.K. established three consulates in Taiwan. British missionaries James Laidlaw Maxwell, Thomas Barclay and William Campbell also made valuable contributions to Taiwan&rsquo;s democracy, education, public health and medical care, he added.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Cho said 2023&rsquo;s bilateral Enhanced Trade Partnership marked the first time a European country formed an institutional economic and trade framework with Taiwan. He listed economic and energy security, digital and financial resilience, and technological and manufacturing innovation as areas with great potential for expanded cooperation, and expected the two-way ties to scale new heights under Bradley-Jones&rsquo; leadership.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The premier also thanked the British Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office for its April 2 statement expressing concern over China&rsquo;s military exercises around Taiwan.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
In response, Bradly-Jones praised growing relations between the two strategic partners and expressed optimism for deepening the relationship based on the shared values of democracy and innovation. She said her country&rsquo;s industrial strategy initiative and Taiwan&rsquo;s Five Trusted Industry Sector project are complementary, and anticipated many more cooperative projects in the future. (SFC-E)<br />
&nbsp;<br />

Published: 2025/04/15
Summary  :
<div class="article-content-part">Taiwan directors Chen Kun-hou and Huang Yu-shan shared their opinions of the Taiwan New Wave April 11 and 12 in London as part of the event &ldquo;Myriad Voices: Reframing Taiwan New Cinema.&rdquo;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
According to the Ministry of Culture, Chen, who is a winner of the Golden Horse Awards&rsquo; best director and lifetime achievement honors, introduced &ldquo;The Boys from Fengkuei&rdquo; by Hou Hsiao-hsien April 11. He shared his extensive cooperation experience with Hou and expressed hope that British audiences would get a taste of Taiwan&rsquo;s hospitality through the film&rsquo;s depiction of culture and scenery and be inspired to visit the country.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Huang delivered a lecture at a seminar April 12, sharing female perspectives on Taiwan&rsquo;s film reform movement and the development of its movie industry in the 1980s. The role of female characters expanded to become a key part of new wave films, she said, adding that the liberation of women&rsquo;s voices echoed the changes in their socioeconomic status during the period.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Both Chen and Huang attended post-screening Q&amp;A sessions of their works, including &ldquo;My Favorite Season&rdquo; and &ldquo;Out of the Blue&rdquo; by Chen and &ldquo;Autumn Tempest&rdquo; by Huang, the MOC said. The ministry added that it is committed to strengthening bilateral cinematic exchanges, increasing the exposure of Taiwan films in the U.K. and boosting access of domestic productions to the British market.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Organized by the Cultural Division of the Taipei Representative Office in the U.K. and the locally based British Film Institute, &ldquo;Myriad Voices&rdquo; runs March 31 through April 30. It features 30 screenings of 15 films, showcasing works by renowned directors such as Chang Yi, Edward Yang, Hou, Wan jen and Wang Toon. (YCH-E)<br />

According to a news release from the Executive Yuan, a trade negotiations team held a video conference with U.S. counterparts April 11 to exchange views on mutual tariffs and nontariff trade barriers including export controls. Both parties look forward to follow-up talks to jointly forge a more robust trade partnership, the release added. (POC-E)<br />

Published: 2025/04/14

<div class="article-content-part">A special exhibition by 30 artists and groups hailing from 14 countries opened April 12 at the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts in the central city of Taichung, inviting audiences to use their senses.<br />

&nbsp;<br />

He cited as examples French filmmaker and movie critique Olivier Assayas&rsquo; introduction of Taiwan new-wave movies of the 1980s to French audiences as well as the translations of many Taiwan comic books and literature.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
He thanked the organizers for staging the avant-garde exhibition and offering visitors a unique way to appreciate and experience sound as an art object through audiovisual and lighting installations.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
In response, Paris commended the NMTFA as a key platform to showcase Taiwan&rsquo;s culture and the work of artists from home and abroad. He said Taiwan and France both value cultural inclusion and diversity, adding that the exhibition is a bold experiment that transcends borders and promotes creative freedom, and that he looks forward to more collaborative projects.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
According to the NTMFA, participating artists include American-Swiss artist Christian Marclay, Dubai-based Laurence Abu Hamdan and Yuko Mohri from Japan, as well as Lin Chi-wei, Jao Chia-en and Wang Fu-jui from Taiwan. The exhibition will run through July 6, the museum added. (SFC-E)<br />

He called on the private sector to work hand in hand with the government, so that the country can weather the storm and find new opportunities for growth. (SFC-E)<br />

Title    : Taiwan’s OAC steps up marine conservation
Published: 2025/04/11
Summary  :
<div class="article-content-part">The Ocean Affairs Council is implementing a research sponsorship program for the second year to foster technological innovation and applications to ensure sustainable marine conservation.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The OAC said it will offer NT$75 million (US$2.28 million) in research grants to 30 selected projects on topics spanning maritime protection and security, ocean pollution prevention, sustainable marine development and smart ocean, as well as surface and underwater vehicle technology development, which are all important subjects of global marine research.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
According to the agency, the country&rsquo;s abundant territorial waters and marine resources render it important for Taiwan to enhance marine technological prowess. This will ensure that local businesses are both globally competitive and meet environmental challenges such as climate change, it said.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
In comparison to the NT$14 million spent last year, the increased amount underscores the importance the government attaches to marine technology development, the OAC said. The grants aim to facilitate research and development of marine technology and cultivate personnel, so as to lay an even stronger sustainable marine development foundation, the agency added.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
In addition to the research sponsorship, the OAC launched the Marine Pollution Control Fund committee April 9 and Minister Kuan Bi-ling convened the first meeting the same day. The 17-member committee comprises academics and experts with a wide range of expertise and marks a major milestone in government policymaking, it said.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
OAC statistics show that the fund has accumulated NT$210 million as of March this year. With an annual reserve of NT$50 million allocated since 2024, the goal is for the fund to reach NT$500 million in total to ensure the government has enough resources to respond to major marine pollution incidents, the agency added. (SFC-E)<br />
&nbsp;<br />

Title    : Sybiha: Russia has violated all ten principles of the Helsinki Final Act, it has no place in the OSCE
Published: Wed, 16 Apr 2025 15:09:00 +0000
Summary  :
<p><img alt="" class="attachment-thumbnail size-thumbnail" height="127" src="https://uatv.ua/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/630_360_1742988038-275-222x127.jpg" width="222" /></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>Russia poses and will continue to pose an immediate and existential threat to the security of Europe, so it is necessary to update the European security system and reform international law.<br />Ukrainian Foreign Minister Andrii Sybiha wrote about this on the social network X, <a href="https://www.ukrinform.ua/rubric-polytics/3982740-sibiga-rosia-porusila-vsi-desat-principiv-gelsinskogo-zaklucnogo-akta-ij-ne-misce-v-obse.html">Ukrinform</a> reports.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>He reminded that this year the Helsinki Final Act turns 50 years old.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>“This document, which is fundamental to the European security architecture, begins with a statement of ten principles. A closer look reveals that Russia has violated each of them,” the minister said.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>In particular, he stated that by attacking Ukraine, the Russian Federation violated the principle of political independence and territorial integrity of states, the obligation not to threaten or use force against any state, the principles of inviolability of borders, peaceful settlement of disputes, non-interference in internal affairs, human rights and fundamental freedoms, equal rights and self-determination of peoples, cooperation in accordance with the principles and purposes of the UN Charter and fulfillment of obligations under international law.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>“Having violated all ten fundamental principles of the Helsinki Final Act, Russia has no right to talk about any of its 'legitimate security interests' and has no place in the OSCE. The architecture of European security must be updated with the understanding that Russia poses and will continue to pose an immediate and existential threat to the security of Europe,” Sybiha said.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>He added that these violations also show that the current international system is dysfunctional and unfair.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>“International law should be a law, not a declaration. With effective enforcement mechanisms. In this regard, we insist on a broader reform of international humanitarian and criminal law - reform of the enforcement instruments of the Geneva Convention and other measures aimed at improving the effectiveness of the international system,” the Foreign Minister stressed.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>The post <a href="https://uatv.ua/en/sybiha-russia-has-violated-all-ten-principles-of-the-helsinki-final-act-it-has-no-place-in-the-osce/">Sybiha: Russia has violated all ten principles of the Helsinki Final Act, it has no place in the OSCE</a> appeared first on <a href="https://uatv.ua/en/">Freedom</a>.</p>
