=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : Sudan crisis response
Published: Wed, 04 Oct 2023 12:36:48 +0000
Summary  :
<span>Sudan crisis response</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">How MSF is responding to urgent needs inside Sudan and in neighboring countries.</div>
  </div>
<span><span>Leila Rafei</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2023-10-04T08:36:48-04:00" title="Wednesday, October 4, 2023 - 8:36am">October 4 2023, 8:36am</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="Faces and stories of resilience" height="1333" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/image_base_media/2025/02/MSB218028.jpg" width="2000" />

</div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in Sudan are treating war-wounded patients with catastrophic injuries and providing humanitarian aid and medical care in refugee camps and displacement sites, where people are living in poor conditions and lack adequate health care and basic needs. More than 12 million people have been <a href="https://data.unhcr.org/en/situations/sudansituation">displaced</a> by the current conflict, including over 3 million people who have fled to neighboring countries such as <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/chad" title="Chad">Chad</a>, <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, and <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/south-sudan">South Sudan</a>.</p><p><em>Photo above: Displaced people attend an MSF health promotion session on cholera prevention in Al Tadamon gathering site, Gedaref state. Sudan 2024 © Faiz Abubakr</em></p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--three-statistics-in-columns paragraph--view-mode--default">
          <div class="statistics-wrapper-full">
      <div class="statistics-wrapper content__wrapper  greater-six">
                  
          <div class="statistics-item greater-six">
  <div class="statistics__number">
      194,032
  </div>
	<div class="statistics__description"><p><strong>Emergency room</strong> consultations</p></div>
</div>
                  
          <div class="statistics-item less-seven">
  <div class="statistics__number">
      59,887
  </div>
	<div class="statistics__description"><p><strong>malnutrition</strong> cases treated</p></div>
</div>
                  
          <div class="statistics-item greater-six">
  <div class="statistics__number">
      174,779
  </div>
	<div class="statistics__description"><p><strong>malaria </strong>patients treated</p></div>
</div>
                
      </div>
    </div>
    </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">
	
		
		
		
		
		
	
	<div class="paragraph paragraph--type--accordion paragraph--view-mode--default">
					
<div class="msf-accordion accordion-container content__wrapper">
      <h2 class="msf-accordion__heading">Sudan crisis FAQ</h2>
  
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>What’s happening in Sudan?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> For nearly two years, Sudan has experienced ongoing violence, including intense gunfire, shelling, and airstrikes. </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>For nearly two years, large parts of Sudan have been experiencing ongoing violence, including intense urban warfare, gunfire, shelling, and airstrikes. The health system, already fragile before the conflict started, is struggling to cope with existing and emerging medical needs while facing overwhelming pressure from the destruction and looting of health facilities, acute shortages of utilities and medical supplies, and under-resourced, unpaid, and overworked personnel. As a result, people face significant challenges accessing medical care throughout the country.</p><h4>What to know about the war in Sudan</h4><h5>It’s led to the world’s largest displacement crisis.&nbsp;</h5><p>The war in Sudan has forced more than 12 million people—over 1 in 5 Sudanese—to flee their homes in the nearly two years since it started, including over 3 million who have crossed its borders into neighboring countries like Chad and South Sudan, where MSF is providing assistance for refugees and returnees. Many displaced people are sheltering in crowded camps established in the aftermath of the 2003 Darfur crisis, with no roof over their heads to protect them from the rain and scorching summer heat.</p><h5>Sudan's health system has collapsed.&nbsp;</h5><p>Sudan’s health system was already fragile before this conflict. Today, artillery attacks, the occupation of hospitals by armed forces, power outages, and shortages of medical supplies and personnel have brought Sudan’s health system to the brink of collapse. Millions of Sudanese lack access to essential medical care despite alarming needs.</p><h5>The war in Sudan is a war on people.&nbsp;</h5><p>People in Sudan continue to be subjected to horrific violence as warring parties attack each other with little respect for civilian life. The violence has also taken on an ethnic dimension in Sudan’s Darfur region, which was devastated by another war in the early 2000s. Refugees who have fled from West Darfur to Chad describe an unbearable spiral of violence, with looting, homes burned, beatings, sexual violence, and massacres, particularly targeting the Masalit ethnic minority.</p><p>Civilians, residential areas, infrastructure, health workers, and health facilities must be protected.</p><h5>The humanitarian response remains critically underfunded.&nbsp;</h5><p>It’s also hindered by restricted access to conflict zones. An urgent-scale-up of humanitarian response is needed to meet the needs of people in Sudan. MSF is one of the few international organizations working in parts of Sudan that are most heavily impacted by the violence. The UN and other humanitarian organizations are barely visible on the ground beyond the main entry points in the east (Port Sudan) and west (El Geneina). This is partly due to the mounting violence, lawlessness, and access challenges imposed by both parties to the conflict.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>What are the medical and humanitarian needs MSF is seeing in Sudan?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> With a collapsed health system, the medical needs in Sudan are dire, urgent, and exacerbated by the conflict. </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>With a collapsed health system, the medical needs in Sudan are dire, urgent, and exacerbated by the conflict.</p><h5>Food insecurity and malnutrition</h5><p>Food insecurity and malnutrition have reached catastrophic levels in parts of Sudan, particularly in Zamzam camp, North Darfur, which is the largest displacement site in the country. In 2024, multiple screenings carried out by MSF and Sudanese health authorities in the camp indicated alarming and worsening rates of malnutrition. On August 1, 2024, the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) Famine Review Committee concluded that <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/sudan-after-famine-declaration-catastrophic-malnutrition-zamzam-camp-only-getting-worse" title="Sudan: After famine declaration, catastrophic malnutrition in Zamzam camp is only getting worse">famine conditions</a> were prevalent in the area.</p><h5>Access to health care&nbsp;</h5><p>Sudan’s health system was already fragile before this conflict. Today, artillery attacks, the occupation of hospitals by armed forces, power outages, and shortages of medical supplies and personnel have brought Sudan’s health system to the brink of collapse. Active fighting and lack of transportation hinder patients’ ability to reach the health facilities that are functioning. By the time many arrive at a hospital, they are in critical condition; pregnant women often have to give birth at home.</p><h5>Disease outbreaks&nbsp;</h5><p>Before the current war, Sudan had a high prevalence of non-communicable diseases and faced both seasonal and non-seasonal outbreaks of diseases like <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/measles" title="Measles">measles</a> and <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>. Now, as the ongoing conflict has disrupted essential services such as water supply and the availability of medicine, the health situation has become even more dire.</p><div class="ckeditor-readmore-wrapper"><div class="ckeditor-readmore"><p>As people flee to overcrowded camps, the risk of disease outbreaks has risen, especially among children. The lack of availability and access to vaccinations has left many children unvaccinated, heightening the risk of deadly but vaccine-preventable diseases such as measles.</p><p>In addition, people with chronic diseases such as <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/diabetes" title="Diabetes">diabetes</a>, asthma, and heart disease are facing serious complications due to lack of medicines and lack of access to functional health facilities.</p></div></div><h5>Surgery and emergency care&nbsp;</h5><p>The war has put intense pressure on hospitals with surgery and emergency departments. MSF teams are seeing war-wounded patients with catastrophic injuries caused by explosions, bullets, and stabbings, and are responding to mass casualty incidents. People injured in road traffic accidents and women in need of emergency cesarean sections also face difficulty accessing care.</p><h5>Maternal and pediatric care&nbsp;</h5><p>Pregnant women and children residing in camps, particularly in the western, southern, and eastern regions of the country, are especially vulnerable to health risks due to harsh living conditions and the insufficient humanitarian response. Women often give birth in unsanitary tents or at home, increasing the risk of complications and infections, while access to <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/maternal-health" title="Maternal health">maternal health</a> care remains insufficient.</p><p>At the same time, the need for postnatal and pediatric care is immense. Children under 5 years old, especially newborns and toddlers, have an increased likelihood of contracting diseases and are more vulnerable to complications from malnutrition, <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a>, measles, or acute watery diarrhea.</p><h5>Obstruction of humanitarian access&nbsp;</h5><p>Throughout the war, there has been a systematic obstruction of aid, humanitarian access, and supplies. It has been difficult to get visas for humanitarian staff to enter the country and travel permits to move around Sudan. Permits to cross front lines have repeatedly been denied. Attempts have also been made to prevent aid from entering the country, including from Chad and South Sudan.</p><h5>Mental health&nbsp;</h5><p>The war and violence continue to have serious <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/mental-health" title="Mental health">mental health</a> implications for people fleeing or stuck in the midst of the fighting. People continue to experience extreme trauma as they lose family members and loved ones; witness and experience violence, including <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/sexual-and-gender-based-violence" title="Sexual and gender-based violence">sexual violence</a>; and the deterioration of their own health or the health of loved ones.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>How is MSF responding in Sudan?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> MSF works in 10 out of 18 states in Sudan with a team of more than 1,500 Sudanese staff and over 200 international staff.  </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF works in 10 out of 18 states in Sudan with a team of more than 1,500 Sudanese staff and over 200 international staff. Our teams work in or support 22 hospitals; 42 primary health care facilities and mobile clinic sites; and 15 integrated community case management sites. We also pay incentives to 3,356 Ministry of Health staff.</p><p>MSF’s main medical activities in Sudan include:</p><ul><li><strong>Emergency care and surgery</strong>, including trauma care for the war-wounded and &nbsp;those with non-war related injuries</li><li><strong>Maternal and pediatric health care</strong>, including cesarean sections</li><li><strong>Malnutrition screening and treatment </strong>for acutely malnourished children and pregnant mothers</li><li><strong>Outpatient care and mobile clinics</strong>, including in sites where displaced people and refugees have sought shelter</li><li><strong>Routine- and catch-up vaccination campaigns</strong></li><li><strong>Responses to outbreaks</strong> of diseases including cholera and measles</li><li><strong>Donations</strong> of medicines and medical supplies to health care facilities</li><li><strong>Incentives, training, and logistical support</strong> for Ministry of Health staff</li><li><strong>Water and sanitation activities, </strong>including setting up and restoring and cleaning latrines and water points.</li></ul></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
        <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/png" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/png" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/png" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/png" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/png" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Map of MSF activities in Sudan." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/MSB217911.png?itok=L2rOsg8U" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
              
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>How is MSF responding in neighboring countries?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> MSF is providing assistance for refugees and returnees who have fled to Chad and South Sudan. </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF is providing assistance for refugees and returnees who have fled to Chad and South Sudan.</p><h3>Chad</h3><p>Since the war started, <a href="https://data.unhcr.org/en/situations/sudansituation">more than 700,000</a> refugees and returnees have crossed the border from Sudan to eastern Chad, according to the UN Refugee Agency. MSF teams work in three border regions that have been hosting most new arrivals: Ouaddaï, Wadi Fira, and Sila, supporting refugees, returnees, and host communities.</p><p>In 2024, MSF provided a wide range of medical services in Chad: primary health care, malnutrition screening and treatment, vaccination, and sexual and reproductive health care. Given the struggle to acquire sufficient, quality water—which increases the risk of waterborne diseases—MSF is constantly working to improve access to water and sanitation. Our teams dig boreholes, build and connect water points in camps, provide technical support to other actors, set up latrines, and rehabilitate water pumps in host-communities. MSF is also intervening in response to an increase in cases of hepatitis E, which is currently an epidemic in the east of the country.</p><p>In addition to medical support, MSF provides refugee communities with non-food items such as plastic sheeting, mosquito nets, and soap, which is crucial during the rainy season to prevent additional heath risks.</p><p>Despite these efforts, the humanitarian response in eastern Chad has been struggling due to insufficient funding for humanitarian organizations on the ground, leaving critical gaps in the provision of food, shelter, water, and sanitation.&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
        <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Returnees in a camp in Twic, South Sudan." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2024/04/MSB169939.jpg?itok=0ME2z06t" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Majook-noon camp houses thousands of displaced people, many of whom are South Sudanese returnees fleeing the war in Sudan. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> South Sudan 2023 ©&nbsp;Sean Sutton/Panos pictures
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h3>South Sudan</h3><p>Since the war in Sudan started, more than 1 million people have fled to South Sudan. The border county of Renk, which has seen a surge of approximately 120,000 new arrivals since December 2024, has been significantly impacted. MSF is providing medical services to refugees and returnees and host communities in several regions, including Renk, the Abyei Special Administrative Area, and the capital, Juba.</p><p>In Renk, MSF supports Renk County Hospital, offering pre- and post-operative care for war-related injuries in partnership with the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), which provides surgical care, runs pediatric services, and operates a cholera treatment unit. MSF has set up 17 additional tents to accommodate the influx of patients.</p><p>MSF also conducts outreach activities at the Gossfami, Girbanat, and Atam informal settlements, which host over 60,000 people facing a severe lack of health care services. MSF initially supplied non-food items like blankets and water containers and continues to conduct outpatient consultations, predominantly treating malaria and diarrhea cases. Our teams also run an ambulance service referring patients to Renk Civil Hospital, provide up to 23,000 liters [over 6,000 gallons] of water daily, and are currently setting up sanitation infrastructure, including latrines and water points.</p><p>On October 28, 2024, the South Sudan Ministry of Health declared a cholera outbreak in Renk County, exacerbated by inadequate sanitation and overcrowded living conditions. The disease spread unusually fast to at least seven of the nation's 10 states. MSF has responded in five states, treating cholera patients and administering vaccinations in areas such as Renk, Malakal, Rubkona, Juba, and Gorom refugee camp, where currently over 12,000 Sudanese refugees are living.</p><p>Despite the increasing number of refugees and returnees, significant gaps remain in the humanitarian response. Water supply and sanitation facilities pose urgent concerns; many communities depend on dwindling rainwater sources, which raises the risk of communal conflict. Moreover, food and shelter shortages persist, with many living in inadequate conditions, such as makeshift tents or under trees, while lacking essential needs. MSF is committed to supporting all affected people in South Sudan, including refugees, returnees, and local communities facing dire circumstances.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>How long has MSF worked in Sudan?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> MSF has been present in Sudan since 1979, witnessing historic changes and escalating needs as political and social dynamics shift rapidly. </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF has been present in Sudan since 1979, witnessing historic changes and escalating needs in response to the rapid shifts in the country’s political and social dynamics, which in turn impact health needs.&nbsp;</p>

<p>Our intervention began shortly before the Second Sudanese Civil War (1983-2005), which was fought primarily between the north and south of Sudan and was one of Africa's longest civil wars. MSF was actively involved in providing medical care to war-affected communities dealing with massive displacement, famine, and the outbreak of diseases. With the independence of South Sudan in 2011, MSF continued operations in both countries, adapting to the shifting dynamics of conflict and the division of resources.&nbsp;</p>

<p>When the war broke out in April 2023, many activities were either stopped or shifted to respond to the emerging needs and emergencies across the country. Some activities continued—in Darfur, for example—thanks to the efforts of our locally hired MSF staff, who continued to work despite the extremely difficult personal and environmental circumstances.&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
      <div class="ac ">
  <h3 class="ac-header">
    <button class="ac-trigger"><p>What does it mean to be an independent and impartial medical humanitarian organization?</p></button>
          <p class="ac-preview-content"> MSF provides medical care to anyone who needs it, regardless of race, religion, or political affiliation. </p>
      </h3>
  <div class="ac-panel">
    
    
  <div class="field field--name-field-accordion-content-block field--type-entity-reference-revisions field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF provides medical care to anyone who needs it, regardless of race, religion, or political affiliation. We are calling on all parties to the conflict to ensure the safety of civilians, medical facilities, and personnel. Hospitals must remain a sanctuary for people seeking care. &nbsp;</p><p>To facilitate our humanitarian and medical work, we speak to all parties to the conflict to request safe, rapid, and unimpeded access to civilians who require medical care and to ensure the safety and security of our staff. This is why our independence and impartiality are essential to our work in all the places we operate across the globe.&nbsp;</p><p><a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/who-we-are" title="Who we are">Learn more about the principles that guide our work &gt;</a></p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
  </div>
			</div>
</div>

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : Harnessing solar power in Nigeria
Published: Wed, 23 Apr 2025 20:07:08 +0000
Summary  :
<span>Harnessing solar power in Nigeria</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">How patient care improved when a hospital switched to renewable energy.</div>
  </div>
<span><span>Leila Rafei</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2025-04-23T16:07:08-04:00" title="Wednesday, April 23, 2025 - 4:07pm">April 23 2025, 4:07pm</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="Solarization of Zurmi General Hospital" height="1241" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB228368.jpg" width="2000" />

</div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>Before Zurmi General Hospital went solar, many of the staff were holding their breath. Some worried about how the change in power would affect medical operations.</p><p>“We have people on oxygen tanks,” said one MSF staff member, reminding the engineers about what was at stake.</p><p>Very quickly, those fears turned to relief. The transition went smoothly, and the electricity remained stable into the following days.</p><p>“Before, it was extremely challenging,” said Israel Mushore, the energy manager who worked on the project for five months. “Patients would be taken into surgery, and there was always the risk of a power cut in the middle of the procedure. Now, with solar power, we have a stable and reliable energy source.”</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--blockquote paragraph--view-mode--default quote-icon">
                  	
<div class="blockquote-container blockquote-container--white">
  <div class="blockquote__wrapper">
    <blockquote><p></p><p>Patients would be taken into surgery, and there was always the risk of a power cut in the middle of the procedure. Now, with solar power, we have a stable and reliable energy source.</p><figcaption>Israel Mushore, energy manager</figcaption></blockquote>
  </div>
</div>
            </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>For years, Zurmi General Hospital had been cut off from the national grid. Instead, it had to rely on generators that consumed more than 3,000 gallons of fuel each month. The system led to frequent and frustrating power disruptions.</p><p>Since installing 436 solar panels this year, the 250-kilowatt solar power system has consistently kept medical devices running and medications refrigerated, as well as enabling emergency surgical procedures. A battery backup system also ensures that hospital operations continue smoothly at night and during extended periods of cloud coverage. Patients in the hospital, including in <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/maternal-health" title="Maternal health">maternity</a> care, the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), and the <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a> unit, have seen their health care improve. &nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="An aerial view of the solar panels installed at Zurmi General Hospital in Nigeria." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB228370.jpg?itok=tukNJ1Rv" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            An aerial view of the solar panels installed at Zurmi General Hospital. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Nigeria 2025 ©&nbsp;Isaac Buay/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>“I cannot overstate how the switch to solar panels has improved our ability to respond to <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a> and pediatric emergencies by being able to better store <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/vaccination" title="Vaccination">vaccines</a> and expand our outreach,” said Abdullahi Mohamed Ali, MSF head of mission in Nigeria.</p><p>At the same time, the introduction of renewable energy has strengthened the hospital’s ability to provide consistent, quality care in the long term. By changing the infrastructure—including what needs to be sourced, transported, stored, and paid for—the hospital is now better equipped to deliver more reliable and uninterrupted care.</p><p>And because solar power is a cleaner energy source, it leaves a smaller environmental footprint, reducing its contribution to the <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/focus/climate-change-emergency" title="Climate emergency">climate crisis</a> already communities around the world.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="The control unit at Zurmi General Hospital in Nigeria, which manages power distribution and storage to ensure seamless transition to solar energy." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB228363.jpg?itok=65VQ_B6X" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            The control unit manages power distribution and storage to ensure seamless transition to solar energy. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Nigeria 2025 ©&nbsp;Isaac Buay/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>The impact of climate change on patients’ health</h2><p>Climate-related shocks like droughts and floods are severely impacting agricultural productivity, disrupting access to land for livestock herders and farmers, and sparking competition over resources. This is fueling violence and displacement, leading to <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/when-does-hunger-become-famine" title="When does hunger become famine?">food insecurity</a> and malnutrition across the region.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Hamida sits beside her daughter, who is suffering from malnutrition, in an inpatient therapeutic feeding center in the northwest." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2024/09/MSB200207.jpg?itok=utJcBr7w" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Hamida sits beside her daughter, who is suffering from malnutrition, in an inpatient therapeutic feeding center in the northwest. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Nigeria 2024 ©&nbsp;Abba Adamu Musa/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>Over the years, MSF teams in the eight northern states of Nigeria where MSF operates—including Zamfara state, where Zurmi General Hospital is located—have recorded a concerning rise in the number of severely malnourished children with life-threatening complications. In 2024, MSF treated over 300,000 children—an alarming 25 percent increase from 2023. Over 75,000 of these children required inpatient care. This year, in anticipation of an even higher number of patients suffering from malnutrition, MSF is in the process of increasing its bed capacity in some of our hospitals.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--blockquote paragraph--view-mode--default quote-icon">
                  	
<div class="blockquote-container blockquote-container--white">
  <div class="blockquote__wrapper">
    <blockquote><p></p><p>From the rising frequency of extreme weather events to violent land disputes stemming from drought-ravaged farmlands that have diminished crop yields, the connection between climate and health is stark.</p><figcaption>Abdullahi Mohamed Ali, MSF head of mission in Nigeria</figcaption></blockquote>
  </div>
</div>
            </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF teams have also observed how years of changing weather—including warmer temperatures and shifting rainfall patterns—have enabled mosquitoes to breed more rapidly and thrive in new areas, increasing Nigerians’ exposure to <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a>. According to 2023 numbers—the most recent data available from the World Health Organization (WHO)—Nigeria accounted for 26 percent of 263 million cases worldwide, with an estimated 6.8 million more cases since 2018.</p><p>“Every day, we witness how climate factors influence the health of communities around the world,” Mohamed Ali said. “From the rising frequency of extreme weather events to violent land disputes stemming from drought-ravaged farmlands that have diminished crop yields, the connection between climate and health is stark.”</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Solarization of Zurmi General Hospital" height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB228364.jpg?itok=zO_bIm8e" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Zurmi General Hospital initially relied on giant 65KVA generators to power the medical medical facility 24 hours a day. With the solar energy system in place, fuel consumption and carbon emissions will be significantly reduced, making health care more sustainable. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Nigeria 2025 ©&nbsp;Isaac Buay/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Stepping up efforts to mitigate climate change</h2><p>Transitioning to renewable energy has meant that MSF can better respond to patients’ needs. By spending less money and time to source and transport costly fuel to keep generators going—especially in remote areas—MSF has been able to devote more resources toward other necessary costs to keep hospitals running and accessible to patients. We are already &nbsp;starting to see results with our other solar panel installations in Zamfara state—Talata Mafara and Gummi—and in Borno, Jigawa, Katsina, Bauchi, Kano, and Sokoto states.</p><p>“While there are still other steps to be taken to reduce MSF's overall environmental impact, switching to solar power is part of our work to create a more sustainable solution that will benefit patients and communities,” Mohamed Ali added.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="content__wrapper"></div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="content__wrapper"></div>

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : When every minute counts: Responding in the critical first 72 hours of an epidemic
Published: Mon, 21 Apr 2025 16:35:24 +0000
Summary  :
<span>When every minute counts: Responding in the critical first 72 hours of an epidemic</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">MSF infectious disease specialist Diyani Dewasurendra describes the scene at a hospital receiving its first cholera cases amid a 2023 outbreak in South Sudan. </div>
  </div>
<span><span>Leila Rafei</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2025-04-21T12:35:24-04:00" title="Monday, April 21, 2025 - 12:35pm">April 21 2025, 12:35pm</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="MSF staff at Malakal CTC" height="1333" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB216316.jpg" width="2000" />

</div>
  </div>
  <div class="field field--name-body field--type-text-with-summary field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item"><div class="background-tan">Diyani Dewasurendra is an infectious disease specialist with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) who was working in <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/south-sudan">South Sudan</a> during a cholera outbreak in 2023. The country is currently experiencing <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/south-sudan-racing-stop-cholera-outbreak" title="South Sudan: Racing to stop a cholera outbreak">another cholera outbreak</a> fueled by dire water and sanitation conditions and gaps in health care and other essential services. Here, Dewasurendra describes the scene inside MSF's hospital in Malakal when the first cases started arriving, and the critical actions taken in the next 72 hours.</div></div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><div class="text--with-red-top-divider">By Diyani Dewasurendra, MSF infectious disease specialist</div><p><br />Every epidemic begins with suspicion: a sudden rise in illness, recurring symptoms, and the first severely ill patients. In crisis zones, infectious diseases can spread at lightning speed. Every minute counts when trying to contain them. The first 72 hours are critical to save lives and prevent a disaster.</p><p>In 2023, I was on assignment in Malakal, <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/south-sudan">South Sudan</a>, when a <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a> outbreak hit.</p><h2>Hours 0 – 12: First signs and measures</h2><p>At our hospital in Malakal, we suddenly saw a spike in children arriving with severe diarrhea. In a region with limited access to safe water, that’s a red flag. On top of that, it was March—the final month of the dry season. Since November, there had been almost no rainfall and many water sources had dried up. This region often sees no rain at all between November and March.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--blockquote paragraph--view-mode--default red-line-icon">
                  
	
<div class="blockquote-container blockquote-container--white">
  <div class="blockquote__wrapper">
    <blockquote><p class="blockquote-without-attribution"></p><p>As soon as the first tests came back positive for cholera, we had to act quickly. The outbreak was now officially confirmed—and every minute counted.</p></blockquote>
  </div>
</div>
            </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>We knew cholera was a possibility, but we had to be sure. We collected samples and sent them to the lab. At the same time, we began monitoring case numbers. As soon as the first tests came back positive for cholera, we had to act quickly. The outbreak was now officially confirmed—and every minute counted.</p><p>In a region where many people lack access to clean water, a disease like cholera can escalate quickly. One of the most dangerous aspects is that the only available water source is often a river—the same river where animals bathe, where people wash themselves, and from which they drink. In situations like this, contamination with germs can have catastrophic consequences.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="Beds in the Assosa cholera treatment center in South Sudan." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB216318.jpg?itok=1DcpH32P" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Inside the pediatric ward at MSF's cholera treatment center in Assosa, near the hospital in Malakal. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> South Sudan 2024 ©&nbsp;Paula Casado Aguirregabiria
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Hours 48–72: Vaccination campaign and epidemic control</h2><p>Now the goal was not just to slow down the outbreak, but to bring it under control. In addition to treating those already infected, the next major step was <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/vaccination" title="Vaccination">vaccination</a>. Cholera can be contained with an oral vaccine—a major advantage, as it allows us to quickly and efficiently vaccinate large groups of people.</p><p>Before starting the vaccination campaign for the community, we had to protect our medical teams. Doctors, nurses, and support staff are in direct contact with patients, so vaccination is essential for their survival. Only after that could we begin the large-scale rollout for the affected population.</p><p>Education also played a crucial role. In crisis areas, people are not generally skeptical of vaccines—but often, they simply don’t know that a vaccine exists. As soon as we explained to the first groups the purpose and benefits of the vaccine, acceptance increased rapidly.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="MSF staff taking care of a patient in a cholera treatment center. " height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/01/MSB216321.jpg?itok=MvnGqR_M" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            MSF staff treat a patient in the cholera treatment center in Malakal, 200 miles south of Renk.  <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> South Sudan 2024 © Paula Casado Aguirregabiria/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Hours 24–48: Treating patients and identifying the source</h2><p>While treating the first patients, we also assessed the water supply. In many parts of South Sudan, there are no wells or pumps—people collect water from rivers or ponds, which are often contaminated.</p><p>I remember one situation where cattle died en masse and hundreds of carcasses were left lying along the riverbank. Yet people had no choice but to continue drinking from the river. Many didn’t realize that the water could be dangerous.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--blockquote paragraph--view-mode--default red-line-icon">
                  
	
<div class="blockquote-container blockquote-container--white">
  <div class="blockquote__wrapper">
    <blockquote><p class="blockquote-without-attribution"></p><p>Hundreds of carcasses were left lying along the riverbank. Yet people had no choice but to continue drinking from the river.</p></blockquote>
  </div>
</div>
            </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>Together with the World Health Organization (WHO) and other partners, we tested the water quality and investigated potential sources of contamination. We knew we couldn’t just treat the disease—we had to prevent more people from getting infected. That’s why we started distributing clean water.&nbsp;</p><p>In some villages, we used charcoal filters or chlorine treatment to improve the water supply in the long term. We also installed sanitation facilities like latrines.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">


<div class="content__wrapper">
  <div class="alert__wrapper">
          <div class="alert__type alert__type--overview">
        Overview
      </div>
                <div class="alert-content">
        <h3 class="alert__title">Facts about cholera </h3>
        <div class="alert__description">
          <p>Up to <a href="https://www.who.int/health-topics/cholera">4 million people are infected</a> with cholera every year, and 140,000 die from it. MSF is active in the fight against cholera worldwide, treating infected patients, running vaccination campaigns, educating communities, distributing hygiene kits, and improving access to clean water and sanitation to curb future outbreaks.&nbsp;</p><h5>Risks and spread</h5><p>Cholera is an acute bacterial infection caused by Vibrio cholerae and spreads mainly through contaminated water and food. It spreads rapidly, particularly in areas with poor water supply and sanitation. Though it occurs worldwide, the highest numbers of cases are in regions with poor water systems and sanitation.&nbsp;</p><p>In humanitarian emergencies such as conflict zones or after <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/focus/natural-disaster-response" title="Natural disasters">natural hazards</a>, the risk of outbreaks increases significantly, as people are often crowded together without access to clean water. Vaccination can significantly reduce the risk of infection and provide long-lasting protection.&nbsp;</p><div class="ckeditor-readmore-wrapper"><div class="ckeditor-readmore"><h5>Symptoms and treatment</h5><p>Cholera symptoms can appear within just a few hours or days of infection. The disease is characterized by severe watery diarrhea, which can lead to extreme dehydration, circulatory collapse, and—if left untreated—death. However, with early treatment using oral rehydration solutions or intravenous fluids, over 99 percent of patients fully recover.</p><p>In MSF medical projects, we operate specialized <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/everything-you-need-know-about-cholera" title="Everything you need to know about cholera">cholera treatment centers</a> to care for infected patients and help stop the spread of the disease. These centers are structured to ensure isolation and safe care, and can be set up within days to respond quickly during acute emergencies.</p><h5>Vaccination</h5><p>The oral vaccine remains the most effective protection against cholera, and currently there is no useful alternative. Administered in two doses, the vaccine provides around 85-percent protection; during outbreaks, a single dose may be administered to protect as many people as possible quickly. The WHO recommends the vaccine for people who live in endemic areas or travel to high-risk regions.</p><h5>Barriers to vaccine access</h5><p>Vaccine production remains a major challenge, as <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/global-cholera-vaccine-stockpile-runs-empty-16-countries-report-outbreaks" title="Global cholera vaccine stockpile runs empty as 16 countries report outbreaks">demand often exceeds supply</a>, particularly in emergencies. The global stock is kept at a level sufficient to respond to epidemics, but to not allow preventive campaigns. A limited number of manufacturers and high production costs add to the global supply shortage.</p><p>During humanitarian crises, vaccines are often not produced or delivered fast enough. Logistical hurdles, such as disrupted supply chains or lack of refrigeration, further complicate vaccination campaigns, especially in remote areas.</p><p>Affordability is also an issue. In Austria, for example, the cholera vaccine costs around $80. While prices vary by country and provider, they remain out of reach for many people worldwide.</p></div></div>
        </div>
              </div>
  </div>
</div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Hours 12–24: Isolation and protection measures</h2><p>The top priority is to stop the disease from spreading further. We immediately set up a cholera isolation ward at the hospital. In Malakal, this was especially challenging, as we already had a separate isolation area for <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/measles" title="Measles">measles</a>. We had to ensure that patients with the two highly contagious diseases wouldn’t come into contact with each other, and that other patients would remain protected from infection.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="mini-cta">
  <h3 class="heading-3 mini-cta__heading">Everything you need to know about cholera</h3>

  
<a class="link-item link-bold link-cta mini-cta__link" href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/everything-you-need-know-about-cholera">Learn more</a>
</div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>At the same time, we started prevention efforts. We installed additional handwashing stations and educated the public about the importance of hygiene. Our health promoters went into surrounding communities to explain the early symptoms of cholera and when to seek treatment.&nbsp;</p><p>Cholera is a severe diarrheal illness and diseases like this are especially dangerous for small children. Though treatable, an infection can lead to death within just a few hours if left untreated.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="A mother holds her child after cholera treatment in South Sudan." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB216310.jpg?itok=eOHANJQN" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            Susane with her youngest child, Sunday Gabriel, who was referred to MSF's cholera treatment center, where he was diagnosed with both cholera and malaria and received treatment. <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> South Sudan 2024 ©&nbsp;Paula Casado Aguirregabiria
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Acting fast saves lives</h2><p>The first 72 hours of an epidemic determine whether it can be contained or spirals into a disaster. In the case of the 2023 cholera outbreak, we were able to respond quickly and limit the number of cases to 1,471. After 90 days, on May 16, 2023, intervention concluded as cases had decreased significantly and the outbreak was contained.</p><p>This outbreak once again showed how crucial early diagnosis, isolation, identifying the source of infection, and fast vaccination are. Each of these steps is vital to saving lives.</p><p>We work under extremely difficult conditions in crisis zones, but access to vaccines remains one of our most powerful tool in the fight against epidemics. At the same time, we must not forget that long-term solutions—such as access to clean water—are just as important to prevent future outbreaks.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="content__wrapper">

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : Sudan: Desperation as hundreds of thousands flee Zamzam camp
Published: Fri, 18 Apr 2025 14:43:37 +0000
Summary  :
<span>Sudan: Desperation as hundreds of thousands flee Zamzam camp</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-subtitle field--type-string field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">People are dying of thirst as the Rapid Support Forces wage war in and around Sudan's largest camp for displaced people. </div>
  </div>
<span><span>Leila Rafei</span></span>

<span><time datetime="2025-04-18T10:43:37-04:00" title="Friday, April 18, 2025 - 10:43am">April 18 2025, 10:43am</time>
</span>

  <div class="field field--name-field-hero-image field--type-entity-reference field--label-hidden field__items">
        <div class="field__item">  <img alt="New displacement from Zamzam" height="1500" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB227939.jpg" width="2000" />

</div>
  </div>
      <div class="field field--content-blocks field--label-hidden field__items">
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>About 25,000 more people have reached the town of Tawila, about 40 miles to the west, where overwhelmed teams from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) are expanding activities to cope with the most pressing medical needs. We are making an urgent appeal to put an end to the siege and the atrocities, to allow those who wish to flee to do so safely, and to deliver humanitarian aid, including by airdropping food and medicines to El Fasher if necessary.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>MSF teams treat new arrivals in Tawila</h2><p>After months of an <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/sudan-zamzam-camp-under-shelling-violence-escalates-north-darfur" title="Sudan: Zamzam camp under shelling as violence escalates in North Darfur">increasingly tight siege </a>on the area around Zamzam, RSF and its allied armed groups stormed the camp, which hosted at least 500,000 people and is Sudan’s largest displacement camp. By April 16, the camp had been largely destroyed an was reportedly under RSF control. The majority of Zamzam’s population is believed to have fled to El Fasher, where they remain trapped, out of reach for humanitarian aid and exposed to ongoing attacks and further mass violence.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--blockquote paragraph--view-mode--default quote-icon">
                  	
<div class="blockquote-container blockquote-container--white">
  <div class="blockquote__wrapper">
    <blockquote><p></p><p>We are treating children who were literally dying of thirst on their journeys ... People tell us that many injured and vulnerable people could not make the trip to Tawila and were left behind.”</p><figcaption>Marion Ramstein, MSF project coordinator in Tawila</figcaption></blockquote>
  </div>
</div>
            </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>MSF teams in Tawila saw over 25,000 people arriving from Zamzam and nearby areas between April 12 and 15, but displaced people are now coming more sporadically and at great risk for their lives along the way. Our teams set up a health post at the entrance of Tawila to provide new arrivals with water and immediate <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">nutritional</a> and medical support. We refer critical cases to the local hospital, where we have been working since last October. About 1,600 patients so far have required emergency outpatient services, mainly because of severe dehydration.</p><p>“We are treating children who were literally dying of thirst on their journeys," said Marion Ramstein, MSF project coordinator in Tawila. "We have received so far over 170 people with gunshot and blast injuries and 40 percent of them are women and girls. People tell us that many injured and vulnerable people could not make the trip to Tawila and were left behind. Almost everyone we talk to said they lost at least one family member during the attack.”&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--full-screen-width-image paragraph--view-mode--default">
          
                
        
  
<div class="content__wrapper full-screen__content large-image-wrapper boxed-width-container">

  <figure class="image">
        
                  <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="893" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="1340" />
              <source height="512" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="780" />
              <source height="410" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="550" />
                  <img alt="MSF teams in Tawila saw over 25,000 people arriving from Zamzam and nearby areas between April 12 and 15." height="893" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/large_image_1340_893/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB227940.jpg?itok=lEIgaG4T" width="1340" />

  


      <div class="image__text full-screen__text">
        <span class="image__meta">
          <figcaption class="figcaption__full-width">
            MSF teams set up a health post at the entrance of Tawila to provide new arrivals with water and immediate nutritional and medical support.  <span class="caption-separator"> | </span> Sudan 2025 ©&nbsp;Marion Ramstein/MSF
          </figcaption>
        </span>
      </div>

  </figure>
  </div>
  </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Hundreds dead amid door-to-door killings</h2><p>Horrific reports have emerged from Zamzam camp, where hundreds of people are estimated to have been killed. Fighters were said to be going door-to-door, shooting people hiding in their homes and burning large parts of the camp. Casualties include 11 staff from the humanitarian organization <a href="https://x.com/MSF_USA/status/1911861206492528846">Relief International</a>, which was running the only remaining clinic in the camp after MSF <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/escalation-fighting-forces-msf-halt-operations-sudans-zamzam-camp" title="Escalation in fighting forces MSF to halt operations in Sudan’s Zamzam camp">suspended its activities in Zamzam</a> in February due to the escalating violence and blockade.</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="paragraph paragraph--type--blockquote paragraph--view-mode--default quote-icon">
                  	
<div class="blockquote-container blockquote-container--white">
  <div class="blockquote__wrapper">
    <blockquote><p></p><p>If the roads to El Fasher are blocked, then air operations must be launched to bring food and medicines to the estimated 1 million people trapped there and being starved.&nbsp;</p><figcaption>Rasmane Kabore, MSF head of mission in Sudan</figcaption></blockquote>
  </div>
</div>
            </div>
</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><p>We urge RSF and all armed groups in the area to <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/mass-casualties-sudan-warring-parties-strike-populated-areas" title="Mass casualties in Sudan as warring parties strike populated areas">spare and protect civilians</a> and ensure that those who want to flee can do so without further harm. States and diplomatic actors must use their leverage to translate hollow statements into concrete actions. There have been repeated warnings from the UN and many observers about the risks of mass killings and <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/msf-report-exposes-spiraling-ethnic-violence-against-people-darfur" title="MSF report exposes spiraling ethnic violence against people in Darfur">ethnic violence</a> in El Fasher and the surrounding displacement camps, which are mostly inhabited by people from the non-Arab Zaghawa and Fur ethnic groups, while most of RSF fighters and their allies originate from Arab tribes.&nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">

  



        


  


  



    
  
  <div class="mbt-container bg--dark-gray">
    <div class="mbt-inner-container mbt__media--left">
      <div class="mbt__media-content ">
                  <div class="mbt__image-content">
                
                  <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 1600px)" type="image/jpeg" width="666" />
              <source height="520" media="all and (min-width: 1170px) and (max-width: 1599px)" type="image/jpeg" width="666" />
              <source height="600" media="all and (min-width: 768px) and (max-width: 1169px)" type="image/jpeg" width="768" />
              <source height="375" media="all and (min-width: 480px) and (max-width: 767px)" type="image/jpeg" width="480" />
              <source height="261" media="all and (min-width: 320px) and (max-width: 479px)" type="image/jpeg" width="335" />
                  <img alt="An illustration of a man with a gun pointed at his head. " height="520" src="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sites/default/files/styles/media_besides_text_666_520/public/image_base_media/2025/04/MSB225166.jpg?itok=C2iWzB9n" width="666" />

  

                          <span class="mbt__caption"> Sudan 2025 © Dora Naliesna/MSF </span>
                      </div>
              </div>
      <div class="mbt__text-content">
                <h2 class="heading-2 mbt__text-content__title">Tales of violence and forced displacement from Sudan</h2>
        <div class="class">
          <p class="caption  caption-large mbt__text-content__desc">Hundreds of thousands of people have been forced to flee to the Nuba Mountains region of South Kordofan, where MSF is supporting several hospitals and medical facilities. </p>
        </div>
                
<a class="link-item link-bold mbt__text-content__link link-icon--right-arrow" href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/tales-violence-and-forced-displacement-sudan">Read more</a>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

</div>
              <div class="field__item">            <div class="paragraph__wysiwyg-text">
        <div class="content__wrapper">
    <div class="body-text  "><h2>Sudan needs aid more urgently than ever</h2><p>After <a href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/no-end-sight-sudans-two-years-war" title="No end in sight: Sudan’s two years of war">two years of a catastrophic war on people</a> met by neglectful indifference, it remains inconceivable to simply resign ourselves to the current collective failure to provide vital assistance where it’s most needed.</p><p>“A massive humanitarian response is needed, now more urgently than ever," said Rasmane Kabore, MSF head of mission in Sudan. "If the roads to El Fasher are blocked, then air operations must be launched to bring food and medicines to the estimated 1 million people trapped there and being starved. A scaled-up response is also needed in Tawila, where some of the survivors are being received and local capacities are overwhelmed.”</p><p>MSF and several other organizations are launching emergency interventions in Tawila, but much more is needed in terms of water, food, medical care, and shelter. &nbsp;</p></div>
</div>
      </div>
      </div>
              <div class="field__item">
  <div class="mini-cta">
  <h3 class="heading-3 mini-cta__heading">No end in sight: Sudan’s two years of war</h3>

  
<a class="link-item link-bold link-cta mini-cta__link" href="https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/no-end-sight-sudans-two-years-war">Read more</a>
</div>
</div>
