Title    : Taiwan inks disaster prevention pacts with Japan, Fiji
Published: 2025/04/22
Summary  :
<div class="article-content-part">Taiwan and Japan renewed a memorandum of understanding on disaster prevention technology cooperation April 21 in the Japanese city of Tsukuba, underscoring the two sides&rsquo; commitment to strengthening emergency preparedness.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
According to the Cabinet-level National Science and Technology Council, the pact was signed by Hongey Chen, director of the National Science and Technology Center for Disaster Reduction (NCDR), and Kaoru Takara, president of the Tsukuba-headquartered National Research Institute for Earth Science and Disaster Resilience (NIED).<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Established in 1963, NIED has experimental facilities and observation equipment in locations across Japan. The institute conducts research on earthquakes, floods, meteorology, landslides and volcanoes, as well as formulating disaster response strategies and boosting urban resilience.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Under the MOU, the two sides will promote related technological R&amp;D and risk management, facilitate sharing of technological information and achievements, engage in reciprocal personnel training, collaborate on disaster analysis and alternately host seminars. The agreement was first inked in 2020 and resulted in multiple substantive projects.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Speaking at the signing ceremony, Chen noted that Taiwan and Japan have similar geography and disaster risks and that it is key to enhance mutual societal security. In response, Takara expressed hope of continuing to deepen bilateral dialogue on preparedness policies.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The same day Hsiao Huan-chang, director-general of the Ministry of the Interior&rsquo;s National Fire Agency, inked an MOU with Puamau Sowane, CEO of Fiji&rsquo;s National Fire Authority, according to the MOI. An eight-day training course, underway through April 29, was also launched to enhance the Pacific island country&rsquo;s emergency medical services.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
At the event, Hsiao pledged to expand technological exchanges with Indo-Pacific countries to advance regional disaster relief capabilities. (POC-E)<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Write to Taiwan Today at&nbsp;<a href="mailto:ttonline@mofa.gov.tw">ttonline@mofa.gov.tw</a><br />
&nbsp;</div>

Summary  :
<div class="article-content-part">The Taiwan Trade and Investment Service Center in Fukuoka was inaugurated by the Ministry of Economic Affairs April 21 in the Japanese city, marking another milestone in the already robust bilateral trade relations.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
According to the MOEA, Taiwan is a global front-runner in advanced semiconductor manufacturing and artificial intelligence hardware production, while Japan is a powerhouse in materials, equipment and quality management expertise.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The ministry said the Kyushu region is often seen as Japan&rsquo;s semiconductor hub, while Fukuoka is the region&rsquo;s economic center. The newly launched center is expected to serve as a key platform to channel resources and provide services such as investment consultation, business matching, technical exchanges and market development to both sides.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
During her opening remarks, Deputy Economic Minister Cynthia Kiang said Taiwan and Japan are like-minded partners with complementary industries. The trade center will help promote even stronger cooperation between the two countries to boost growth momentum for the Asia-Pacific value chain and explore more win-win opportunities in other markets, she added.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The center is the second established under the ministry&rsquo;s Pursuing Global Opportunities With Domestic Supply strategy announced by Minister Kuo Jyh-huei, following one that opened in the Czech Republic in December 2024.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The launch event was attended by more than 200 officials, political figures and business representatives from the two sides. These included Taiwan External Trade Development Council Chair James C.F. Huang, Fukuoka Gov. Seitaro Hattori, Saga Gov. Yoshinori Yamaguchi and Kagoshima Gov. Kōichi Shiota. (SFC-E)<br />

Title    : Palauan sailing boat en route to Taiwan
Published: 2025/04/22
Summary  :
<div class="article-content-part">A Palauan sailing boat named Alingano Maisu is en route to Taitung County in eastern Taiwan as part of an Austronesian cultural seafaring exchange activity organized by Taitung County Government and Palau&rsquo;s Micronesian Voyaging Society, with the support of the Ocean Affairs Council, the latter said April 21.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
According to the OAC, departing Palau April 20, the Polynesian vessel uses traditional navigation and will pass islands off the Philippines and Batan Islands and expects to berth at Taiwan&rsquo;s Orchid Island off Taiwan&rsquo;s southeastern coast on May 8. After meeting and chatting with local Indigenous Tao people, the 10-crew members, including Syaman Manazang from Taiwan, will set off again and arrive at Taitung&rsquo;s Fudafudak tribal village May 10.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The council said the boat will be companied by two ten-people Tao vessels when arriving at Orchid Island and will be welcomed by the Indigenous Amis on Taitung&rsquo;s coast. Elders of the two tribes will pray for blessings for the venture, it added.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Named by late leading navigator Mau Piailug, encompassing the meaning of selfless sharing and we are from the same island, Alingano Maisu is an 18-year-old single-masted boat, with a hull length of 17 meters and a deck width of 5 meters.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
In addition to the Austronesian seafaring cultural exchange, Taitung County government also launched a project to cultivate personnel in Indigenous peoples&rsquo; traditional shipbuilding and navigation skills to echo the OAC initiative on revitalizing maritime cultures, the council said.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The initiative aims to raise public awareness of maritime knowledge, promote shipbuilding and navigation techniques and promote related arts and cultural creative forms the OAC said, adding that it is committed to working with local governments, civil organizations, educational facilities and museums to enrich the country&rsquo;s inheritance and development of marine culture. (YCH-E)<br />
&nbsp;<br />

&nbsp;<br />
Named &ldquo;Crossing Realms: A Gender and Light Journey in the Metaverse,&rdquo; the exhibition runs through May 11 and combines light projections and immersive experiences to explore diverse perspectives on the relationship between gender and art, family, science, sports and other topics.<br />

&nbsp;<br />
The gender and sports section displays outstanding performances of Taiwan female athletes like Chi Cheng, who was a 1968 Olympic medalist in track and field, while the gender and arts section presents award-winning films from home and abroad that tell stories of protagonists that break through traditional stereotypes.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
A series of activities will be held on weekends, including magic shows and introductions to ballroom culture, picture books on body boundaries and sexual violence prevention, the MOE said.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
According to the ministry, Taiwan committed to the goal of gender equality. It cited the Gender Equity Education Act as evidence, saying that it has been revised five times following its passage in 2004 to further align with societal developments and updated practices. The MOE further designated April 20 as Gender Equality Education Day in 2023 to expand the implementation of gender equality in schools, it added. (YCH-E)<br />

Title    : OAC welcomes Japan delegation
Published: 2025/04/18
Summary  :
<div class="article-content-part">The Cabinet-level Ocean Affairs Council received a Japanese delegation April 16 in southern Taiwan&rsquo;s Kaohsiung City, highlighting commitment to jointly developing the blue carbon economy.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Welcomed by OAC Deputy Minister Huang Hsiang-wen, the group comprised Yokohama City Council members Hirotaka Mori and Shuhei Takada, as well as Kanagawa Prefectural Assembly members Akihito Sugahara and Manabu Morita.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Taiwan and Japan face similar climate change and sustainable utilization of marine resources challenges, Huang said. She added that Taiwan is actively promoting marine carbon sinks and has included the goal in the country&rsquo;s pathway to net-zero emissions in 2050.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Huang noted that the OAC has completed blue carbon sink methodology for mangrove and seagrass beds, and expressed hope that after review by the Ministry of the Environment the methodology will be incorporated into the National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Report and the carbon credit verification mechanism.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Mori said the delegation&rsquo;s visit aims to share Japan&rsquo;s successful experience of blue carbon sinks and undertake exchange with businesses on relevant technology. The council added that they both agreed that the key to success in marine ecological protection and restoration is local stakeholders&rsquo; confidence and trust in decision making.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The OAC added that Huang attended the 12th annual World Ocean Summit and Expo held last month in Tokyo, sharing Taiwan policy on plastic restriction and an initiative to set up an Indo-Pacific waste management cooperation platform with representatives from over 10 countries. In addition, the OAC has worked with Japan on handling marine waste management, having signed a cooperative memorandum with the Japan Ministry of the Environment in 2023.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
The OAC is committed to strengthening collaboration with Japanese authorities in sectors including further carbon sinks, protection of marine biodiversity, the blue economy and ecological rehabilitation. (YCH-E)<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Write to Taiwan Today at <a href="mailto:ttonline@mofa.gov.tw">ttonline@mofa.gov.tw</a></div>

&nbsp;<br />
During their stay, members of the group will attend performances at the Taiwan International Festival of Arts running through May 18 and share their observations of Taiwan&rsquo;s art landscape. They will also take part in the Observers Forum set for April 19 in Taipei City.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
Organized by Taipei-based Taiwan Contemporary Culture Lab, the Observers Forum brings arts critics with diverse national backgrounds to exchange perspectives and share experiences of the multifaceted nature of contemporary arts and culture.<br />
&nbsp;<br />
During the forum&rsquo;s first session, six of the visiting guests will shed light on the contemporary landscape of arts and cultural criticism in Southeast Asia, while in the second, critics and writers from Taiwan will focus closely on the ecosystem of art and cultural criticism at home. Summary  :
<figure><img alt="" class="attachment-rss-image-size size-rss-image-size wp-post-image" height="640" src="https://i0.wp.com/asiatimes.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/Trade-Ships-Shipping.jpg?fit=1024%2C640&amp;quality=89&amp;ssl=1" width="1024" /></figure>
<p>TOKYO – The sudden downshift in South Korea&#8217;s exports leaves little doubt about the extent to which Asia is in harm&#8217;s way amid Donald Trump’s tariff tantrum.<br />
 <br />
In the first 20 days of April, South Korea’s overseas shipments fell 5.2% year on year — the mirror image of the 5.5% rise for the full month of March. US-bound exports plunged by 14.3% in the first 20 days of April.</p>
<p>It’s an early glimpse of the collateral damage to come as the most protectionist US president in more than a century rocks Asia’s export-reliant economies. And it could be an omen of greater-than-feared pain to come.</p>

Title    : MP: Council of Europe and ICC unlikely to bring Russia’s leaders to justice
Published: Wed, 23 Apr 2025 20:05:00 +0000
Summary  :
<p><img alt="" class="attachment-thumbnail size-thumbnail" height="107" src="https://uatv.ua/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/Mariia-Mezentseva-Fedorenko-222x107.jpg" width="222" /></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>The Council of Europe and the International Criminal Court will not be able to bring Russia's top military and political leadership to justice for the crime of aggression against Ukraine.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>This was reported by Mariia Mezentseva-Fedorenko, MP, head of the Ukrainian delegation to PACE, in the program of Ihor Dolhov on the&nbsp;<a href="http://youtu.be/c3k8h-5KkNM?si=Tr20sLwxsUj3HAIT" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank">Ukrinform YouTube channel</a>.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>“The Council of Europe is an international organization that has recently celebrated 75 years of activity, but it is still not a court. And it is not an international court, such as the International Criminal Court, which operates in the Netherlands. Although it would not be able to bring the top political and military leadership of the Russian Federation to justice either. There are very specific legal reasons for this,” she noted.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>The MP recalled that last year the Verkhovna Rada ratified the Rome Statute, thus Ukraine entered into “absolutely legal, legitimate relations with a body where the crime of aggression can be considered.”</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>“But Russia will not shoot itself in the foot and will not implement such ratification,” she explained.</p>
<p>According to her, the UN court, which was a potential platform for justice for Russian criminals, is not currently being considered either.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>The parliamentarian explained that it is precisely because of the inability to bring the Russian leadership to justice for the crime of aggression by existing bodies and institutions that the need to create an international tribunal arose.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>The post <a href="https://uatv.ua/en/mp-council-of-europe-and-icc-unlikely-to-bring-russia-s-leaders-to-justice/">MP: Council of Europe and ICC unlikely to bring Russia&#8217;s leaders to justice</a> appeared first on <a href="https://uatv.ua/en/">Freedom</a>.</p>

Title    : Russians preparing to intensify assault operations along entire southern frontline – military spox
Published: Wed, 23 Apr 2025 18:05:00 +0000
Summary  :
<p><img alt="" class="attachment-thumbnail size-thumbnail" height="127" src="https://uatv.ua/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/630_360_1743930365-571-222x127.jpg" width="222" /></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>Taking advantage of a ceasefire, the enemy has transferred equipment and personnel from Crimea to Zaporizhzhia region. Ukraine’s Defense Forces expect intensified assault operations by Russian troops along the entire southern frontline.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>This was reported in a comment to <a href="https://www.ukrinform.net/rubric-ato/3985072-russians-preparing-to-intensify-assault-operations-along-entire-southern-frontline-military-spox.html">Ukrinform</a> by Vladyslav Voloshyn, Spokesperson for the Southern Defense Forces.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>"In Zaporizhzhia region — specifically Huliaipole, Novopavlivka, and Orikhiv sectors — the enemy continues active assault operations, especially in the Novopavlivka sector, where they are advancing toward Pryvilne and Vilne Pole. There were 17 assault attempts in that area over the past day. The enemy is also quite active in the Orikhiv sector, carrying out assaults toward Mali Shcherbaky, Stepove, and Lepkove. So indeed, taking advantage of the so-called ‘Easter ceasefire’ and halt in shelling, the enemy regrouped their forces, moved personnel from assault units, their weapons, and military equipment to frontline positions, and continues to conduct assaults in small infantry groups," Voloshyn said.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>When asked whether the enemy is concentrating fresh forces only in Zaporizhzhia direction, the Spokesperson said it concerns all southern directions.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>"According to our intelligence, the enemy is regrouping and redeploying a certain amount of forces and resources from both Crimea and Russia to continue assault operations. We are recording an increase in the amount of weaponry, military equipment, and assault units across all southern sectors of the front — especially in the areas of Huliaipole, Novopavlivka, and Orikhiv. We also observe a buildup of these assault units in the Prydniprovske sector, near the settlement of Oleshky. Therefore, we do not rule out intensified assault operations in Zaporizhzhia region itself, as well as increased enemy activity in Kherson direction. The enemy is currently accumulating forces and resources, conducting logistical preparations, and constantly carrying out reconnaissance," Voloshyn said.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>At the same time, Voloshyn noted that while the Russian invaders do not yet have sufficient forces for a full-scale offensive, they do have enough to conduct assault operations in small infantry groups with the support of combat vehicles.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>A particular role in supplying the enemy’s assault groups is now played by light motorized vehicles.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>"According to our intelligence, light motorized vehicles — such as motorcycles, buggies, and quad bikes — are now playing a key role. The enemy has recently started actively using them in assault operations. These vehicles can move quickly through fields, are highly maneuverable, and are difficult to target or destroy using both conventional fire and FPV drones. That’s why the enemy has increasingly turned to using them," the Spokesperson explained.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>He noted that Ukrainian defenders destroy around 20 motorcycles and 5–7 buggies and quad bikes every day.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>As reported by Ukrinform, over the past 24 hours, the occupiers carried out 359 strikes on 13 settlements in Zaporizhzhia region. One person was killed and 40 others were injured in an attack on Zaporizhzhia.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>The post <a href="https://uatv.ua/en/russians-preparing-to-intensify-assault-operations-along-entire-southern-frontline-military-spox/">Russians preparing to intensify assault operations along entire southern frontline – military spox</a> appeared first on <a href="https://uatv.ua/en/">Freedom</a>.</p>

Title    : Council of Europe expects up to 6M claims to Damage Register from Ukrainians – MP
Published: Wed, 23 Apr 2025 17:06:00 +0000
Summary  :
<p><img alt="" class="attachment-thumbnail size-thumbnail" height="127" src="https://uatv.ua/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/630_360_1541761461-849-222x127.jpg" width="222" /></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>The Council of Europe anticipates up to 6 million claims to the Damage Register from Ukrainians affected by Russian aggression.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>This was announced by Member of Parliament and head of the Ukrainian delegation to the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe (PACE), Maria Mezentseva-Fedorenko, in a program hosted by Ihor Dolhov on&nbsp;<a href="http://youtu.be/c3k8h-5KkNM?si=Tr20sLwxsUj3HAIT" rel="noreferrer noopener" target="_blank">Ukrinform’s YouTube channel</a>.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>“It’s important that accountability for aggression is now directly and practically linked to something every Ukrainian can do on their phone today. Applications for compensation in nine categories — covering both material and non-material losses — can be submitted through the Diia app,” Mezentseva said.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>According to her, a European Commission team from the Damage Register has recently arrived in Kyiv, and an official office has been opened in Ukraine to offer consultations to victims.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>“Not everyone knows that even if you have already received compensation from the state, you can still submit an application to the Register. These are two separate processes that do not overlap. You can also submit claims to the Register if your situation falls under several categories or even all of them,” Mezentseva-Fedorenko added.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>So far, over 20,000 claims have been submitted by Ukrainians to the Damage Register. However, Council of Europe officials have projected up to 6 million claims.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>“We must ensure the capacity of this process and not disappoint our citizens. Funding remains a key issue,” Mezentseva noted.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>As Ukrinform previously reported, the Council of Europe and the International Criminal Court (ICC) are unable to hold Russia’s top military-political leadership accountable for the crime of aggression against Ukraine under their current jurisdictions.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>

<p>“As you know, we remain absolutely committed to bringing a just and lasting peace to Ukraine, and today's talks are an important part of that,” he said.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>As reported by Ukrinform, the head of the Presidential Office, Andriy Yermak, Defense Minister Rustem Umerov and Foreign Minister Andriy Sybiha arrived in London on Wednesday, where talks are scheduled between representatives of the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Ukraine.</p>
<p>They will discuss ways to achieve a full and unconditional ceasefire as a first step towards a full-fledged settlement process and a just and sustainable peace.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>The American side was to be represented by Secretary of State Marco Rubio, as well as President Donald Trump's special representatives Steve Witkoff and Keith Kellogg. However, State Department spokeswoman Tammy Bruce said on Tuesday that Rubio would not attend the meeting in London.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>The British Foreign Office confirmed that peace talks to resolve Russia's war against Ukraine at the level of the foreign ministers of Britain, the United States, France, Germany and Ukraine, which were to take place on Wednesday, have been postponed.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>Sibiga and Umerov began a meeting with their British counterparts David Lammy and John Healey.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>

Title    : France: Europe will demand respect for Ukraine’s territorial integrity in any peace deal
Published: Wed, 23 Apr 2025 14:36:00 +0000
Summary  :
<p><img alt="" class="attachment-thumbnail size-thumbnail" height="149" src="https://uatv.ua/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/gettyimages-521854066-612x612-1-222x149.jpg" width="222" /></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>France says that European countries believe that any peace agreement to end the war unleashed by Russia must include respect for Ukraine's territorial integrity.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>This was stated in a comment to <a href="https://www.afp.com/">AFP</a> by the office of French President Emmanuel Macron.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>This comment came as US Vice President J.D. Vance stated that both Ukraine and Russia would have to “give up some of the territory they currently possess.”</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>“The territorial integrity of Ukraine and its European aspirations are very strong demands for the Europeans,” Macron's office emphasized.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>The US, according to media reports, is ready to recognize Russia's control over Ukrainian Crimea and ease sanctions against Moscow as part of a potential peace deal.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>On Tuesday, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said that Ukraine does not recognize Russia's occupation of Crimea, which is internationally recognized as Ukrainian territory.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>
<p>It was expected that on April 23, negotiations on a peaceful settlement would be held in London at the level of the foreign ministers of the five states. However, it later became known that the meetings were held at the level of high-level officials.</p>

Title    : Trump’s Approval Rating Falls in the U.S.
Published: Wed, 23 Apr 2025 14:03:00 +0000
Summary  :
<p><img alt="" class="attachment-thumbnail size-thumbnail" height="128" src="https://uatv.ua/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/4277-222x128.jpg" width="222" /></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>U.S. President Donald Trump's approval rating has dropped to its lowest level since his return to the White House.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>This is according to a <a href="https://www.reuters.com/world/us/trump-approval-rating-dips-many-wary-his-wielding-power-reutersipsos-poll-finds-2025-04-21/?fbclid=IwY2xjawJz98pleHRuA2FlbQIxMAABHvrNcVwvFjSoZlX_GZ94Q8qFzDa3UGbRDPEUMIyma7zgldnmGlJ1JVtylgGI_aem_cMyoufWrprBIO3ZKPNDMtw">Reuters/Ipsos</a> poll.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>About 42% of respondents in the six-day survey approved of Trump’s performance as president. Three weeks ago, the same poll showed 43%, and right after Trump’s inauguration in January, the figure stood at 47%.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>The beginning of Trump’s new term shocked his political opponents, as he signed dozens of executive orders expanding his influence over both government agencies and private institutions such as universities and law firms.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>Although Trump’s rating remains higher than during most of Democratic predecessor Joe Biden’s presidency, the Reuters/Ipsos poll indicates that many Americans are dissatisfied with his actions.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>About 83% of the 4,306 respondents said that the U.S. president must comply with federal court decisions, even if he disagrees with them.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>57% disagreed with the statement that “it’s okay for a U.S. president to cut off funding to universities if he disagrees with how they are run.”</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>66% do not believe the president should control leading cultural institutions such as national museums and theaters.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>The poll showed that on a range of issues—from inflation and immigration to taxation and the rule of law—more Americans disapprove of Trump’s performance than approve, on every single topic covered.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>Regarding immigration, his strongest area of support, 45% approved of Trump’s performance, while 46% disapproved.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>About 59% of respondents, including a third of Republicans, said that America is losing credibility on the global stage. The poll has a margin of error of about 2 percentage points.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph {"className":""} --></p>
<p>Meanwhile, recently published results from a Gallup poll showed that Trump’s approval rating in the first quarter of his second term was 45%—higher than for the same period during his first term.</p>
<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>
<p><!-- wp:paragraph --></p>

<p><!-- /wp:paragraph --></p>

Title    : Russia slaps Telegram with another multi-million-ruble fine for refusing to take down ‘prohibited content’
Published: Mon, 21 Apr 2025 20:07:52 +0300
Summary  :
<p>A Moscow court has fined the messaging service Telegram 4 million rubles (almost $50,000) for refusing to remove content prohibited under Russian law, according to the news outlet RBC. Officials didn’t specify what materials Telegram refused to censor. Since the start of the full-scale invasion of Ukraine, Russia has added numerous war-related speech offenses to its already long list of illegal online content. <p>

Title    : 'He kissed up well'. Artyom Zhoga was supposed to embody Putin’s new model of veterans in high places. So far, his performance has fallen flat.
Published: Mon, 21 Apr 2025 18:59:55 +0300
Summary  :
<p>In his February 2024 address to Russia’s Federal Assembly, Vladimir Putin called for veterans of the war in Ukraine to become the country’s “new elites” and to hold “leading positions” in government. In the approximately 14 months since then, this initiative has brought few success stories — though not for lack of trying. One of the most visible of these “new elites” is Artyom Zhoga, a former commander of the pro-Russian separatist Sparta Battalion in Ukraine’s Donetsk region who's spent the last six months serving as Putin’s official envoy to the Ural Federal District. In 2023, Zhoga publicly asked Putin to run for a fifth term, playing a key role in the president’s campaign announcement and raising his own profile. Since his big promotion, however, he's largely failed to become a full-fledged official; he currently spends most of his time meeting with soldiers and defense industry workers, attending ceremonies and celebrations, and making appearances at sporting events. Meduza special correspondent Andrey Pertsev explains why no one's holding their breath for Zhoga to start making his own political decisions.<p>

Title    : 'Wiping out neighborhood after neighborhood'. Russia pounds Ukraine's Pokrovsk, forcing civilians to flee under fire. For many, it's not the first time.
Published: Mon, 21 Apr 2025 16:26:58 +0300
Summary  :
<p>Russian forces are continuing their offensive near Pokrovsk in Ukraine’s Donetsk region. In its Monday morning update, Ukraine’s General Staff reported that Russian troops had launched 39 attacks on the Pokrovsk front over the previous 24 hours — more than on any other section of the frontline. As Meduza reported in early April, Russia has redeployed significant forces from the Toretsk area to Pokrovsk, a shift that allowed Ukrainian troops to regain control over part of Toretsk’s city center and its western outskirts. Meanwhile, Pokrovsk remains under constant assault from Russian drones, artillery, and bombing. “KAB [guided bombs] are wiping out neighborhood after neighborhood — 30 to 60 strikes a day,” said Ukrainian photographer Kostiantyn Liberov, who visited Pokrovsk in the first half of April. According to a Ukrainian military lieutenant with the callsign “Aleks” who spoke to the news agency UNIAN, Russian forces have not managed to capture Pokrovsk, but the city is “basically being torn to pieces.” “With this level of fighting, unfortunately, Pokrovsk is headed for the same fate as Bakhmut,” he said. Pokrovsk currently serves as Ukraine’s main logistical hub for its forces in central Donbas. It’s also a base for Ukrainian drone operators, who have managed to slow Russia’s advance towards the city for several months. According to Forbes correspondent David Axe, Russian troops met a “wall of drones” when they reached the city's suburbs. Below, Meduza shares photographs taken in Pokrovsk on April 12. The strikes have continued daily since then (though their intensity waned briefly during the "Easter truce").<p>

Title    : Statement on ISW Methodology
Published: Fri, 05 May 2023 01:23:40 +0000
Summary  :
<div class="field field-name-field-cover-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img alt="" height="125" src="https://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/styles/square_thumbnail/public/ISW%20LOGO%202_153.jpg?itok=kxannOZ8" width="125" /></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p align="center" style="text-align: left;"><strong>Statement on ISW Methodology</strong></p>
<p align="center" style="text-align: left;"><strong>May 4, 2023</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: left;">The Institute for the Study of War (ISW) welcomes robust and rigorous debate on the issues ISW covers and is especially grateful for the interaction with and feedback from those who engage seriously with the methodological challenges of performing intelligence from publicly available information. ISW’s entire team shares a passion for sound tradecraft and a desire to engage openly regarding our methodology, including our analytic and forecasting successes as well as our limitations. We seek to raise the general level of discussion of national security and especially military issues and are grateful for the aid of all who contribute to that effort.</p>
<p>A few key takeaways regarding ISW’s approach can help inform readers about ISW’s work and establish constructive topics for engagement:</p>
<ul><li>ISW applies rigorous intelligence tradecraft that reflects best practices drawn from the US intelligence community. ISW uses technical language from the military and intelligence community in its products in order to maintain the rigor of its tradecraft and communicate with the greatest possible precision.</li>
<li>ISW’s extensive, daily collection and analysis provides a highly tested baseline of existing patterns, enabling relatively fast identification of anomalies and inflections. ISW’s ability to make a judgment on a given piece of data is informed by its months of prior study.</li>
<li>ISW has applied its proven methodology for analyzing conflicts for over 15 years. ISW’s Ukraine work applies the same tradecraft ISW has used to analyze and map other wars, including ISW’s extensive coverage of the war against ISIS in Iraq and Syria.</li>
<li>ISW is fully independent of the US and foreign governments, takes no money from these entities, and is committed to its independence as a key source of objectivity.</li>
<li>ISW aims to inform, not convince, audiences and makes available the sourcing of each product to ensure readers can engage directly with the underlying data and form their own conclusions, especially amidst disinformation campaigns. ISW uses no classified or privileged information in its products.</li>
<li>ISW analysts interpret available data to form assessments – they do not simply report facts. ISW explicitly states its specific confidence level in each assessment whenever applicable and encourages our readers to include it when reporting our assessments in order to minimize the risk of misinterpretation. ISW will publish low-confidence assessments if its analysts judge the issue being assessed to be sufficiently important, timely, or risky to warrant a flag even as ISW continues to evaluate new information.</li>
<li>ISW innovates new ways of collecting, analyzing, and visualizing public data. ISW established a new geospatial program to scale its mapping effort after the Russian invasion and to drive mapping innovation, which was generously enabled by the Dr. Jack London Geospatial Fund.</li>
</ul><p>ISW is committed to providing accurate, granular, and timely intelligence from open sources on threats to US national security interests, including Russia’s brutal invasion of Ukraine. The purpose of ISW’s work is to inform US and allied decision-makers and to educate public audiences regarding these threats. ISW products help to visualize and explain fast-moving conflicts as well as to interpret their trajectory and significance.<strong> ISW’s publication series on the war in Ukraine is an exemplar of ISW’s institutional values and methodology. As such, it is a useful means of understanding ISW’s approach to intelligence analysis.</strong></p>
<p>ISW applies industry-leading tradecraft. ISW’s analytic program trains and applies intelligence methodology that emphasizes source evaluation and characterization, structured analytical techniques, and other foundational principles. Retired members of the intelligence community have informed this tradecraft over many years and ISW welcomes engagement with current intelligence experts regarding ISW’s methodologies. ISW extends this tradecraft into its written product. ISW uses military and intelligence technical language and concepts with precision not only to communicate within a framework that US and allied governments can easily interpret but also, more importantly, to maintain the rigor and discipline of ISW’s analysis even in external communication.</p>
<p><strong>Independence and transparency are core ISW values and are applied to all ISW products.</strong> ISW accepts no US or foreign government money and uses no classified material from any source to produce our analysis. ISW’s independence is a critical enabler of its objectivity. ISW also aims to demonstrate what is possible to achieve in the public domain through the careful application of rigorous tradecraft, even though it is often more difficult than alternative methods. The proven utility of ISW’s products to US and allied governments demonstrates the value of ISW’s approach. ISW’s analytic program is attractive to both aspiring and former members of the intelligence community for this reason.</p>
<p><strong>ISW’s commitment to informing audiences – not convincing them – is demonstrated by ISW’s extensive sharing of its sourcing.</strong> ISW makes available extensive footnotes detailing the evidence used to inform each assessment and has done so for Ukraine since Russia’s current invasion began in February 2022. The investment in this level of evidence-sharing reflects ISW’s commitment to ensuring that readers can form their own judgments on the basis of the evidence and ISW’s reasoning and do not need to take ISW’s word for anything. ISW also analyzes the various information operations directed at and interacting with the war in Ukraine and makes its sourcing available to provide transparency into ISW’s own conclusions.</p>
<p><strong>ISW is not a news organization, however.</strong> <strong>ISW products do not simply report facts but rather <span style="text-decoration: underline;">interpret</span> available data to form assessments regarding what is occurring, has occurred, and could occur and the implications.</strong> Understanding the distinction between fact and assessment is critical for responsibly using ISW products. Assessments can be wrong. In fact, if an analyst is never wrong it is typically a sign that the analyst is doing more reporting than assessing. ISW analysts make calls about what they are seeing and its significance on the basis of data which is invariably incomplete and often contradictory. That data includes but is not limited to the data layers behind ISW’s Ukraine map. ISW analysts also form and continually revise strategic assessments of key actors’ intent, decision-making, capacity, and other factors. This holistic approach is intensive and comprises an analytic backend that is less visible than ISW’s maps but no less vital. ISW’s assessments are sometimes wrong, of course. Whenever ISW concludes that it has made a mistake it publishes a formal correction.</p>
<p>Moreover, analytically sound mapping of war itself requires more than mere data aggregation, as maps are also analytic judgments in visual form. More information on ISW’s mapping methodology is available <a href="https://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Cartographical%20Methodology%20Explanation%20ISW%20CTP%202022.pdf">here</a>.</p>
<p><strong>ISW explicitly states its specific confidence level whenever applicable and encourages our readers to include it when reporting our assessments in order to minimize the risk of misinterpretation.</strong> ISW does not refrain from publishing low-confidence assessments, which often distinguishes ISW from other organizations. Instead, ISW will publish at low confidence if its analysts judge the issue being assessed to be sufficiently important, timely, or risky to warrant a flag, which ISW then caveats as necessary and then re-evaluates as new information emerges. This practice enables early warning that provides a valuable means of scoping the aperture of decision-makers even as the situation develops. It is particularly important amidst highly contested information environments like the one in Ukraine.</p>
<p>ISW’s diligence in performing daily analysis of the available data regarding the war in Ukraine is a powerful enabler of ISW’s accuracy. ISW’s teams maintain a constant stare at not only the battlespace but also the information environment. This approach often enables analysts to make relatively fast judgments of new information based on the established patterns ISW monitors closely. It also enables rapid detection of change, anomalies, and inflections which is a key marker of ISW’s unique success in understanding and explaining the war in Ukraine and other conflicts. It has been a critical enabler of ISW’s forecasting accuracy for many years. For example, ISW <a href="https://www.iswresearch.org/2013/11/further-indications-of-al-qaedas.html">warned</a> that ISIS would attempt to seize territorial control in Iraq and that Mosul was vulnerable seven months before ISIS launched its blitz offensive in June 2014. </p>
<p><strong>ISW has applied this proven methodology for analyzing conflicts for over 15 years.</strong> ISW products, including detailed maps, have consistently been utilized by decision-makers and news organizations covering fast-moving and complex national security challenges because of their accuracy and consistency. ISW’s maps of ISIS control in Iraq and Syria provided the leading source of insight and visualization of the war against ISIS after Mosul’s fall and were broadcast widely by international media organizations and leveraged <a href="https://twitter.com/CENTCOM/status/852957314990649345?lang=en">directly</a> by US Central Command in public communications to explain the status of the fight. ISW has extensively mapped the war in Syria, produced detailed maps of the war in Afghanistan at key stages, and has mapped the fight in Ukraine in various ways since the Russians first invaded in 2014. </p>
<p><strong>ISW continues to innovate new ways of collecting, analyzing, and visualizing public data in order to answer intelligence questions that provide US and allied decision-makers with timely and reliable information.</strong> New social media platforms, commercially available data, censorship and disinformation efforts, automation tools and other software all pose new and interesting analytic challenges and opportunities for studying conflict. ISW routinely grapples with these and other opportunities to enhance our tradecraft and reach new insight.</p>
<p><strong>ISW scaled up its mapping effort to meet the demands posed by the Ukraine war in 2022 and established a new geospatial program at ISW, generously enabled by the Dr. Jack London Geospatial Fund.</strong> ISW’s Geospatial team is now a discrete entity that works in support of ISW’s analytic team, providing granular tracking and visualization of the war that informs the assessments ISW analysts produce. This configuration – a mapping team in support of an analytic team – represents a consolidation of ISW’s traditional approach to analyzing conflicts and will enable ISW to continue to achieve greater scale by applying this tradecraft to new portfolios, including China. It also enables ISW’s ongoing innovation of new mapping approaches.</p>
<p>ISW is extraordinarily proud of what its dedicated team has achieved in covering the war in Ukraine for over 430 days. ISW remains grateful to every reader as well as to our generous supporters who enable our work. We also appreciate the hard work of the many other responsible organizations and experts who are adding important insights to the public debate and discussion. ISW’s teams are available, as ever, for inquiries into ISW’s methodology or regarding its products and can be reached via <a href="mailto:press@understandingwar.org">press@understandingwar.org</a>. </p>
</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-pushtofront field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://www.understandingwar.org/latest-isw-front/promote">Promote</a></div></div></div>

Title    : ISIS Campaign to Escape Detention in Syria and Iraq
Published: Fri, 04 Oct 2019 21:01:22 +0000
Summary  :
<div class="field field-name-field-cover-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img alt="" height="125" src="https://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/styles/square_thumbnail/public/ISIS%20Prepares%20for%20Breakout%20-%20V5.png?itok=hPLgDGQz" width="125" /></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p style="font-size: 13.008px;"><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">By John Dunford and Brandon Wallace </span></p>
<div align="justify"><em><strong>Key Takeaway:</strong> ISIS has mounted low-level efforts to <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2019/10/isiss-campaign-to-escape-detention-in.html" target="_blank">replenish</a><a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2019/10/isiss-campaign-to-escape-detention-in.html" target="_blank"> </a>its ranks from members held in detention facilities and displacement camps across Syria and Iraq since late 2018. Some ISIS members have paid bribes to guards in order to buy their freedom. Others have rioted or mounted small-scale escapes attempts from at least four detention facilities in Syria and Iraq since September 2018. ISIS is likely <a href="http://www.understandingwar.org/report/isiss-second-comeback-assessing-next-isis-insurgency" target="_blank">preparing</a><a href="http://www.understandingwar.org/report/isiss-second-comeback-assessing-next-isis-insurgency" target="_blank"> </a>more coordinated and sophisticated operations to free its detained members in Iraq and Syria. The largest risk likely faces the network of makeshift detention facilities spread across <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2019/05/isiss-opportunity-in-northern-syrias.html" target="_blank">Northern Syria</a>. </em></div>

Title    : ISIS Reasserts Global Reach for Ramadan 2019
Published: Wed, 01 May 2019 20:31:06 +0000
Summary  :
<div class="field field-name-field-cover-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img alt="" height="125" src="https://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/styles/square_thumbnail/public/ISIS%20Ramadan%20Chart1.jpg?itok=riApywYl" width="125" /></div></div></div><!--

    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item even"><a href="https://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/ISIS%20Ramadan%20Chart.pdf"><img src="https://www.understandingwar.org/modules/file/icons/application-pdf.png" style="float: left;" />Download the PDF</a></div>

<div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><em><br /></em></strong></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><em>Key Takeaway:</em></strong><em> ISIS has orchestrated an annual campaign of intensified attacks around the Islamic holy month of Ramadan since 2012, first in Iraq and then globally. It has sustained this recurring surge in its global operations every year despite its concurrent territorial losses in Iraq and Syria. ISIS’s latest Ramadan campaign began in late April 2019, two weeks before the start of Ramadan on May 5. ISIS has thus far declared a new province in Central Africa, conducted a devastating attack in Sri Lanka on Easter Sunday, and launched rare attacks in Saudi Arabia and Bangladesh. ISIS Emir Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi also released his first video statement since his declaration of the Caliphate in 2014, emphasizing his survival, foreshadowing upcoming campaigns, and shaping the future trajectory of ISIS. ISIS is likely to continue demonstrating its global reach by conducting additional major attacks during this upcoming Ramadan in order to offset its loss of core terrain and maintain its image as the world’s deadliest terror organization.</em></p>
<p align="center" style="text-align: left;"><em>By Brandon Wallace with Jennifer Cafarella</em></p>
<p style="text-align: left;"><em><strong>Read the full assessment <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2019/05/isis-reasserts-global-reach-for-ramadan.html" target="_blank">here</a>.</strong><br /></em></p>

Title    : Turkey and Russia Prepared to Launch Joint Military Patrols in Syria’s Idlib

<div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong>Key Takeaway: </strong>Growing Turkish-Russian military cooperation in Syria is a dangerous sign of a wider <a href="http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkey-russia-hold-joint-naval-drill-in-black-sea-141754">shift</a> to a <a href="http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkey-buying-russian-s-400s-a-done-deal-erdogan-141708">closer</a> strategic relationship between Turkey and Russia. Russia gave Turkey permission to fly air sorties into Northern Syria as part of an agreement for <a href="https://www.dailysabah.com/war-on-terror/2019/03/08/turkey-russia-patrols-in-syrias-idlib-will-be-important-step-for-lasting-ceasefire-minister-says">joint military patrols</a> along the frontlines in Greater Idlib Province. The Turkish Armed Forces <a href="https://www.trthaber.com/haber/turkiye/tel-tokanda-turk-askerine-sevgi-gosterisi-407747.html">began</a> joint frontline patrols with pro-regime forces on March 8 with accompanying <a href="file://C:/Users/Kozak/Downloads/Enab%20Baladi">overflights</a> by the Turkish Air Force. The Turkish-Russian agreement in Idlib Province demonstrates that Syrian President Bashar al-Assad is failing in his attempts to spoil the de-escalation zone in Northern Syria brokered by Russia, Iran, and Turkey in 2017. Turkey will likely soon begin independent joint patrols with the Russian Armed Forces. Turkey and Russia <a href="https://www.enabbaladi.net/archives/282027">began</a> joint patrols of a separate area near Tel Rifaat north of Aleppo City on February 14. Turkey’s deepening relationship with Russia in Syria decreases the likelihood that the U.S. will reach a negotiated <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-gives-european-allies-friday-deadline-to-sign-on-to-syria-proposal-11551995825">agreement</a> with Turkey over the status of <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2019/03/disposition-of-adversary-and-friendly.html">Eastern Syria</a>. Russia intends to use its engagement with Turkey in Western Syria to set conditions to cooperate with Turkey against the U.S.-Led Coalition and its partnered Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) in Eastern Syria.  ISW is closely following the evolving situation in Idlib Province and will provide further updates as necessary.</p>

Title    : Disposition of Adversary and Friendly Forces in Eastern Syria
Published: Sat, 09 Mar 2019 17:47:38 +0000
Summary  :
<div class="field field-name-field-cover-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img alt="" height="125" src="https://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/styles/square_thumbnail/public/Syria%20and%20Western%20Iraq%20Map%20-%2025%20FEB%202019-01.png?itok=6Pznd4Z9" width="125" /></div></div></div><!--

-->
<div class="field field-name-field-pdf-report field-type-file field-label-hidden clearfix">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item even"><a href="https://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Syria%20and%20Western%20Iraq%20Map%20-%2025%20FEB%202019.pdf"><img src="https://www.understandingwar.org/modules/file/icons/application-pdf.png" style="float: left;" />Download the PDF</a></div>
      </div>
</div>
<div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong style="font-size: 13.008px;"><em>Key Takeaway</em></strong><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">: U.S. President Donald Trump’s recent </span><a href="https://www.npr.org/2019/02/22/696928907/u-s-will-leave-200-peacekeeping-troops-in-syria" style="font-size: 13.008px;">decision</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> to keep a residual force of at least 400 troops in Syria prevents the immediate takeover of valuable natural resources and infrastructure in Eastern Syria by Iran, Assad, and Russia. These actors nonetheless still have options that could lead to the defeat or expulsion of U.S. forces. The residual U.S. forces will operate at Al-Tanf on the Syrian-Jordanian Border as well as in Northern and Eastern Syria across the Euphrates River. The garrison at Al-Tanf is relatively defensible with secure supply lines to Jordan as well as a limited tactical requirement to defend the base and a surrounding fifty-five kilometer exclusion zone, which includes the Rukban IDP Camp. The U.S. is significantly more vulnerable east of the Euphrates River. Iran, Assad, and Russia are building up forces west of the Euphrates River and using outreach to local tribes to gain footholds on its eastern bank. Even a limited drawdown by the U.S. will create security gaps east of the Euphrates River that could be exploited by Iran, Assad, and Russia.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><em>Map Methodology: </em></strong>This graphic depicts the disposition of both adversary and partnered forces deployed at key infrastructure locations and urban centers in Eastern Syria and Western Iraq. Position locations are based on information available in open sources reviewed by the Institute for the Study of War (ISW). The list of locations and forces depicted on this graphic is not exhaustive but rather meant to show the presence of forces at assessed locations of vital strategic value or likely escalation. It also does not provide an assessment of the size of the deployed forces or their integration into wider command-and-control structures. The graphic does not depict the specific deployment locations of U.S.-Led Anti-ISIS Coalition forces beyond the garrison at Al-Tanf.  ISW will continue to update this dataset and publish updates as necessary. U.S. and allied government readers may contact ISW to request more details on the specific units and forces represented generally on this graphic.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">By the ISW Research Team</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">View the enlarged map <a href="https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-lkMwxmnNVKU/XILq1SYImlI/AAAAAAAAKN0/OomkbZ-KktosiRkxz6FO5JekAOGVRw43gCLcBGAs/s1600/Syria%2Band%2BWestern%2BIraq%2BMap%2B-%2B25%2BFEB%2B2019-01.png">here</a>.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><img height="700" src="https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-lkMwxmnNVKU/XILq1SYImlI/AAAAAAAAKN0/OomkbZ-KktosiRkxz6FO5JekAOGVRw43gCLcBGAs/s1600/Syria%2Band%2BWestern%2BIraq%2BMap%2B-%2B25%2BFEB%2B2019-01.png" width="610" /></p>

Title    : ISIS Re-Establishes Historical Sanctuary in Iraq
Published: Thu, 07 Mar 2019 15:37:00 +0000
Summary  :
<div class="field field-name-field-cover-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img alt="" height="125" src="https://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/styles/square_thumbnail/public/ISIS%20Joe%20Map%20Final_Map%20and%20Header.jpg?itok=ZjklJ2yR" width="125" /></div></div></div><!--
THIS FILE IS NOT USED AND IS HERE AS A STARTING POINT FOR CUSTOMIZATION ONLY.
See http://api.drupal.org/api/function/theme_field/7 for details.
After copying this file to your theme's folder and customizing it, remove this
HTML comment.
-->
<div class="field field-name-field-pdf-report field-type-file field-label-hidden clearfix">
    <div class="field-items">
          <div class="field-item even"><a href="https://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/ISIS%20Resurgence%20Joe%20Map%20MAR%202019%20-%20Final%20Approved_0.pdf"><img src="https://www.understandingwar.org/modules/file/icons/application-pdf.png" style="float: left;" />Download the PDF</a></div>
      </div>
</div>
<div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">ISIS’s post-Caliphate insurgency in Iraq is accelerating faster than efforts to prevent it by the U.S. Anti-ISIS Coalition. ISIS is re-establishing capable insurgent networks in multiple historical strongholds and linking them together, setting the conditions for future offensive operations against the Government of Iraq. The U.S. and its partners should not view the current relative security in Baghdad as confirmation of the defeat of ISIS. The U.S. Anti-ISIS Coalition’s strategy to enable Iraq to “independently manage” an insurgency through intelligence support and other building partner capacity efforts will likely fail to prevent ISIS from regaining momentum based on its current trajectory in Iraq.</span></p>
<p>By Brandon Wallace</p>
<p>Continue reading this update here on <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2019/03/isis-re-establishes-historic-sanctuary.html" target="_blank"><em><strong>ISW's Blog</strong></em></a>.</p>

Title    : Russia in Review: Russia's Influence Grows After Moldovan Elections
Published: Wed, 06 Mar 2019 05:00:00 +0000
Summary  :
<div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img src="https://files.constantcontact.com/c9ccf499301/d7f25d44-7d67-446d-8201-7553a9322dcd.png" /></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">The Kremlin is successfully increasing its political influence in Moldova. The pro-Kremlin Party of Socialists of the Republic of Moldova (PRSM) won the largest share in the February 24 Moldovan Parliamentary Elections. However, Moldova will likely be forced to call new elections within the next forty-five days due to continued deadlock in government-formation negotiations. Russia will likely bolster its disinformation campaign over the next six weeks in order to set conditions ahead of a new vote. Pro-Kremlin Moldovan President Igor Dodon will also likely continue to shape the information space and stress the need for a strategic alliance with Russia rather than the EU in order to ensure a decisive victory for his PSRM. The U.S. should engage diplomatically and work with favorable political parties in order to counter Russia’s agenda in Moldova.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">By Darina Regio with Andrea Snyder</p>
<div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden">
<div class="field-items">
<div class="field-item even">
<p>Continue reading this update here on <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2019/03/russias-influence-grows-after-moldovan.html" target="_blank"><em><strong>ISW's Blog</strong></em></a>.</p>

Title    : Navigating the U.S.-Turkey Relationship Beyond the Quagmire
Published: Wed, 25 Jul 2018 04:00:00 +0000
Summary  :
<div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p align="center" style="text-align: justify;"><strong style="font-size: 13.008px;"><em>Key Takeaway</em></strong><em style="font-size: 13.008px;">: The U.S. needs Turkey as an active partner despite its slide into authoritarianism under Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The U.S. should adopt an interest-based approach towards Turkey that shapes its behavior in line with shared strategic objectives such as reversing the gains of Iran and Russia in the Middle East.</em></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The U.S. needs Turkey to contribute actively as an ally in NATO. </strong>The U.S. and NATO face an <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2018/07/hungary-risks-nato-unity-on-ukraine.html">increasingly</a> <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2018/07/putin-poised-for-easy-victory-ahead-of.html">aggressive</a> Russia in the Middle East and Europe.<strong> </strong>Turkey plays an integral role in countering this threat. It dominates the Turkish Straits connecting the Black Sea to the Eastern Mediterranean. It provides a strategically-positioned platform on the southern flank of NATO from which to exert influence in the Middle East and Black Sea. It also maintains the second-largest available combat force in NATO. The U.S. and NATO already operate a number of critical military installations across Turkey including Incirlik Airbase.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Turkey is nonetheless the largest vulnerability to NATO’s cohesion.</strong> Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2018/06/the-collapse-of-turkeys-democracy.html">cemented</a> his own authoritarian rule in the 2018 Turkish General Elections. His new regime is pursuing self-serving policies that undermine the U.S. and NATO. Erdogan is <a href="https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2018/04/trump-syria-withdrawal-iran-turkey-russia.html">willing to align</a> with Russia and Iran against the U.S. Anti-ISIS Coalition. He has repeatedly fueled <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-europe-migrants-eu/eu-summit-to-focus-on-lowering-mediterranean-immigration-idUSKBN1JL2PJ">diplomatic rifts</a> with the U.S. and EU. He has conducted <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2018/01/syrias-war-after-isis-begins-as-turkey.html">military operations</a> <a href="https://www.militarytimes.com/flashpoints/2018/03/05/pentagon-operations-against-isis-in-eastern-syria-paused/">targeting</a> the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) - the principal ground partner of the U.S. Anti-ISIS Coalition in Syria. His <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2018/03/turkey-threatens-new-attacks-in-syria.html">interventions</a> (and <em>de facto</em> territorial annexations) in Iraq and Syria undermine the ability of the U.S. and NATO to credibly condemn similar acts of aggression by Russia.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The U.S. should commit to a smarter interest-based approach that compels greater cooperation from Turkey. </strong>The U.S. and Turkey are mired in tactical negotiations that fail to address their wider <a href="http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/PLANEX%20Report%202%20FINALFINAL.pdf">strategic divergences</a> or repair the damage from years of <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2017/11/turkeys-silent-al-qaeda-partner-in-syria.html">opposing</a> <a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2017/05/turkey-divide.html">policy</a> <a href="http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/The%20Pitfalls%20of%20Relying%20on%20Kurdish%20Forces%20to%20Counter%20ISIS.pdf">choices</a> in Iraq and Syria. The Trump Administration has engaged to resolve discrete challenges with Turkey such as the status of the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/04/world/middleeast/turkey-syria-kurds-manbij.html">contested town</a> of Manbij in Northern Syria and the <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-works-to-ease-tensions-with-turkey-to-secure-pastors-release-1522852192">arbitrary detention</a> of U.S. Pastor Andrew Brunson. These talks are insufficient to mend the relationship absent a more fundamental realignment between the U.S. and Turkey. The U.S. must refocus on areas of shared interest with Turkey following the reelection of an emboldened Erdogan.</p>
<ul style="text-align: justify;"><li><em style="font-size: 13.008px;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Counter-Terrorism</span></em><em style="font-size: 13.008px;">:</em><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> The U.S. and Turkey can find common ground against designated terrorist groups such as ISIS, al Qaeda, and the Kurdistan Workers’ Party (PKK). All three groups threaten the long-term stability of Turkey. The U.S. could offer </span><a href="http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/turkey-us-to-talk-on-pkk-fight-in-july-fm-133230" style="font-size: 13.008px;">military and intelligence support</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> against the PKK in Turkey and Iraq. The U.S. should also actively limit the influence of the PKK-linked Syrian Kurdish YPG within the SDF. These reforms are independently valuable as a means to address grievances among local Sunni Arabs that could fuel a renewed insurgency against the U.S. Anti-ISIS Coalition. Turkey must in turn cease its </span><a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2018/02/the-al-qaeda-blind-spot-for-us-approach.html" style="font-size: 13.008px;">cooperation</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> with al Qaeda in Syria and instead engage actively in counter-terrorism operations against al Qaeda and other </span><a href="https://www.criticalthreats.org/analysis/americas-real-enemy-the-salafi-jihadi-movement" style="font-size: 13.008px;">Salafi-Jihadist Groups</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">. Turkey must also halt cross-border operations against the SDF that disrupt the Anti-ISIS Campaign in Syria.</span></li>
</ul><ul style="text-align: justify;"><li><em style="font-size: 13.008px;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Regional Stability</span></em><em style="font-size: 13.008px;">:</em><strong style="font-size: 13.008px;"> </strong><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">The U.S. and Turkey both aim to contain and ultimately resolve the crises in Iraq and Syria. The U.S. and Turkey </span><a href="https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/syria/2018-07-11/dont-get-out-syria" style="font-size: 13.008px;">could</a> <a href="http://thehill.com/opinion/international/374226-tamping-down-the-crisis-in-turkey" style="font-size: 13.008px;">cooperate</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> to build mutually-acceptable local governance and security structures in both countries that exclude Iran as well as Salafi-Jihadist Groups. The U.S. should revisit its regional strategy to incorporate Turkey as a productive contributor - rather than a reluctant </span><a href="https://www.cnn.com/2015/08/29/europe/turkey-airstrikes/index.html" style="font-size: 13.008px;">late addition</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> - to the U.S. Anti-ISIS Campaign. Turkey must in turn limit its unilateral interventions against the PKK in Iraq and Syria and curb its covert support for local actors linked to Salafi-Jihadist Groups.</span></li>
</ul><ul style="text-align: justify;"><li><em style="font-size: 13.008px;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Iran</span></em><em style="font-size: 13.008px;">:</em><strong style="font-size: 13.008px;"> </strong><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">The U.S. and Turkey both agree on the need to curtail Iran’s influence in the Middle East. Both states</span><strong style="font-size: 13.008px;"> </strong><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">desire to reverse Iran’s military and political gains in both Syria and Iraq. The U.S. and Turkey could cooperate to support the formation of a new Government of Iraq </span><a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2018/06/contours-of-anti-us-iraqi-government.html" style="font-size: 13.008px;">not beholden</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> to Iran. Turkey should be encouraged to limit its </span><a href="http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/us-demand-to-stop-oil-trade-with-iran-not-binding-for-turkey-minister-133872" style="font-size: 13.008px;">cross-border trade</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> with Iran as well as its diplomatic cooperation with Iran and Russia in the Astana Process on Syria. The U.S. can encourage this outcome through the threat of trade-related </span><a href="https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2018/05/turkey-iran-united-states-can-ankara-bypass-sanctions.html" style="font-size: 13.008px;">sanctions</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> as well as support for alternative energy pathways such as the </span><a href="https://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFL8N1TY3A1" style="font-size: 13.008px;">Southern Gas Corridor</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">.</span></li>
</ul><ul style="text-align: justify;"><li><em style="font-size: 13.008px;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Russia</span></em><em style="font-size: 13.008px;">:</em><strong style="font-size: 13.008px;"> </strong><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">The U.S. and Turkey share an interest in containing a </span><a href="http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/The%20Gray%20Zone_Dubik_2018.pdf" style="font-size: 13.008px;">revisionist</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> Russia. Turkey particularly is threatened by the expansion of Russia into Syria and the </span><a href="http://iswresearch.blogspot.com/2018/06/russia-challenges-ukraine-in-sea-of-azov.html" style="font-size: 13.008px;">Black Sea</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">. The U.S. and NATO must </span><a href="https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/official_texts_156624.htm" style="font-size: 13.008px;">reassure</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> Turkey by increasing military deployments to deter aggression by Russia in the Black Sea and Middle East. Turkey must freeze its </span><a href="" style="font-size: 13.008px;">purchase</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> of the Russian S-400 Surface-to-Air Missile System. The U.S. in turn should sustain its bilateral security partnership with Turkey including joint military exercises and the sale of key capabilities such as advanced </span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-airshow-patriot/u-s-state-department-in-talks-with-turkey-to-sell-patriot-system-idUSKBN1K61LH" style="font-size: 13.008px;">air defense systems</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> and the </span><a href="https://www.defensenews.com/smr/nato-priorities/2018/06/21/turkey-gets-first-f-35-as-congress-put-pressure-on-pentagon-to-stop-future-deliveries/" style="font-size: 13.008px;">F-35</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">. Turkey should also be encouraged to limit its diplomatic cooperation with Russia and Iran in the Astana Process on Syria.</span></li>
</ul><ul style="text-align: justify;"><li><em style="font-size: 13.008px;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Responsible Governance in Turkey</span></em><em style="font-size: 13.008px;">:</em><strong style="font-size: 13.008px;"> </strong><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">The U.S. still holds a stake in the long-term economic and political durability of Turkey despite the reelection of Erdogan. The U.S. should promote reforms or trade agreements that create a positive investment market in Turkey without rewarding economic mismanagement under Erdogan. The U.S. also must not shy away from enforcing minimal standards of behavior on Turkey. Turkey must be pressed to halt its use of ‘</span><a href="http://www.defenddemocracy.org/content/uploads/documents/REPORT_Erdogan_Hostages.pdf" style="font-size: 13.008px;">hostage diplomacy</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;">’ and release </span><a href="https://www.csce.gov/international-impact/press-and-media/press-releases/helsinki-commission-leaders-troubled-continued" style="font-size: 13.008px;">detained</a><span style="font-size: 13.008px;"> political prisoners such as U.S. Pastor Andrew Brunson. The U.S. must continue to promote a return to rule of law in Turkey that includes an independent judiciary and other checks on the power of Erdogan.</span></li>
</ul><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>The U.S. can manage its relationship with Turkey without capitulating to Erdogan. </strong>The U.S. and Turkey both need one another to confront their mutual adversaries in the Middle East and Europe. This fact remains true despite the unacceptable growth of authoritarianism under Erdogan. There is no quick policy fix to resolve the tensions between the U.S. and Turkey. The U.S. could nonetheless use an incremental and interest-based approach focused on clear areas of strategic convergence in order to protect its long-term alliance with a post-Erdogan Turkey.</p>
<p align="center" style="font-size: 13.008px; text-align: left;"><em>By Elizabeth Teoman</em></p>
</div></div></div><h3 id="tagtitle"><span>Tags</span></h3>
