      </div>
</div>
<div class="field field-name-field-multiple-authors field-type-user-reference field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://www.understandingwar.org/users/elizabeth-teoman">Elizabeth Teoman</a></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-pushtofront field-type-taxonomy-term-reference field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="https://www.understandingwar.org/latest-isw-front/promote">Promote</a></div></div></div>
=== ENTRY END ===

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : A "Remarkable" Afghan Ceasefire
Published: Fri, 22 Jun 2018 21:50:54 +0000
Summary  :
<div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><img src="http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Afghan%20ALP_USMC%20Image_20120414_b.jpg" /></span></strong></span></strong></p>
<p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 8.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 8.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">Image Source: U.S. Marine Corps, Cpl. Reece Lodder (Flickr)</span></span></p>
<p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><br /></span></strong></span></strong></p>
<p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">A “Remarkable” Afghan Ceasefire</span></strong></span></strong></p>
<p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: left;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">By Scott DesMarais</span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><em><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">Key Takeaway:</span></em></strong><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> The U.S. and Afghanistan have an opportunity to advance their strategic goal of negotiating an acceptable settlement with the Taliban, but not all Taliban members are reconcilable. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The Taliban faces a potential rift between its leadership and rank-and-file militants in Afghanistan that threatens the Taliban’s cohesion. Large numbers of rank-and-file militants expressed their support for peace during unprecedented joint celebrations alongside Afghan National Security Forces (ANSF) during a nationwide ceasefire for Eid al-Fitr on June 15 - 17. The ceasefire’s events exposed rifts amongst Taliban leadership concerning reconciliation. The U.S. and the Government of Afghanistan could exploit these apparent rifts in order to advance their strategic goal of a negotiated settlement with the Taliban. The new momentum towards peace could nonetheless generate additional pressure for the withdrawal of the U.S. from Afghanistan amidst the scheduled 2018 Afghan Parliamentary Elections.<strong> </strong>ISIS - Wilayat Khorasan could also exploit these rifts in to bolster its recruitment of hardline Taliban militants and expand its operations in Afghanistan.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">What Happened</span></span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">The Taliban and Afghan National Security Forces (ANSF) engaged in “</span></strong><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/in-remarkable-scenes-taliban-fighters-join-eid-celebrations-across-afghanistan-as-cease-fire-begins/2018/06/15/8c48e7c4-70ab-11e8-b4d8-eaf78d4c544c_story.html?noredirect=on&amp;utm_term=.4741279e9cb0"><strong><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">remarkable scenes</span></strong></a></span><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">” of joint celebration during a three-day ceasefire observed by both the Taliban and the ANSF. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The Government of Afghanistan </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/17/world/asia/afghanistan-bombing-taliban-isis.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; color: #1155cc;">estimated</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> that up to 30,000 Taliban militants entered government-held cities across the country during the three-day truce in honor of the end of Ramadan.<span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span style="background: white;"><span><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"><sup>1 </sup></span></span></span></span></span>The </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/the-eid-ceasefire-allowing-afghans-to-imagine-their-country-at-peace/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">gatherings</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> reportedly occurred in several regions that have seen intense fighting during the Taliban’s 2018 Al-Khandaq Offensive including Faryab, Farah, Ghazni, and Kunduz Provinces as well as traditional Taliban strongholds such as </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/16/atmar-taliban-soldiers-selfies-%E2%80%98war-flames-fueled-outside%E2%80%99"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Helmand</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> and </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/the-eid-ceasefire-allowing-afghans-to-imagine-their-country-at-peace/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Kandahar</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> Provinces. Even “senior” leaders reportedly met with government officials in </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/the-eid-ceasefire-allowing-afghans-to-imagine-their-country-at-peace/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Zabul</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> and </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://twitter.com/voadeewa/status/1007626016657944577?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw&amp;ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.afghanistan-analysts.org%2Fthe-eid-ceasefire-allowing-afghans-to-imagine-their-country-at-peace%2F"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Logar</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> Provinces. Taliban fighters interviewed by the media repeatedly </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/17/world/asia/afghanistan-bombing-taliban-isis.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan&amp;action=click&amp;contentCollection=world&amp;region=stream&amp;module=stream_unit&amp;version=latest&amp;contentPlacement=3&amp;pgtype=collection"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">expressed</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> their fatigue with continued violence and their </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"></a><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; color: #1155cc;">growing</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> desire for peace.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">The ceasefire could validate President Ghani’s strategy to achieve a negotiated settlement. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">Ghani </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-taliban/afghanistans-ghani-offers-talks-with-taliban-without-preconditions-idUSKCN1GC0J0"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">offered</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> the Taliban full political reconciliation in exchange for a ceasefire and the resumption of peace negotiations on February 28. The Taliban refused to acknowledge the offer officially, although multiple U.S. officials have claimed that </span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">elements of the Taliban including “</span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-afghanistan/taliban-talking-and-fighting-says-u-s-commander-in-afghanistan-idUSKCN1IV2HP"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">senior-level leaders</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">” are “</span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/13/asia/mattis-afghanistan-taliban-peace-talks-intl/index.html"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">clearly interested</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">” in talks with the Government of Afghanistan since Ghani’s peace offer. <span style="background: white;">Ghani later unilaterally </span></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/07/world/asia/afghanistan-ashraf-ghani-cease-fire-taliban.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan&amp;action=click&amp;contentCollection=world&amp;region=stream&amp;module=stream_unit&amp;version=latest&amp;contentPlacement=1&amp;pgtype=collection"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">announced</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> the ceasefire for Eid al-Fitr on June 7 despite ongoing operations by the Taliban that </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/7-provincial-centers-face-%E2%80%98serious-security-threats"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">threatened</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> at least seven provincial capitals around Afghanistan. The Taliban bowed to public pressure and </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/09/world/asia/taliban-cease-fire-afghanistan.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">announced</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> their own nominally-unrelated ceasefire on June 9. Ghani has attempted to leverage the apparent success of the truce to spur further political progress. Ghani </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;"><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-taliban-palace/afghan-president-extends-ceasefire-with-taliban-by-10-days-idUSKBN1JD0R6">announced</a> </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">a unilateral ten-day extension of the ceasefire - until June 30 – on June 17. He also stressed that his government is open to negotiations with the Taliban on “issues of mutual concern” including the “</span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/afghan-government-extends-cease-fire-with-taliban-as-fighters-join-civilians-to-celebrate-eid/2018/06/16/a3fcecce-7170-11e8-b4d8-eaf78d4c544c_story.html?noredirect=on&amp;utm_term=.b022e704f63d"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; color: #1155cc;">presence of foreign forces</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">” in Afghanistan.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The Taliban leadership has thus far rejected further extension of a ceasefire and has resumed its attacks in some remote locations</span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">. The Taliban spokesperson </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afp.com/en/news/205/taliban-say-ceasefire-wont-be-extended-suicide-attack-kills-18-doc-16341x6"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">stated</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> that the group has “no intention to extend the ceasefire" on June 17 and resumed offensive operations throughout Afghanistan including on June 18. Taliban militants conducted significant attacks in </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/18/4-security-personnel-killed-taliban-attacks"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Faryab</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">, </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.voanews.com/a/taliban-afghan-attack/4446599.html"><span lang="EN-US" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN-US">Badghis</span></a></span><span class="MsoHyperlink"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">, and </span></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/20/policemen-among-24-killed-farah-clashes-raid"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Farah</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> Provinces since their ceasefire’s expiration. The Taliban may intend to exploit the government’s extended ceasefire to amass fighters and launch a coordinated operation against </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/7-provincial-centers-face-%E2%80%98serious-security-threats"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">vulnerable</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> provincial capitals in Faryab or Farah Provinces. The Taliban also executed smaller attacks </span><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">in many provinces where joint celebrations occurred such as </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/clashes-resume-kunduz-after-eid-ceasefire"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Kunduz</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">, </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/20/4-taliban-killed-many-security-personnel-injured-logar-helmand-clashes"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Logar</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">, </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/19/policemen-among-7-dead-nangarhar-assault"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Nangarhar</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">, and </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/06/20/4-taliban-killed-many-security-personnel-injured-logar-helmand-clashes"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Helmand</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">Implications</span></span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The Taliban faces a potential rift between its leadership and rank-and-file militants in Afghanistan that threatens the Taliban’s cohesiveness. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">Taliban militants repeatedly </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/17/world/asia/afghanistan-bombing-taliban-isis.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">violated</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> a formal directive from their leadership to avoid government-controlled areas on June 16. Taliban fighters also </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://twitter.com/1TVNewsAF/status/1008650300381679616"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">demanded</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> an extension to the ceasefire in parts of Paktika Province </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/the-eid-ceasefire-allowing-afghans-to-imagine-their-country-at-peace/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">controlled</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> by the hardline Haqqani Network. The Taliban released an official post-ceasefire statement stressing the organizational cohesion and control demonstrated by the “successful implementation” of the truce despite the clear violations of leadership orders.<sup><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif;" xml:lang="EN">2 </span></span></span></span></sup><span>The Taliban leadership also allegedly </span></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">considered</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> a ten-day ceasefire for late 2018 due to growing pressure for a negotiated settlement within the Taliban.</span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> The Government of Afghanistan and the U.S. could attempt to exploit the apparent divisions within the Taliban to split rank-and-file fighters from their leadership if the Taliban refuses to engage with Kabul.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The Taliban also faces a power struggle within its ruling Quetta Shura. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The ceasefire could exacerbate a </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/50-quetta-shura-supports-peace-talks-says-raziq"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">rift</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> between Taliban leaders who are open to reconciliation and hardliners unwilling to negotiate a settlement. The joint celebrations reportedly </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"></a><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; color: #1155cc;">surprised</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> and angered some Taliban leaders including Taliban Second Deputy Leader </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Mullah Yaqoob</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">.<sup><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif;" xml:lang="EN">3</span></span></span></span></sup> Taliban leader Mullah Haibatullah Akhundzada – a reported </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.crpaweb.org/single-post/2018/03/20/Do-the-Taliban-Have-any-Appetite-for-Reconciliation-with-Kabul-Antonio-Giustozzi"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">moderate</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> - may use widespread support for peace amongst the rank-and-file to consolidate his control within the Quetta Shura vis-à-vis hardliners such as Mullah Yaqoob and First Deputy Leader </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Haqqani_Network_0.pdf"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Siraj Haqqani</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">. This power struggle predates the ceasefire. Akhundzada reportedly </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.pajhwok.com/en/2018/02/01/new-appointments-reflect-power-struggle-within-taliban"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">reshuffled</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> multiple shadow governors and senior leaders to increase his control over the movement in February 2018. </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.khaama.com/taliban-reshuffles-leadership-council-after-eid-ceasefire-05385/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">Rumors</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> of additional post-ceasefire leadership changes may further demonstrate shifting dynamics in favor of Akhundzada. The weakening of hardliners like Haqqani - who maintains </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="http://www.understandingwar.org/sites/default/files/Haqqani_Network_0.pdf"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">close ties</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> to al Qaeda and Pakistan - in favor of Akhundzada could open space for peace-inclined factions of the Taliban to pursue a negotiated settlement. Hardline elements are likely to continue the fight against Kabul.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">The U.S. could exploit these apparent rifts in order to advance its strategic objectives in Afghanistan. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN">The U.S. intends to use military and diplomatic means to </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.defense.gov/News/Transcripts/Transcript-View/Article/1382901/department-of-defense-press-briefing-by-general-nicholson-via-teleconference-fr/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">pressure</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> the Taliban to negotiate a peace settlement with the Government of Afghanistan. </span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2018/06/283271.htm"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">stated</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> that the U.S. is “prepared to support, facilitate, and participate” in peace negotiations that would include “a discussion of the role of international actors and forces” in Afghanistan on June 16. U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for South and Central Asian Affairs Alice Wells </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://docs.house.gov/meetings/FA/FA00/20180620/108448/HHRG-115-FA00-Wstate-WellsA-20180620.pdf"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">reaffirmed</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> the willingness to participate in negotiations but reiterated the established U.S. position that the Taliban must negotiate directly with the Government of Afghanistan on June 20. Incoming U.S. Forces – Afghanistan Commander <span style="background: white;">Lt. Gen. Scott Miller has also testified that a </span></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.defense.gov/News/Article/Article/1554390/resolute-support-nominee-effort-still-needed-to-prevent-homeland-attacks/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;">political settlement</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; background: white;" xml:lang="EN"> must end the War in Afghanistan.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">The U.S. nonetheless must remain cautious that the peace process does not jeopardize its access to Afghanistan. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">Members of the both houses of the Afghan Parliament have </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/violence-increased-afghanistan-following-trump-strategy"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">criticized</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> the U.S. role in Afghanistan since May 2018. Some members of the upper house have </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.tolonews.com/index.php/afghanistan/cancel-security-agreements-us-and-nato-senators"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">called</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> for the review or cancellation of the Bilateral Security Agreement (BSA) between the U.S. and Afghanistan.<sup><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif;" xml:lang="EN">4 </span></span></span></span></sup>Meanwhile, </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/15/world/asia/afghanistan-peace-march-.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FAfghanistan&amp;action=click&amp;contentCollection=world&amp;region=stream&amp;module=stream_unit&amp;version=latest&amp;contentPlacement=6&amp;pgtype=collection">peace protesters</a> </span></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-taliban/afghan-peace-marchers-arrive-in-kabul-exhausted-and-tired-of-war-idUSKBN1JE0DZ"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">marching</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> from Helmand Province to Kabul to encourage reconciliation with the Taliban have also </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/peace-hopefully-for-a-few-days-a-ceasefire-for-eid-as-helmand-marchers-approach-kabul/"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">demanded</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> a specific timeline for the withdrawal of the U.S. from Afghanistan. Taliban sources have also claimed that a clearly-defined timeline for withdrawal could have </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jun/17/taliban-refuse-to-extend-truce-with-afghan-forces"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">persuaded</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> Taliban leadership to accept a ceasefire extension after Eid al-Fitr. These converging demands for the withdrawal of the U.S. from Afghanistan could begin to spiral into a widespread populist movement ahead of the scheduled 2018 Afghan Parliamentary Elections and 2019 Afghan Presidential Elections. The U.S. must not depart abruptly or under a fixed timeline but rather through a gradual drawdown after setting and testing the conditions for sustained peace in Afghanistan.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">ISIS could also exploit the ceasefire and possibility of a negotiated settlement to expand its operations in Afghanistan. </span></strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">ISIS’s Afghanistan branch, ISIS Wilayat Khorasan,<strong> </strong></span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://ent.siteintelgroup.com/Statements/is-claims-85-casualties-in-2nd-suicide-bombing-in-24-hours-on-afghan-taliban-and-afghan-security-forces-in-nangarhar.html"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">claimed</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> two separate </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-taliban/afghanistan-eid-car-bomb-claimed-by-islamic-state-kills-26-idUSKBN1JC044"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">attacks</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> that targeted joint celebrations between the Taliban and ANSF in Nangarhar Province during Eid al-Fitr. The statements </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://ent.siteintelgroup.com/Statements/is-claims-killing-wounding-nearly-100-from-afghan-taliban-and-afghan-forces-in-what-former-calls-mysterious-explosion-in-nangarhar.html"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">noted</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> that the attacks targeted gatherings of both the ANSF and “the apostate Taliban Movement.” The Taliban later released a post-ceasefire </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; color: #1155cc;"><a href="https://ent.siteintelgroup.com/Statements/is-claims-killing-wounding-nearly-100-from-afghan-taliban-and-afghan-forces-in-what-former-calls-mysterious-explosion-in-nangarhar.html">statement</a> </span></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN">arguing that the Taliban is the only movement leading “jihad across the country,” and adding that “multiple parties [are] not participating in this jihad.”<sup><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: 'Arial',sans-serif;" xml:lang="EN">5 </span></span></span></span></sup>The statement - while directed against the U.S. assessment of a fractured jihadist movement in Afghanistan - may also highlight the Taliban leadership’s concern that the ceasefire will harm their credentials as the leaders of the jihad in Afghanistan. ISIS could position itself to recruit </span><span lang="EN" xml:lang="EN"><a href="https://www.crpaweb.org/single-post/2017/12/15/Enemies-or-Jihad-Brothers-Relations-Between-Taliban-and-Islamic-State"><span style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;">dissatisfied hardline</span></a></span><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 10.0pt; line-height: 115%;" xml:lang="EN"> members of the Taliban if Taliban leadership begin openly pursuing a peaceful settlement with the Government of Afghanistan.</span></p>
<div>

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : Labor Department Official Warns That Staff Who Speak With Journalists Face “Serious Legal Consequences”
Published: Wed, 23 Apr 2025 09:20:00 -0400
Summary  :
<p class="byline">
                by <a class="name" href="https://www.propublica.org/people/mark-olalde">Mark Olalde</a>                </p>
                                             

                                                                    
            
                <p>ProPublica is a nonprofit newsroom that investigates abuses of power. <a href="https://www.propublica.org/newsletters/dispatches?source=54G&amp;placement=top-note&amp;region=local">Sign up for Dispatches</a>, a newsletter that spotlights wrongdoing around the country, to receive our stories in your inbox every week.</p>

            

                

      
  



                    
<p>A top official in the Department of Labor this week informed all staff members that they could face criminal charges if they speak to journalists, former employees or others about agency business.</p>

<p>A memo sent Monday by Secretary of Labor Lori Chavez-DeRemer’s chief of staff, Jihun Han, and obtained by ProPublica, states that “individuals who disclose confidential information or engage in unauthorized communications with the media may face serious legal consequences.”</p>

<p>Among the ramifications, the memo states, are “potential criminal penalties, depending on the nature of the information and the applicable laws,” and “immediate disciplinary actions, up to and including termination.”</p>

<p>The guidance document went on to say that “any unauthorized communication with the media,” regardless of what information is shared or how it is shared, “will be treated as a serious offense.”</p>
        
    
                    
<p>The memo listed laws, regulations and a departmental guide to explain its legal position. Among them was a regulation concerning civil servants’ ethical obligations and a law, the Freedom of Information Act, guaranteeing the public the right to inspect certain public records.</p>

<p>“This message will serve as your only warning,” the memo stated.</p>

<p>The warning comes as current and former Labor Department employees have spoken to the news media about <a href="https://thehill.com/opinion/technology/5235329-federal-labor-agency-changes/">harms they see resulting from the dismantling of portions of their agency</a>, which enforces laws guaranteeing rights to a safe workplace, fair pay and protections against discrimination.</p>

<p>“It’s very chilling,” a Labor Department employee who requested anonymity for fear of retribution told ProPublica. “It’s never a good look when you’re telling people to never talk about what you’re doing.”</p>

<p>Labor Department spokespeople did not immediately respond to a request for comment.</p>

<p>“These types of missives can chill the free flow of information to the press and the public,” said Gabe Rottman, vice president of policy at the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press. “That’s a concern.”</p>

<p>Civil servants do not sacrifice their First Amendment rights by accepting a job with the federal government, but <a href="https://www.acludc.org/en/know-your-rights/federal-employee-speech-first-amendment">there do exist higher restrictions</a> on what information they can disclose publicly. Government agencies that handle classified information have on rare occasions launched criminal investigations against leakers, but those are typically invoked <a href="https://www.rcfp.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/12-8-2019-Leaks-Chart-1.pdf">only when leaks involve</a> classified national security intelligence or protected financial information, Rottman said.</p>

<p>“But normally, disclosures to the press or others would be a matter of employee discipline as opposed to carrying criminal sanctions,” he said.</p>

<p>While the memo raising the possibility of criminal penalties was sent to Labor Department employees, it reflects a common approach by the administration of President Donald Trump to guard against federal government employees speaking to reporters.</p>

<p>Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard, for example, <a href="https://newrepublic.com/post/192753/tulsi-gabbard-clamps-down-leaks-media-threat">has publicly announced</a> an aggressive pursuit of leakers. Elon Musk, who launched the Department of Government Efficiency, which is at the heart of the shake-up of the federal government, <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2025/03/21/elon-musk-leak-hunt-026928">has bragged about</a> his tactics in rooting out leaks at his companies. And Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/apr/22/pete-hegseth-signal-group-chat">has blamed alleged leaks</a> by former Pentagon staffers for reigniting controversy over his use of the Signal messaging app to discuss military operations.</p>

<p>Federal employees at various agencies told ProPublica that an air of suspicion has descended on their workplace during Trump’s second term, with rumors flying of surveillance of rank-and-file government workers. In the Department of Agriculture, for example, a banner temporarily appeared on government computers when employees logged in, telling them that “unauthorized or improper use of this system may result in disciplinary action, as well as civil and criminal penalties.”</p>

<p>Agriculture Department spokespeople did not immediately respond to a request for comment.</p>

<p>The Labor Department employee told ProPublica that Monday’s memo felt like the latest attack on a workforce already weathering layoffs, spending freezes and reorganizations.</p>

<p>“It’s been horrible. It’s been a deeply exhausting roller coaster,” the employee said. “It’s very difficult to work when you’re in a constant state of being terrorized by your employer.”</p>
=== ENTRY END ===

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : Fentanyl Pipeline: How a Chinese Prison Helped Fuel a Deadly Drug Crisis in the United States
Published: Wed, 23 Apr 2025 06:00:00 -0400
Summary  :
<p class="byline">
                by <a class="name" href="https://www.propublica.org/people/sebastian-rotella">Sebastian Rotella</a>                </p>
                                             

                                                                    
            
                <p>ProPublica is a nonprofit newsroom that investigates abuses of power. Sign up to receive <a href="https://www.propublica.org/newsletters/the-big-story?source=54G&amp;placement=top-note&amp;region=national">our biggest stories</a> as soon as they’re published.</p>

            

                

      
  



                    
<p>China’s vast security apparatus shrouds itself in shadows, but the outside world has caught periodic glimpses of it behind the faded gray walls of Shijiazhuang prison in the northern province of Hebei.</p>

<p>Chinese media reports have shown inmates hunched over sewing machines in a garment workshop in the sprawling facility. Business leaders and Chinese Communist Party dignitaries have praised the penitentiary for exemplifying President Xi Jinping’s views on the rule of law.</p>

<p>But the prison has an alarming secret, U.S. congressional investigators disclosed last year. They revealed evidence showing that it is a Chinese government outpost in the trafficking pipeline that inundates the United States with fentanyl.</p>

<p>For at least eight years, the prison owned a chemical company called Yafeng, the hub of a group of Chinese firms and websites that sold fentanyl products to Americans, according to the U.S. <a href="https://docs.house.gov/meetings/ZS/ZS00/20240416/117142/HRPT-118-1.pdf#page=21">congressional investigation</a>, as well as Chinese government and <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25881584-c4ads-hebei-shijiazhuang-yafeng-chemical-plant/">corporate records</a> obtained by ProPublica. The company’s English-language websites brazenly offered U.S. customers dangerous drugs that are illegal in both nations. Promising to smuggle illicit chemicals past U.S. and Mexican border defenses, Yafeng boasted to American clients that “100% of our shipments will clear customs.”</p>

<p>Although China tightly restricts the domestic manufacturing, sale and use of fentanyl products, the nation has been the world’s leading producer of fentanyl that enters the United States and remains the leading producer of chemical precursors with which Mexican cartels make the drug. Overdoses on synthetic opioid drugs, most of them fentanyl related, have killed over 450,000 Americans during the past decade — more than the U.S. deaths in the Vietnam, Iraq and Afghanistan wars combined.</p>

<p>The involvement of a state-run prison is just one sign of the Chinese government’s role in fomenting the U.S. fentanyl crisis, U.S. investigators say. Chinese leaders have insistently denied such allegations. But U.S. national security officials said the Yafeng case shows how China allows its chemical industry to engage openly in sales to overseas customers while blocking online domestic access and enforcing stern laws against drug dealing inside the country. Beijing also encourages the manufacture and export of fentanyl products, including drugs outlawed in China, with generous financial incentives, according to a bipartisan inquiry last year by the House Select Committee on Strategic Competition between the United States and the Chinese Communist Party.</p>

<p>“So the Chinese government pays you to send drugs to America but executes you for selling them in China,” Matt Cronin, a former federal prosecutor who led the House inquiry, said in an interview. “It’s impossible that the Chinese Communist Party doesn’t know what’s going on and can’t do anything about it.”</p>
        
    
                    
<p>China’s antidrug cooperation has been persistently poor, U.S. officials said. In 2019, Xi imposed controls that cut the export of fentanyl, but Chinese sellers shifted to shipping precursors to Mexico, where the cartels expanded their production.</p>

<p>“We couldn’t get the Chinese on the phone to talk about fighting child pornography, let alone fentanyl,’’ said Jacob Braun, who served as a senior official at the Department of Homeland Security during the Biden administration. “There was zero cooperation.”</p>

<p>China also remains the base of <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/how-beijing-chinese-mafia-europe-protect-interests">global organized crime groups</a> that launder billions for fentanyl traffickers in the U.S, Mexico and <a href="https://globalnews.ca/news/8122106/canada-needs-u-s-style-racketeering-laws-current-organized-crime-laws-failing-b-c-ag-tells-feds/">Canada</a>. <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/china-cartels-xizhi-li-money-laundering">ProPublica has previously reported</a> that this underground banking system depends on the <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/liu-tao-trump-meeting-china-investigation">Chinese elite</a>, who move fortunes abroad by acquiring drug cash from Chinese criminal brokers for Mexican cartels. <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-icbc-spain-investigation/fines-short-jail-terms-for-four-ex-icbc-spain-employees-in-laundering-case-idUSKBN23N2Q6/">Chinese banks</a> and businesses also help hide the origin of illicit proceeds. The regime in Beijing therefore has considerable control over key nodes in the fentanyl chain: raw materials, production, sales and money laundering.</p>

<p>U.S. leaders, <a href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v%3DgVlTMqQPF04&amp;sa=D&amp;source=docs&amp;ust=1744036544050687&amp;usg=AOvVaw1FPSqrIFDP2O3cfZig2gNA">Democrats</a> and <a href="https://selectcommitteeontheccp.house.gov/sites/evo-subsites/selectcommitteeontheccp.house.gov/files/evo-media-document/Written%20Testimony%20-%20The%20Honorable%20Bill%20Barr.pdf">Republicans</a> alike, have accused China of using fentanyl to weaken the United States. Some veteran agents agree.</p>

<p>Ray Donovan, who retired in 2023 as the Drug Enforcement Administration’s chief of operations, said he believes that a “deliberate strategy” by the Chinese state has caused the trafficking onslaught “to grow in size and scope.”</p>

<p>“They have said for years that they are cracking down,” Donovan said in an interview. “But we haven’t seen meaningful action.”</p>

<p>Still, current and former U.S. officials told ProPublica that the national security community has not found conclusive evidence of a planned, high-level campaign against Americans by the Chinese government. That is partly because for years the U.S. treated fentanyl as a law enforcement matter rather than a national security threat, making it hard to gather intelligence about the extent and nature of the regime’s role.</p>

<p>“If this was Chinese intelligence doing something, we have a focus on that as counterintelligence,” said Alan Kohler, who retired from the FBI in 2023 after serving as director of the counterintelligence division. “If it was drug cartels, we have a criminal focus on that. But this area of crime and state converging falls between the seams in and among agencies.”</p>

<p>Nonetheless, the current and former officials said rampant fentanyl trafficking could not continue without at least the passive complicity of the world’s most powerful police state.</p>

<p>“I haven’t seen smoking-gun evidence that it’s a policy or strategy of the government at a high level,” Kohler said. “You could argue that their decision not to do anything about it, even after the results are clear, is tacit support.”</p>
        
    
                            
    
                    
<p>In a written statement, the spokesperson for China’s embassy in Washington described as “totally groundless” any allegation that the regime has fomented the crisis.</p>

<p>“The fentanyl issue is the U.S.’s own problem,” said the spokesperson, Liu Pengyu. “China has given support to the U.S.’s response to the fentanyl issue in the spirit of humanity.” At the United States’ request, he said, China in 2019 restricted “fentanyl-related substances as a class,” becoming the first country to do so, and has cooperated with the U.S. on counternarcotics.</p>

<p>“The remarkable progress is there for all to see.”</p>

<p>The Trump administration has made the fight against fentanyl a priority and <a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/fact-sheets/2025/02/fact-sheet-president-donald-j-trump-imposes-tariffs-on-imports-from-canada-mexico-and-china/">in February</a> imposed a 25% tariff on Chinese imports to pressure Beijing for results. The approach could put a dent in the drug trade, but it’s too early to tell, officials said.</p>

<p>“The Chinese system responds to a negative incentive,” said former FBI agent Holden Triplett, who served as legal attache in Beijing and director of counterintelligence on the National Security Council. “China may be willing to endure more pain than we can give. But it is our only chance.”</p>

<p>To respond effectively, the U.S. needs a clearer picture of the Chinese fentanyl underworld, Triplett and others say. The activities of the Shijiazhuang prison are a compelling case study, but not the only one.</p>

<p>To examine the role of the Chinese state in the drug trade, ProPublica interviewed more than three dozen current and former national security officials for the U.S. and other countries, some of whom provided exclusive inside accounts. The reporting also drew on last year’s House investigation, digging into significant findings that have received little public attention, plus court files, government documents, academic studies, private inquiries and public records in the U.S., China and Mexico.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

    
            (Collage by Mike McQuade for ProPublica. Source images: Google Maps and screenshots from ads found by a U.S. congressional inquiry.)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
Prison Business
<p>In 2010, the Hebei Prison Administration Bureau combined three detention facilities to create a high-security prison in Shijiazhuang, the capital of Hebei province. The region is a base of China’s chemical industry, which is the largest in the world. It is also weakly regulated and freewheeling, according to U.S. national security officials, private studies and other sources. A shifting array of companies peddle everything from innocuous fertilizers to deadly opioids.</p>

<p>Liu Jianhua, a veteran Chinese Communist Party official with a master’s degree in business administration from the University of Illinois Chicago, became director of the prison in 2014. By then, fentanyl was cutting a swath across America. Overdose deaths soared due to the ease with which U.S. users and dealers could acquire fentanyl products by mail from China.</p>

<p>China’s high-tech surveillance apparatus aggressively polices the online activities of its citizens. Yet sales of fentanyl to foreigners have thrived on popular, easily accessible websites, said Frank Montoya Jr., a former FBI agent with years of China-related experience who served as a top U.S. counterintelligence official.</p>

<p>“You don’t have to go on the dark web,” Montoya said. “It is out in the open.”</p>

<p>Yafeng Biological Technology Co. Ltd., also known as Hebei Shijiazhuang Yafeng Chemical Plant, became a typical player on this frontier, the congressional inquiry found. (As part of its reporting, ProPublica mapped links between the prison, the company and the U.S. drug market with the help of two entities that specialize in China open-source research: Sayari, a company that provides risk management and supply-chain analysis and that supported the House inquiry, and C4ADS, a nonprofit that investigates illicit global networks.)</p>

<p>Yafeng’s <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20240225091201if_/http:/www.chinayfkj.com/EN/news/danye.asp?id=1">websites</a> and <a href="https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25881584-c4ads-hebei-shijiazhuang-yafeng-chemical-plant/">Chinese corporate records</a> describe the firm as a chemical manufacturer. It has ties through other websites, phone numbers and email addresses to at least nine companies that advertised illicit drugs, causing investigators to conclude that Yafeng was a network hub, according to the report and interviews. It’s common for interconnected Chinese fentanyl producers and brokers to obscure details about their enterprises and change names and platforms to elude detection, U.S. officials said.</p>

<p>In some ways, Yafeng presented itself to foreign buyers as a respectable company. The English-language websites featured peppy phrases like “team spirit” and “promoting the well-being of community.” The China-based sales representatives gave themselves Western names: Diana, Monica, Jessica. A map of markets showed shipping routes from China to the United States, Mexico, Canada and other countries.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            A map on Yafeng’s website showed its distribution and a list of available drugs to purchase.
    
            (U.S. government)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
<p>Yet the sales pitches left little doubt that the firm knew its activities were illegal. Yafeng websites utilized familiar terms assuring U.S. and Mexican drug users and traffickers of the company’s skill at smuggling illegal narcotics overseas, according to the House report and U.S. investigators. The company touted its use of “hidden food bags,” a method in which drugs are concealed in shipments labeled as food products. Ads promised “strong safety delivery to Mexico, USA” with “packaging made to measure” to “guarantee” that illicit chemicals would elude border inspections, documents show.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            Advertisements on a Chinese website
    
            (U.S. government)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
<p>Chinese traffickers often discuss lawbreaking in such brazen terms with foreign customers, seemingly unconcerned about China’s omnipresent surveillance system, court files and interviews show. Another firm, Hubei Amarvel Biotech, explicitly explained to U.S. and Mexican clients online — complete with photos — its methods for “100% stealth shipping” of drugs disguised as nuts, dog food and motor oil, <a href="https://www.justice.gov/d9/2023-06/sdny_unsealed_2023.06.22_amarvel_biotech_indictment_stamped_redacted.pdf">court documents</a> say. After undercover DEA agents lured two Amarvel executives to Fiji and arrested them, a New York jury <a href="https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/two-chinese-chemical-company-executives-convicted-and-multiple-websites-and-0">convicted them</a> in February on charges of importation of fentanyl precursors and money laundering. (One defendant, Yiyi Chen, has filed a motion requesting an acquittal or retrial.)</p>

<p>At the time of the arrests, the Chinese government issued a statement condemning the U.S. prosecution as “a typical example of arbitrary detention and unilateral sanctions.”</p>

<p>Similarly, Yafeng websites displayed photos of narcotics in plastic baggies to peddle a long list of chemicals, including fentanyl precursors and U-47700, a powerful fentanyl analogue outlawed in both the U.S. and China that has no medical use, the House report says.</p>

<p>One victim of U-47700 was Garrett Holman of Lynchburg, Virginia. Holman had fallen in with youths who discovered how easy it was to buy synthetic drugs online. In late 2016, Holman overdosed on U-47700, street name “pinky,” that arrived by mail from southern China. His father, Don, performed CPR before paramedics rushed Holman to the hospital. Although he survived, another overdose killed him just days before his 21st birthday in February 2017.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            Garrett Holman
    
            (U.S. government)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
<p>“My son’s opioid exposure was less than two months,” Don Holman told <a href="https://docs.house.gov/meetings/FA/FA16/20180906/108650/HHRG-115-FA16-Transcript-20180906.pdf#page=100">a hearing of the House Foreign Affairs Committee</a> the next year. “At 20 years old, I do not believe my son deserved to die for his initial bad choices.”</p>

<p>The father handed over evidence, including the envelope in which the drugs arrived, to federal agents, who traced about 20 shipments back to the same sender in China, he said in an interview. Don Holman blames the fentanyl crisis on the American appetite for opioids as well as the Chinese government. He has spent eight years telling anyone he can, from drug czars to fellow parents, about the experience that shattered his family.</p>

<p>“I’ve had to hit parents right between the eyes, like: ‘Hey, your child is not going to be here if you don’t do something,” he said. “You need to wake up.’”</p>

<p>No link to Yafeng surfaced in that case. The firm’s sales of U-47700 and other illicit drugs occurred during a period when its sole owner and controlling shareholder was the Shijiazhuang prison, according to the House inquiry, Sayari and C4ADS.</p>

<p>One of Yafeng’s street addresses was that of the prison, ProPublica determined through satellite photos and public records. Another Yafeng address next door also houses the offices of a clothing firm owned by the provincial prison administration. A third Yafeng address a few blocks away is a former municipal police station, records and photos show.</p>

<p>The director of the prison, Liu Jianhua, left his post after becoming the target of a corruption inquiry in 2021, according to Chinese media reports. It’s unknown how that investigation was resolved or if his fall had anything to do with the drug activity. Liu could not be reached for comment. The prison administration did not respond to requests for comment.</p>

<p>Yafeng stopped doing business under that name at some point between 2018 and 2022, records show. Yet the Yafeng group continued to function through at least one of its affiliated websites, protonitazene.com, the congressional report said. As of last year, the site was still advertising “hot sale to Mexico” of drugs including nitazenes, which are 25 times more powerful than fentanyl.</p>

Government Incentives
<p>Yafeng is not the only company with connections to the Chinese state and fentanyl.</p>

<p>Gaosheng Biotechnology in Shanghai is “wholly state-owned,” congressional investigators found. The company sold fentanyl precursors and other narcotics — some illegal in China — on 98 websites to U.S., Mexican and European customers, <a href="https://docs.house.gov/meetings/ZS/ZS00/20240416/117142/HRPT-118-1.pdf#page=20">the report says</a>. Senior provincial development officials visited Gaosheng and praised its benefits for the regional economy. Gaosheng did not respond to requests for comment.</p>

<p>The Chinese government owned a stake in <a href="https://docs.house.gov/meetings/ZS/ZS00/20240416/117142/HRPT-118-1.pdf#page=23">Zhejiang Netsun</a>, a private firm that had a Chinese Communist Party member serving on its board of directors as a deputy general manager, the congressional report says. Netsun carried out over 400 sales of illegal narcotics, the report says, and served as a billing or technical contact for over 100 similar companies — including Yafeng. Netsun did not respond to requests for comment.</p>

<p>And the Shanghai government gave monetary awards and export credits to Shanghai Ruizheng Chemical Technology Co., a “notorious seller of fentanyl products, which it advertises widely and openly on Chinese websites like Alibaba,” <a href="https://docs.house.gov/meetings/ZS/ZS00/20240416/117142/HRPT-118-1.pdf#page=20">the report says</a>. Chinese officials invited company reps to roundtable discussions about technology and business. Shanghai Ruizheng did not respond to requests for comment.</p>
        
    
                            
    
                    
<p>Chinese government officials who interact with the trafficking underworld are often prominent in provincial governments, where corruption is widespread, said a former senior DEA official, Donald Im, who led investigations focused on China. Not only can they make money through kickbacks or investments, but they benefit politically, rising in the Communist Party hierarchy if their local chemical industries prosper.</p>

<p>“Key government officials know about the fentanyl trade and they let it happen,” Im said.</p>

<p>China’s central government also plays a vital role by providing systemic financial incentives that fuel fentanyl trafficking to the Americas, U.S. officials say. The House inquiry <a href="https://docs.house.gov/meetings/ZS/ZS00/20240416/117142/HRPT-118-1.pdf#page=11">discovered a national Value-Added Tax rebate program</a> that has spurred exports of at least 17 illegal narcotics with no legitimate purpose. They include a fentanyl product that is “up to 6,000 times stronger than morphine,” the House report says.</p>

<p>This state subsidy program has pumped billions of dollars into the export of fentanyl products, including ones outlawed in China, according to the report and U.S. officials. The tax rebate is 13%, the highest available rate. To qualify, companies have to document the names and quantities of chemicals and other details of transactions, the report says.</p>

<p>The existence of this paper trail refutes a frequent claim by Chinese leaders: that weak regulation of the chemical sector makes it impossible to identify and punish suspects.</p>

<p>Chinese officials did not respond to specific questions about the government financial incentives or the state-connected companies involved in drug trafficking. But the embassy spokesperson said China has targeted online sellers with a “national internet cleanup campaign.”</p>

<p>During that crackdown, Liu Pengyu said, Chinese authorities have cleaned “14 online platforms, canceled over 330 company accounts, shut down over 1,000 online shops, removed over 152,000 online advertisements, and closed 10 botnet websites.” He said Chinese law enforcement has determined that many illegal ads appear on foreign online platforms.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            Collage by Mike McQuade for ProPublica. Source images: U.S. government.
    
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
Wall of Resistance
<p>In May 2018, Cronin — then a federal prosecutor based in Cleveland — went to Beijing in pursuit of one of the biggest targets in the grim history of the fentanyl crisis: the Zheng drug trafficking organization, an international empire accused of trafficking in 37 U.S. states.</p>

<p>Cronin and his team of agents hoped to persuade Chinese authorities to prosecute <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mkyLQEnFggE">Guanghua and Fujing Zheng</a>, a father and son who were the top suspects. They ran into a wall of resistance.</p>

<p>In an interview, Cronin recalled walking into a cavernous room in China’s Ministry of Public Security where a row of senior officials and uniformed police waited at a long table. A curtain-sized Chinese flag covered a wall.</p>

<p>Cronin took a breath, opened a stack of binders he had lugged from Cleveland and presented his case. The prosecutor laid out evidence connecting the Zhengs, who were chemical company executives based in Shanghai, to two overdoses in Ohio. The U.S. distribution hub was a warehouse near Boston run by a Chinese chemist, Bin Wang. Later, Wang said he simultaneously worked for the Chinese government “tracking chemicals produced in China” and traveled home monthly from Boston “to consult with Chinese officials,” a memo by his lawyer said.</p>

<p>The response of the Chinese counterdrug chiefs was a brush-off, Cronin recalled in the interview. Essentially, he said, they told him: “You are right that the Zhengs are exporting these drugs that are killing Americans. But unfortunately, technically what they are doing is not a violation of Chinese law.”</p>

<p>Cronin pulled out another binder. He went over evidence and an expert analysis showing that the Zhengs had committed Chinese felonies, including money laundering, manufacturing of counterfeit drugs and mislabeling of packages.</p>

<p>Tensions rose when the Chinese officials responded that, unfortunately, the police unit that handled such offenses was not available; they rebuffed Cronin’s offer to delay his return flight in order to meet with that unit, he said.</p>

<p>After the U.S. Justice Department <a href="https://www.justice.gov/archives/opa/pr/two-chinese-nationals-charged-operating-global-opioid-and-drug-manufacturing-conspiracy">charged the Zhengs</a> that August with a drug trafficking conspiracy resulting in death, a Chinese newspaper reported that a Chinese senior counterdrug official criticized the case. The U.S. “failed to provide China any evidence to prove Zheng violated Chinese law,” the official said.</p>
        
    
                    

    
        

                        
                    
                

            Thomas Rauh
    
            (Courtesy of James Rauh)
    
    
    

    

        
    
                    
<p>Later, the U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned the Zhengs and designated the son as a <a href="https://ofac.treasury.gov/media/44656/download?inline">drug kingpin</a>. U.S. investigators told ProPublica they concluded that the Zhengs operated with the blessing of the Chinese government, citing the defendants’ sheer volume of business, high-profile online activity and open communications on WeChat, the Chinese messaging platform that authorities heavily monitor.</p>

<p>Ohio courts granted millions of dollars in civil damages to the family of Thomas Rauh, a 37-year-old who died of an overdose in Akron in 2015. The family never received any money, however.</p>

<p>Rauh’s father, James, who traveled and did business in China in his youth, has become an antidrug activist. He said the U.S. government must do more to crack down on China’s role and counter public stigma that still blames addicts.</p>

<p>“I don’t think the U.S. government wants to take the responsibility for confronting this,” he said.</p>

<p>A decade of frustration has compelled James Rauh to call for a drastic solution. He wants the U.S. to designate fentanyl as a weapon of mass destruction in response to what he sees as an intentional Chinese campaign.</p>

<p>“It’s asymmetric warfare,” he said.</p>

<p>The Zhengs remain free in China and have never responded to the allegations in court. During a brief encounter with a “60 Minutes” journalist in Shanghai in 2019, Guanghua Zheng denied he was still selling fentanyl in the United States and said the Chinese government “has nothing to do with it.” <a href="https://www.justice.gov/usao-ndoh/pr/chinese-national-sentenced-nearly-six-years-prison-distributing-opioids-and-other-drugs">Wang</a> pleaded guilty and served prison time.</p>

<p>The Zheng case is typical, said Im, the former senior DEA official. Thousands of DEA leads relayed to Chinese counterparts over the years have been “met with silence,” he said. In other cases, Chinese officials have asked for more details about the targets of U.S. investigations — and then warned suspects linked to the Communist Party, Im said.</p>

<p>Most U.S. national security officials interviewed for this story described similar experiences, citing a few exceptions, such as a <a href="https://www.npr.org/2019/11/07/777173066/china-jails-9-in-fentanyl-trafficking-case-that-began-with-a-u-s-tip">joint U.S.-Chinese operation</a> in Hebei province in 2019.</p>

<p>A former DEA agent, William Kinghorn, recalled the dispiriting aftermath of an investigation he oversaw centered on <a href="https://www.state.gov/chuen-fat-yip">Chuen Fat Yip</a>, whose firms allegedly distributed more than $280 million worth of drugs. Yip has denied wrongdoing and <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/chinas-suspected-fentanyl-king-claims-hes-being-framed-by-pepsi-coke/">denounced U.S. criminal charges</a> and sanctions. He is on the DEA’s 10 most wanted fugitives list and remains free in China, U.S. officials said.</p>

<p>“We obtained information that the Chinese authorities did ban or shut down the companies” the DEA targeted in the case, Kinghorn said in an interview. “We learned that afterward these same people [linked to Yip] were now owning or managing similar companies. Even though they had been banned, they basically just changed the name of the company.”</p>

<p>A sense of impunity persists in the chemical industry, according to <a href="https://www.elliptic.co/blog/chinese-businesses-fueling-the-fentanyl-epidemic-receive-millions-in-cryptocurrency-payments">a 2023 inquiry</a> by Elliptic, a U.K. analytics firm. It reported that many of the 90 Chinese companies contacted by its undercover researchers were “willing to supply fentanyl itself, despite this being banned in China since 2019.”</p>

<p>The final year of the Biden administration brought signs of modest progress in China, including new regulations, shutdowns of firms, and arrests of a suspected money launderer and four senior chemical company employees charged by U.S. prosecutors.</p>

<p>Citing those cases from 2024, spokesperson Liu Pengyu said China has “collaborated closely” with the U.S., adding, “Multiple major cases are making great progress.”</p>
        
    
                            
    
                    
<p>Meanwhile, U.S. overdose deaths fell by 33% compared with the previous year, according to <a href="https://www.dni.gov/files/ODNI/documents/assessments/ATA-2025-Unclassified-Report.pdf#page=5">the annual threat assessment by the U.S. intelligence community</a> released March 25. The drop may be tied to the increased availability of naloxone, a drug for treating overdoses, the report said.</p>

<p>The threat assessment report warned that “China likely will struggle to sufficiently constrain” companies and criminal groups involved in the U.S. fentanyl trade, “absent greater law enforcement actions.”</p>

<p>Cronin, the former federal prosecutor, went on to become chief investigative counsel for the House Select Committee. He led last year’s inquiry into China’s role in the fentanyl crisis. The committee’s review of seven Chinese company websites <a href="https://docs.house.gov/meetings/ZS/ZS00/20240416/117142/HRPT-118-1.pdf#page=28">found over 31,000 instances</a> of firms offering illegal chemicals during a period of about three months in early 2024.</p>

<p>Undercover communications with the firms “revealed an eagerness to engage in clearly illicit drug sales,” the report says, “with no fear of reprisal.”</p>
        
             

                                    
        
                        <p><a href="https://www.propublica.org/people/kirsten-berg">Kirsten Berg</a> contributed research.</p>
=== ENTRY END ===

=== ENTRY START ===
Title    : The Trump Administration’s War on Children
Published: Wed, 23 Apr 2025 05:00:00 -0400
Summary  :
<p class="byline">
                by <a class="name" href="https://www.propublica.org/people/eli-hager">Eli Hager</a>                </p>
                                             

                                                                    
            
                <p>ProPublica is a nonprofit newsroom that investigates abuses of power. Sign up to receive <a href="https://www.propublica.org/newsletters/the-big-story?source=54G&amp;placement=top-note&amp;region=national">our biggest stories</a> as soon as they’re published.</p>

            

                

      
  



                    
<p>The clear-cutting across the federal government under President Donald Trump has been dramatic, with mass terminations, the suspension of decades-old programs and the neutering of entire agencies. But this spectacle has obscured a series of moves by the administration that could profoundly harm some of the most vulnerable people in the U.S.: children.  </p>

<p>Consider: The staff of a program that helps millions of poor families keep the electricity on, in part so that babies don’t die from extreme heat or cold, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/02/climate/trump-layoffs-energy-assistance-liheap.html#:~:text=The%20Trump%20administration%20has%20abruptly,their%20heating%20and%20cooling%20bills.">have all been fired</a>. The federal office that oversees the enforcement of child support payments has been hollowed out. Head Start preschools, which teach toddlers their ABCs and feed them healthy meals, will likely be <a href="https://apnews.com/article/head-start-office-closures-hhs-trump-00b1a6b33ef918cb66e59b7ffb07ac13">forced to shut down en masse,</a> some as soon as May 1. And funding for investigating child sexual abuse and internet crimes against children; responding to reports of missing children; and preventing youth violence has been withdrawn indefinitely. </p>

<p>The administration has laid off thousands of workers from coast to coast who had supervised education, child care, child support and child protective services systems, and it has blocked or delayed billions of dollars in funding for things like school meals and school safety. </p>

<p>These stark reductions have been centered in little-known children’s services offices housed within behemoth agencies such as the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Justice, offices with names like the Children’s Bureau, the Office of Family Assistance and the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention. In part because of their obscurity, the slashing has gone relatively overlooked.</p>

<p>“Everyone’s been talking about what the Trump administration and DOGE have been doing, but no one seems to be talking about how, in a lot of ways, it’s been an assault on kids,” said Bruce Lesley, president of advocacy group First Focus on Children. He added that “the one cabinet agency that they’re fully decimating is the kid one,” referring to <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-administration/trump-set-sign-executive-order-shuttering-department-education-rcna197191">Trump’s goal of shuttering the Department of Education</a>. Already, some 2,000 staffers there have lost or left their jobs.</p>
        
    
                    
<p>The impact of these cuts will be felt far beyond Washington, rippling out to thousands of state and local agencies serving children nationwide.</p>

<p>The Department of Education, for instance, has rescinded <a href="https://www.the74million.org/article/close-to-3-billion-in-pandemic-funds-in-jeopardy-as-education-department-abruptly-halts-payments/">as much as $3 billion</a> <a href="https://www.chalkbeat.org/2025/03/31/linda-mcmahon-cancels-covid-relief-spending-extensions-for-schools/">in pandemic-recovery funding</a> for schools, which would have been used for everything from tutoring services <a href="https://marylandmatters.org/2025/03/31/maryland-faces-418m-catastrophic-loss-in-pandemic-era-relief-funds/">for Maryland students who’ve fallen behind</a> to making the air safer to breathe and the water safer to drink <a href="https://www.abc12.com/news/education/flint-community-schools-lose-15-6-million-of-unspent-covid-grants/article_586a4f8d-5894-4946-bea8-8cce39fcfd4d.html">for students in Flint, Michigan</a>. The Department of Agriculture, meanwhile, has <a href="https://stateline.org/2025/04/04/usda-cuts-hit-small-farms-as-trump-showers-billions-on-big-farms/">canceled</a> $660 million in promised grants to farm-to-school programs, which had been providing fresh meat and produce to school cafeterias while supporting small farmers. </p>

<p>At the Department of Health and Human Services, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the agency’s secretary, has dismissed all of the staff that had distributed $1.7 billion annually in Social Services Block Grant money, which many states have long depended on to be able to run their child welfare, foster care and adoption systems, including birth family visitation, caseworker training and more. The grants also fund day care, counseling and disability services for kids. (It is unclear whether anyone remains at HHS who would know how to get all of that funding out the door or whether it will now be administered by White House appointees.)</p>

<p>Head Start will be especially affected in the wake of Kennedy’s mass firings of Office of Head Start regional staff and news that the president’s draft budget proposes <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/education/2025/04/11/trump-proposal-eliminating-head-start/83045346007/">eliminating funding for the program altogether</a>. That would leave one million working-class parents who rely on Head Start not only for pre-K education but also for child care, particularly in rural areas, with nowhere to send their kids during the day. </p>

<p>Some local Head Start programs <a href="https://www.seattletimes.com/education-lab/central-wa-head-start-programs-shut-down-without-federal-funding/">are already having to close their doors</a>, and many program directors are encountering impediments to spending their current budgets. When they seek reimbursement after paying their teachers or purchasing school supplies, they’re being directed to a new “Defend the Spend” DOGE website asking them to “justify” each item, even though the spending has already been appropriated by Congress and audited by nonpartisan civil servants.</p>

<p>Next <a href="https://www.cbpp.org/research/health/republicans-in-congress-considering-harsh-medicaid-cuts-that-would-shift-costs-to">on the chopping block</a>, it appears, is Medicaid, which serves children in greater numbers <a href="https://www.kff.org/medicaid/state-indicator/medicaid-enrollees-by-age/?currentTimeframe=0&amp;sortModel=%7B%22colId%22:%22Location%22,%22sort%22:%22asc%22%7D">than any other age group</a>. If Republicans in Congress go through with the cuts they’ve been discussing, and Trump signs those cuts into law, kids from lower- and middle-class families across the U.S. will lose access to health care at their schools, in foster care, for their disabilities or for cancer treatment.</p>

<p>The Trump administration has touted the president’s record of “protecting America’s children,” asserting in a <a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/articles/2025/03/president-trump-is-protecting-americas-children/">recent post</a> that Trump will “never stop fighting for their right to a healthy, productive upbringing.” The statement listed five examples of that commitment. Four were related to transgender issues (including making it U.S. government policy that there are only two sexes and keeping trans athletes out of women’s sports); the other was a ban on COVID-19 vaccine mandates at schools that receive federal funding.</p>

<p>The White House, and multiple agencies, declined to respond to most of ProPublica’s questions. Madi Biedermann, a Department of Education spokesperson, addressed the elimination of pandemic recovery funding, saying that “COVID is over”; that the Biden administration established an “irresponsible precedent” by extending the deadline to spend these funds (and exceeding their original purpose); and that the department will consider extensions if individual projects show a clear connection between COVID and student learning. </p>

<p>An HHS spokesperson, in response to ProPublica’s questions about cuts to children’s programs across that agency, sent a short statement saying that the department, guided by Trump, is restructuring with a focus on cutting wasteful bureaucracy. The offices serving children, the statement said, will be merged into a newly established “Administration for Healthy America.” </p>
